PARA.TAB: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. R. G. Halverson OBE) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development. I refer the minister to his reported comments on ABC radio of March 13 this year, which were that Sydney West airport at Badgerys Creek needed to be `up and running as quickly as possible because that will further help reduce the noise problem of Sydneysiders'. Can he guarantee that his decision announced today to consider Holsworthy as an alternative site will not substantially delay construction of Sydney West airport?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I can say to the House that the decision today to run a parallel environmental impact study of both Badgerys Creek and Holsworthy is designed to give a guarantee to the people of Sydney that a second airport for Sydney—a Sydney West airport—will be constructed as quickly as possible. The whole purpose of what the government has announced today is to overcome the problem of the legacy of the previous government's delaying of the construction of a second airport for Sydney.

ANSWER.PARA: It is worth noting—and honourable members need to note this—that the previous government put all of its eggs into the one basket over Badgerys Creek. Indeed, it initiated an environmental impact study in January of this year. Had that proceeded, it could have raised the possibility that Badgerys Creek was an unacceptable site for an airport from an environmental point of view. Had that been the case, and with all your eggs invested in the one basket, it would have meant further delay to the construction of a second airport for Sydney. Our actions are designed to guarantee that, if an environmental impact study on Badgerys Creek proves a negative outcome from an environmental point of view, this government has an alternative to move to without further delay.

The one thing the people of Sydney are sick and tired of is further delay in constructing a second airport for Sydney. The reason they are concerned is that the delay in the construction of a second airport for Sydney further imposes more unnecessary aircraft noise over their heads. Our decision today is designed to give us a fallback position in case that environmental impact study provides us with an environmentally unacceptable outcome.

Can I reiterate to the House that it is this government's first priority to develop an airport at Badgerys Creek. We are determined to proceed with a second airport for Sydney. Our first priority is Badgerys Creek. This will minimise any further delay in the settlement of that outcome.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. I ask the Prime Minister: what action is the government taking to implement its election pledge to amend the Native Title Act to ensure its workability and to ensure that Aboriginal people, pastoralists and miners have new certainty in dealing with the difficult questions surrounding the whole issue?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the House will be aware that there is a lot of concern throughout the Australian community regarding the operation of the Native Title Act in its current form. In the election campaign the coalition parties committed themselves to a number of things. We said that we would retain the Native Title Act, and we will. We said that we would reserve the right to propose amendments to the Native Title Act to ensure its workability, and we will. We also said that we would respect the principles of the Racial Discrimination Act, and we will. In the next little while the government will be circulating a lengthy discussion paper—
—Here's Wilson!
—Order! It is not only the opposition that is delighted to see the member for O'Connor back with us.
—To complete the last of that trilogy, we said that we would honour the principles of the Racial Discrimination Act, and we will.

ANSWER.PARA: The government will shortly circulate a discussion paper that contains a number of options. Those options will not include a proposal through legislation to extinguish native title. The options will, however, include a number of proposals to address the unworkable features of the Native Title Act. One of the greatest and most legitimate complaints that I have heard from people in the mining industry and the pastoral industry is the proliferation of the practice whereby unsubstantial and vexatious claims are made across wide areas of land which have the effect of gumming up any prospect of early development. Because of the construction of the existing act, those claims trigger the right to negotiate principles under the existing legislation.

One of the options that will be proposed will result in a significant curtailment of the right to negotiate procedures under the existing legislation. I might remind the House that the right to negotiate procedures was not mandated by the decision of the High Court of Australia in Mabo No. 2 v. the State of Queensland, and the right to negotiate procedures of the existing act is unknown to other forms of common law title that exist in Australia.The notion that any option to propose a more stringent approach to the right to negotiate would be taking a right away from native title holders which has not been taken away from the holders of other common law titles in Australia would not be a valid argument.

This is a very difficult issue and there are strongly held opinions right across the political spectrum. I dare say there are people in the Labor Party who feel uneasy about the existing Native Title Act; there are certainly a lot of people in the coalition parties who believe it must be amended to make it more workable. And in proposing the options that we do propose we are responding to the concerns of pastoralists and the mining industry. We recognise that the economic future of this country depends on resource development and upon getting a set of laws which do not allow people who do not have substantial claims to stall development for years.

The complaints that are legitimately made about the present Native Title Act are that it is so widely cast, so cumbersome in its procedures and has so added to the original intent of the Mabo decision that it is being used by some in the community as an instrument to obstruct and delay legitimate development in this country.

That is something that must be addressed. We are going to try to address it in a way which respects the principles of the act and respects the survival of native title as decreed by the High Court of Australia in its decision but which does not give to the putative claimants of native title rights to obstruct, delay and obfuscate that are not available to the putative claimants of other common law titles throughout Australia.

I would have thought that that is a very effective way of responding to a difficult issue. The discussion paper we are putting out obviously is what it is called—a discussion paper. It indicates the disposition of the government at present. We invite people who are interested—including state governments and others in the community—to respond, and I hope that the legislation which follows from that process is legislation that can enjoy the support of the entire House.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development. Is the minister aware that for the six‐month period from November 1995 to April 1996, as compared with the 12‐month period previously, there was a 9.6 per cent growth in aircraft movements at Sydney airport? Can the minister guarantee that the existing curfew and cap on aircraft movements at Sydney airport will remain in place over the next five years?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The government when in opposition made a commitment to impose a cap of 80 aircraft movements per hour for Sydney airport. That is a commitment that we made in opposition and that we will now fulfil in government, as indeed we have in regard to a number of other commitments relating to Sydney airport.

ANSWER.PARA: In addition, the honourable gentleman raises the question of a curfew for Sydney airport. It is worth while reminding the House that the person who introduced legislation into this chamber to enforce that curfew through legislation is the now Prime Minister of Australia. Through that bill and the pressure that it imposed on the parliament, the Prime Minister gave to the people of Sydney—for the very first time—a guarantee through legislation that their curfew would be in place through the legislative process. I can answer the question proposed by the honourable gentleman by saying yes, the cap for aircraft movements will remain, as our commitment stated it would, and indeed the legislation surrounding the curfew and the consequences of that legislation will remain.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Has the Prime Minister's attention been drawn to reports of possible significant delays in the Senate in relation to the passage of government legislation? What will be the consequences of such delays for good government, for jobs and for the environment in all parts of Australia?
—Mr Speaker, under standing order 144, the question is hypothetical and is out of order.
—There is no point of order.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention has been drawn to the current disposition of the opposition and the minority parties in the Senate to delay, at least until 20 August, a vote on the Telstra privatisation legislation.

ANSWER.PARA: I think it raises a very interesting question, and that is that we have been told by the Australian Democrats since the election that there are no circumstances in which the Australian Democrats will vote in favour of a one‐third privatisation of Telstra.

If that is the case, then I think the Australian people are entitled to ask, `Why on earth are they wasting the time and money of the Australian Senate to have a committee inquiry into something they say they have already made up their minds on?' The Australian Democrats apparently want until 20 August to dream up some excuse to the environmentalists of Australia as to why they are going to vote down the best environmental package this country has seen since World War II.

No amount of bobbing and weaving and procedural devices by the Australian Democrats can alter the fact that only one issue is at stake in this Telstra legislation: are you for or against a good environmental package? We on this side of the House are in favour of a good environmental package.

The longer this debate goes on, more and more the Australian people are going to ask: why is it that the Australian Labor Party, the Australian Democrats and the Australian Greens are against cleaning up the River Murray? Why is it that the Australian Democrats and the Australian Labor Party are against cleaning up water pollution? Why is it that the Australian Democrats and the Australian Labor Party are against doing something about ocean outfall?
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You can interrupt, yabber and jabber along over there as long as you like, but nothing is going to absolve you. And every day that goes by the more you will be indicted by the true environmentalists of this country as not being the least bit interested.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development. Given your encouragement and plans for a new international airport at Holsworthy with several 5,000‐metre runways, what consideration have you given to the fact that: Holsworthy is directly surrounded by 500,000 residents in the south‐west Sydney arc from Bankstown to Liverpool to Campbelltown; that thousands of young home buyers have recently purchased homes in Holsworthy—homes that you will now have to acquire; and that the last time your department made an assessment of Sydney's second airport needs Holsworthy was ranked second last out of 10 options due to its close prox imity to residential areas, its high cost, environmental concerns and the large number of unexploded bombs on the military site?
—And the fact it is a whole series of ravines.
—The Leader of the Opposition had better watch out or there will be a bomb under him in a minute.

—Minister, your proposal is a farce and a lifestyle disaster for families in the electorates of Blaxland, Banks, Werriwa, Hughes and Fowler. Can you assure this House and those families that this madcap plan will not proceed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I can assure the honourable gentleman that the government's first priority is to develop an airport to resolve the aircraft noise problems of Sydney. I can also assure the House that the government's first priority is to develop Sydney's second airport at Badgerys Creek.

ANSWER.PARA: The environmental impact studies that were done in 1985, which the honourable gentleman referred to in his question, highlighted a number of factors. It also needs to be remembered that in 1985 when Badgerys Creek was being considered for selection as a possible site for a second airport it was in a country area without much urban development.

Honourable members would be aware that since 1985 urban development has moved rapidly into the Badgerys Creek area, particularly under the flight paths that would exist if an airport was constructed at Badgerys Creek.

If the honourable gentleman who asked the question looks at an overall map of Holsworthy, he will note that Holsworthy offers something quite unique for any of these sites. That is, it offers flight paths to and from the south that are over uninhabited areas, which is something that cannot be said about Badgerys Creek.

Can I also deal with the specific instances that the honourable gentleman referred to in relation to Holsworthy. There were two issues of concern in the 1985 EIS selection process in relation to Holsworthy. The first was unexploded ordnance, or bombs as he prefers to call them, and the second was the terrain.

BREAK.PARA: On the first issue of unexploded ordnance, members of the House need to be aware that since 1985 technology has moved on. We are advised that the unexploded ordnance problem is no longer a reason not to consider Holsworthy as a possible site for a second airport.

Both sites, either Badgerys Creek or Holsworthy, have major engineering problems in relation to terrain. Badgerys Creek is not billiard table flat. Both sites have problems. Both sites will be considered in a proper environmental impact study and a judgment will be made following the completion of that study as to the correct decision for this government to make on developing a second airport for Sydney to alleviate aircraft noise problems for Sydney residents.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. What are the implications for the future sound management of the economy of failing to deal with the $8 billion `poisoned chalice', the $8 billion budget black hole, left to this government by Labor? Would the government ever consider as a deliberate policy choice at a time of sustained economic growth, ignoring the opportunity to eliminate the budget deficit?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fahey, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I have noted on a number of occasions now that the Leader of the Opposition gets a little upset when this side of the House refers to the deficit this government inherited as Beazley's black hole. He also gets upset when it is referred to on this side of the House—
—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. There is a form of the House which enables ministers to make statements. In previous parliaments this has been raised. I suggest he make a statement.
—Order! There is no point of order. The minister will answer the question.

—When members on this side of the House refer to the deficit we inherited, they say those who are concerned about it should send the bill to Beazley. If he does not like those sayings, perhaps he should consider a comment that was made in an article by Terry McCrann. It was dated 16 April and the title was `Beazley inherits his $8 billion poisoned chalice'. The reference in that article was to the fact that the budget did not just turn sour in the space of two days. We found out two days after we got to government what the true state of the economy and the accounts were. The Leader of the Opposition used a certain defence in respect of that. About that, Terry McCrann said:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . and you, Beazley, were part of the small cabal that set out quite deliberately to lie to the voters through the campaign by declining to have them updated and released.
Deliberately lie. If he does not like that, perhaps he should refer—

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Speaker: I ask that the statement `deliberately lie' be withdrawn.
—Why? He read it.
—No, he read it—then he went and repeated it, himself. I want that second accusation withdrawn.
—Minister, the Leader of the Opposition has found your comments offensive. I invite you to withdraw your comments.
—I withdraw the comments I made and rely upon the quote.
—I take the point that he should withdraw unreservedly.
—I ask the minister to withdraw in the appropriate and proper manner.
—I withdraw, Mr Speaker. On 13 March, Alan Ramsey wrote an article entitled `A surplus—of Labor fantasy'. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: Keating, Willis and Beazley, as the key co‐conspirators, went through the election campaign telling people Labor's day‐to‐day handling of the economy was in surplus and would remain in surplus.
He went on to say:
This is what is known in acceptable parliamentary language as an "untruth".

We now know the real reason for the deficit. The shadow Treasurer yesterday, while musing on the fact that there is a deficit in the economy, told the people of Australia and the people of this House that there is a reason for it. What he said is quite illuminating. He asked a rhetorical question:
How come the budget is not in better shape after 4½ years of sustained growth?
He said:
Let me answer it by saying it is not a product of mismanagement . . . it is a product of deliberate policy choice.

That was the answer given by the shadow Treasurer, that the deficit is a product of deliberate policy choice. The people of Australia would like to know whether the foreign debt which blew out under Labor from $23 billion to $185 billion was a product of deliberate policy choice. What we have inherited is the responsibility to clear that deficit. That is why the Australian people put us in government, to make sure that we take the pressure off interest rates, give small business a chance to increase growth in employment, and give the economy a chance to grow. That is why Labor was thrown out.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Finance. In the light of his comments in answer to the question he has just received, does he consider the failure of the now Prime Minister, then Treasurer, in 1983 to release a $25 billion budget deficit figure in today dollar terms that he was advised of in the last election campaign as a deliberate lie or a piece of statesmanship?
—Let me answer that by saying that I referred a short time ago—
—Before you proceed with your answer, the Leader of the Opposition used the term—
—I asked him whether he thought it was a deliberate lie.
—The Leader of the Opposition is treading very closely to the forms of the House. I remind him of that.
—The answer, Mr Speaker, is no.
—My question is also to the Minister for Finance and Acting Treasurer.
—No.
—You had nobody standing, so pipe down. You missed your cue.
—Order! The member for Capricornia was not on his feet when I called the Deputy Leader of the Opposition.

—I ask the minister: do you acknowledge that Australia, when measured against all comparable industrialised economies in the OECD, has the second lowest general government expenditure, the fourth lowest public debt and the second lowest structural deficit? Why, under these and other circumstances, did you say last month that the $8 billion worth of budget cuts that you were chasing were fixed in stone—or aren't you saying that any more?

—On 12 March the Treasurer indicated to the Australian people that this government had inherited a deficit of $8 billion. The Treasurer also indicated at that time that it was this government's intention to address that deficit, and that we would do so by savings. That is the task which we are now undertaking. That particular task will be completed on 20 August. I am sure that on 20 August the shadow Treasurer will be most interested in the manner in which we have addressed that task, because we will achieve it.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Given that the government's industrial relations reform legislation was a key component of the election platform, will the minister please indicate when the legislation will be introduced into this parliament.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The government is on track to introduce the legislation very shortly. It has been a significant task to translate the coalition's policy at the last election to an important piece of legislation for consideration by the House. We are obviously putting the finishing touches to that. I do want to express my gratitude to the many people who have been involved in the process, including the member for La Trobe, who has been the chairman of the backbench committee and who has been very involved in the drafting and the consultative work.

ANSWER.PARA: The consultations in the drafting of the legislation have been very intense and extensive. The consultative process has also been very constructive and worth while. The National Labour Consultative Council has provided us with assistance—and, in particular, the committee on industrial legislation, which is the technical subcommittee of the NLCC, which is comprised of representatives of the ACTU and the ACCI.

I have personally been involved in meetings of 20 hours or more duration, specifically in the COIL meeting. Apart from the COIL meeting, other meetings with unions have included the CPSU, the AMWU and other unions. I have even had discussions in more general terms with unions such as the CFMEU and, dare I say it, with the New South Wales Trades and Labour Council. In each and every case, whilst there are obvious differences—

TALK.START.PARA: —The MUA.

—No, you are the one who spoke to the MUA, Prime Minister, at an afternoon tea last week. Whilst obviously many of the unions have a particular view, beyond the public position, on a private basis a number of those to whom I have spoken have been prepared to offer constructive comments, not for political benefit but in the interests of our having good legislation, which is important to the rank and file trade unionists.

PARA.BREAK: We have had consultations with, as I mentioned, the ACCI, and also with the Australian Chamber of Manufactures, the Australian Mines and Metals Association, the BCA, COSBOA, the HIA, the Master Builders, the Metal Trades Industry Association, the Minerals Council of Australia, the National Farmers Federation, and the Motor Traders Association of Australia. I particularly mention the MTAA as they have many small businesses within their constituency, as do other organisations. We have been very intent on ensuring that our package is relevant, appropriate and easy for small business, because they have had to deal with the com plexities of Labor's scheme for many years. As a result, when people see the bill, they will see that one of its many great advantages is its operation as far as it affects small business. I have also had a range of other consultations on an individual basis and, of course, with a number of companies.

ANSWER.PARA: I say that against the backdrop of discussions about the time which the Senate will need to deal with these issues. I urge the Senate to give reasonable time to the coalition's proposal and not to delay it. I say that because there are many benefits in the package which do need to be introduced as soon as good sense would allow.

I was concerned—I have not heard any confirmation of this report—to read a report this morning that suggested that the Democrats' view was that the bill was such a massive overhaul of industrial relations there was no chance of having it passed by the government's 30 June deadline. The truth is that the bill is a fair articulation of that which we took to the last election. It is a fair statement of the policy which we have presented. It would be a breach of our responsibility if we did not impress upon the Senate that the Australian people have supported this legislation. They have called on us to proceed apace with this legislation, within reason. We have done so. We look forward to its reasonable passage through the Senate in due course.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is again addressed to the Minister for Finance and Acting Treasurer. Can he advise the House of the expected impact on the Australian economy of the recent strong appreciation of the Australian dollar? Are you factoring that into your budget strategy? If so, how? If not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fahey, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am impressed that the shadow Treasurer is interested in such things as the value of the Australian dollar because he was part of the Labor government in 1986 when home mortgage interest rates were 15½ per cent, and that continued for 18 months. In 1989, home mortgage interest rates, under a Labor government of which the shadow Treasurer was a part, were 17 per cent. It took a recession to get them down at that point.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. Quite clearly, this is not relevant to the question. The question was about the value of the currency, not interest rates. I suggest you bring the minister to order. He obviously doesn't know what he is talking about.
—The appreciation of currency has an impact which is widespread. There is no point of order.
—Mr Speaker—
—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. The Speaker is not supposed to provide advice to ministers in trouble. If you are not in that situation, sir, your possession of independence—
—There is no point of order.

—When Labor inherited government in 1983, the home mortgage real interest rate was two per cent. When the coalition inherited government in 1996, the home mortgage real interest rate was seven per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: It is very clear that the economic management of the opposition when in government left this country in a mess. The Leader of the Opposition does not like to be blamed for the black hole that we have inherited—the poisoned chalice, surplus of fantasy, call it what you like. This government will address the problem in the interests of the Australian people.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Has the minister seen reports that the passage of the government's industrial relations reform package should be opposed because it allegedly reduces the role of the Industrial Relations Commission? Can the minister inform the House whether the government actually intends to reduce the powers of the commission?
—I have seen these reports and I must say they are absurd.

—On a point of order, Mr Speaker: the standing orders quite clearly say that ministers cannot be asked to announce government policy. This is certainly an announcement of government policy and it is out of order.
—The minister is not about to reflect on an announcement of government policy so far as I am aware in the very beginnings of his answer. There is no point of order.

—It is an absolute nonsense to say that we are gutting the commission. Those who argue that are really saying that there should be absolutely no change to the commission. It is all the more absurd because the argument which is run on this is that, because we want to simplify the award system, that equals gutting the commission. The opposition, in particular Mr Keating in 1993, advanced the very argument for simplification that we are now advancing and you never heard anybody on their side saying, `Simplification equals gutting the commission.' It does not. Yes, it is changing the role of the commission, but the world is changing; Australia is changing.

BREAK.PARA: One of the problems under the last government was that they were not prepared to make the changes to allow Australians to get on and meet the challenges of that very change. In fact, it is our policy to make a series of changes to the commission. In some respects we are actually enhancing the role of the commission. Take awards, for example: we want awards to be simplified, but we also want them to be a genuine protection for people. If there is a breach of an award under proposals in the government's policy, we will increase the penalties for breaching awards. Those penalties have not changed for 20 years and we are going to bring them up to play a fair role.

We are also going to provide expressly for the commission to have a role as a mediator and we will ensure that the commission, on the consent of the parties, can make recommendations to assist parties with their employee relations. That actually will be an enhanced role for the commission.

The commission will be given greater power to resolve industrial disputes. In particular, the commission will be empowered to issue directions preventing or stopping industrial action. For those opposite who claim to be advocates of the commission, instead of canning that policy they ought to be supporting it. It is in the public interest that the commission, within the confines of the policy that we are advancing, should have a proper and reasonable power to deal with industrial disputes. The commission will also continue to be responsible for resolving intractable disputes where bargaining for a certified agreement threatens essential services or the economy.

I put it to members opposite that they should also reflect on the fact that the claim by the ACTU that it views the commission as an independent umpire is nonsense. The truth of the matter is that in Australian industrial relations for many years the unions only supported the role of the commission in so far as it supported the privileges of unions. That is not supporting the commission as an independent umpire. That is simply supporting their own vested interest. Unions have regularly defied the decisions of the commission when they disagreed with them. The Novacoal dispute, which has been in the press recently, is the latest case in point.

The ACTU opposes the commission's role in the resolution of demarcation disputes, a view now dutifully shared by the shadow minister for industrial relations. One only has to think back to the storm of abuse which was directed at the commission by both the previous Labor government and the ACTU at the time of the 1991 national wage case to understand just how spurious is the Labor movement's respect for the commission. They have a feigned respect, not a real respect, for the commission.

We do have a respect for the commission and we have a proper role for the commission in a modern industrial relations system. That is why the claim that we are gutting the commission is absolute nonsense. Yes, its role is changing, but I believe that its role needs to change if we are to make the changes to the system to give people a chance of a job in the future and, most importantly and unlike during Labor's 13 years, to give people a chance of earning more in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Finance aware that in the coalition's document Meeting our commitments the coalition forecast savings of $290 million over three years for its proposed pension bonus plan? The Department of Finance calculated the plan would generate much lower savings of between $24 million and $145 million over the three years. Are you aware, too, that in addition Finance noted that the plan would actually become a cost to the budget in the medium term? Has the government now received further departmental advice, which confirms the earlier Finance costing conclusion, that there is a hole of between $145 million and $260 million in this single election commitment? If so, how will the government be funding the shortfall whilst also meeting its election commitments?
—Day after day the opposition seeks to get details of the budget, which is due on 20 August. I simply suggest to the Leader of the Opposition that all will be revealed on 20 August.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism. Given the importance of the car industry to the Australian economy and particularly to my electorate of Kingston, I ask the minister: can he outline the government's commitment to supporting a viable and internationally competitive car industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —During the election campaign the government gave two commitments to the motor car industry: firstly, that there would be a productivity commission inquiry; and, secondly, that we would consult with the various interested groups within the industry. I have to say that I have consulted with the Treasurer in relation to the productivity commission inquiry as to its terms, and I will now draw together the various industry representatives to discuss with them the outcomes of those discussions. Following that, the Treasurer and I will announce terms for the productivity commission and its eventual scope.

ANSWER.PARA: While I am here I can say to the honourable member—as she is the member for Kingston and therefore hers is the electorate in which the Mitsubishi plant is located—that Mitsubishi in recent times has come forward with a new model, a very attractive model, which makes a substantial commitment in her electorate to the employment in that area—and not only to the employment in that area but also a substantial commitment to further investment. Also, very recently General Motors Corporation announced that it was putting a second line of production into the Elizabeth plant in the electorate of Makin. That is a commitment of $1.4 billion and another 700 jobs.

Both of these, together with the Ford commitment earlier in the year, indicate the very substantial commitment and benefit to employment and investment that the motor car industry brings to Australia. I am looking forward to a very positive outcome from the productivity commission inquiry.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beazley, Kim, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. I ask the Prime Minister: do you recollect remarks that you made during the election campaign, on 16 February 1996, at St Gregory's Primary School in Queanbeyan, where you said:

QUESTION.PARA: Can I make it clear. Take the migrant waiting periods. It doesn't apply to refugees, it doesn't apply in humanitarian circumstances. It of course doesn't apply to family allowance and other benefits.
Prime Minister, are you also aware of correspondence between you and the Minister for Social Security, Senator Jocelyn Newman, in which you say:

Notwithstanding your concerns about child-care assistance and child-care cash rebate and your desire to consult the Minister for Health and Family Services, I propose that two-year waiting period apply to these payments. In addition to the payments considered above, I propose that maximum family payment, formerly additional family payment, maternity allowance and multiple birth allowance, be included on the waiting period list. I am informed that the inclusion of maximum family payment will result in additional savings of approximately $1 million.

If you are aware of that particular item of correspondence between you and the Minister for Social Security, how do you rationalise that with your earlier statements? Is it yet another broken promise?

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly do remember the visit to St Gregory's. I do remember being questioned. I have no reason to doubt that the Leader of the Opposition has correctly read the transcript that was provided. I also recollect that there was a concise statement of the policy issue in relation to that in the document called Meeting our commitments , and the text of the letter that I wrote to the minister is completely consonant with the precise statement of the policy.
—My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Does the foreign minister intend to meet the Dalai Lama when he visits Australia later this year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Downer, Alexander, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Canning for her question. I have seen articles by one or two journalists in the last few days, belying their normal accuracy, suggesting that the coalition government may not be willing to meet the Dalai Lama, despite the fact that we had given a commitment during the election campaign to indeed have such meetings.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me just make it clear that the Australian government's policy since 1972 on the recognition of the People's Republic of China has implicitly recognised Tibet as part of the People's Republic of China. Nevertheless, having said that, we recognise, as I guess the previous government did, the Dalai Lama as a spiritual and cultural leader, a figure of very great international significance and a person who has visited Australia on two previous occasions—once in 1982, during the time of the Fraser government, and on the second occasion in 1992.

During the election campaign I wrote to Mr Stewart Johnson, the national president of the Australia‐Tibet Council. In that letter I said to him that senior government ministers and officials would be happy to meet with the Dalai Lama, subject of course to mutual availability. The Dalai Lama will be in Australia, I understand, between 14 and 29 September, and I myself am expected to be at the United Nations General Assembly for much of that period. But, having said that, just in case the miserably and sorry opposition is disappointed—

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—I am surprised that you do not want me to go to the United Nations General Assembly and get Australia elected to the security council; I am surprised. We know now the Labor Party's position, which is presumably to scuttle the show.

ANSWER.PARA: But I make the point—if I could get to the point that I want to make—that I will be happy, naturally enough, to meet the Dalai Lama on either 14 or 15 September. I would say that in committing myself to meet the Dalai Lama—and I am sure others in the government will be happy to meet him as well—I am upholding a commitment that in opposition the now government made and am carrying on a precedent now of quite some years standing.

I recognise that the Chinese ambassador has made a public request that a member of the Australian government does not meet the Dalai Lama. But, at the end of the day, we make the judgments about the people we meet here in Australia; ambassadors do not make those judgments for us.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beazley, Kim, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister and follows on from the question I asked him previously. He said in answer to the proposals that, whatever might have been said at St Gregory's Primary School in Queanbeyan, the Meeting our commitments document was consistent with the letter that he wrote to the Minister for Social Security. I ask the Prime Minister: is he aware that Mr Costello, the then shadow Treasurer, wrote in Meeting our commitments on 15 February 1996 that `full access to family payment and Medicare will be maintained for all migrants immediately on arrival'? I again remind him of the quote I referred to previously which came from his correspondence with Senator Newman. He said:

QUESTION.PARA: In addition to the payments considered above, I propose that maximum family payment, formerly additional family payment, maternity allowance and multiple birth allowance, be included on the waiting period list. I am informed that the inclusion of maximum family payment will result in additional savings of approximately $1 million.
Will he now confirm, as he would not previously, that he has broken an election commitment?

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not add anything to what I said earlier except to say that I will get hold of the Meeting our commitments document and I will have a look at the transcript. If I have anything to add I will. I repeat what I said earlier that it was my understanding when I wrote that letter that it was completely consonant with the commitment that had been made. There is a difference in the classification of family payments which you acknowledged in your question, so I would not crow too soon.

—My question without notice is addressed to the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs, who has responsibility for Customs. Has the minister seen reports in this morning's press alleging deficiencies in the administration by customs officers of the regulations governing the importation of guns into Australia? Are these reports correct?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Prosser, Geoff, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Wannon for his question and acknowledge the member's interest in this most important national issue. I have read the article in the Canberra Times which he referred to regarding the administration by Customs of import regulations, particularly concerning guns. Since being appointed minister responsible for Customs I have had two ombudsman reports on the deficiencies in handling personal search requirements and one other, audit report No. 20, regarding the deficiencies in the administration of the diesel fuel rebate scheme.

ANSWER.PARA: I have undertaken to address the issues. In relation to personal searches, I have ensured that changes have been made to the procedures to remedy the concerns expressed by the Ombudsman. In relation to the diesel fuel rebate, I have initiated actions to address concerns raised by the Auditor-General. In the most sensitive area of gun control, I have moved to close a loophole in the previous regulations and I have also made a commitment that these regulations will be enforced. What we are about in government is ensuring that proper administration of the law is adhered to.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also to the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs. I refer him again to the Customs Service internal minute which proposes 440 job cuts in that body. In your answer yesterday, Minister, you said that the proposed job cuts were due to the so-called $8 billion deficit. That same Customs minute shows this to be incorrect. It says that the cuts are entirely due to your election promises. Will you now explain how your actions will assist the crackdown on illegal drugs, weapons and pornographic material when you are going to gut the mechanism by which they can be checked?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Prosser, Geoff, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. We set out during the election campaign the savings measures that we intended to undertake to bring the budget, as we understood it at the time, back into surplus and to fund our election commitments. In addition to that, as my colleague the Minister for Finance has already set out today, we were left with an $8 billion black hole by you lot. Our commitment to fill that is pretty massive.

ANSWER.PARA: I might add that, in our discussions with Customs in regard to the administrative savings, we will not be compromising the border control of this country. I mentioned yesterday that we have some six million passenger movements into the country. We process them through advanced passenger processing, better X‐ray equipment—

TALK.START.PARA: —This is on cargo.

—I am pleased that the member has given me the opportunity to speak on cargo movements. The Customs department is right now engaged in processing cargo management procedures. Once implemented, they will process better those requirements. In regard to customs control and customs procedures, they will be able to better manage through a range of measures such as risk assessment, better targeting, procedural management, behaviour control and customs sniffer dogs. I tried to set out yesterday that it is impractical to search six million passengers. Target procedures and target resources are in place. The Customs Service is already carrying those procedures out.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I seek leave of the parliament to table the minute I referred to, which clearly shows that the cuts in question are due entirely to their election promises.

—My question without notice is addressed to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. Is the minister aware of recent comments concerning the impact of the government's policy of abolishing the existing restrictions on new schools? What would be the effect of the government's policy on public sector spending?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Dr David, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Swan for his question. I have seen in the press this morning comments on the impact of the removal of the existing bureaucratic restrictions on the establishment of non‐government schools on government spending.

ANSWER.PARA: The government's commitment to abolish the Labor Party's new schools policy is one of our longest standing policy commitments. The government believes that parents should be able to exercise freedom of choice in the school to which they send their children, whether that school is in the government or the non‐government sector. Furthermore, the government acknowledges that there is a public benefit in the education of all children and that it is therefore appropriate for public funding to be made available, regardless of the parents' choice.

BREAK.PARA: The new schools policy was established by the former government in 1985 to restrict parents in the exercise of their choice. It was called at the time the `no new schools' policy, and there are several things that I want to say to the House about this policy. Firstly, it failed in its principal object. In the 15 years between 1970 and 1985, before Labor introduced the new schools policy, the percentage of students in non‐government schools increased from 22 per cent to 25.8 per cent. In the 10 years of the new schools policy, from 1986 to 1996, the percentage increased from 26.4 per cent to 29.4 per cent, a faster rate of increase than before the policy was established.

So far as can be determined, therefore, the policy has affected this trend, if at all, only at the margins. But there is little doubt, firstly, that it has pushed up fees for those parents least able to afford them and it has therefore operated in a socially inequitable manner. Secondly, the policy has imposed a huge bureaucratic set of arrangements which have caused frustrations and costly delays of up to two years or more for parents wishing to establish new schools. Other community agencies and churches have been equally frustrated by these bureaucratic restrictions.

There are now in the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs eight people whose role it is to administer the policy. They service committees in states and territories that also involve people from state government and non‐government school organisations. They sit down for one month of every year, trying to prioritise the applications that have come before the committees. It is red tape and duplication of the states' services gone mad, and all because some parents want to exercise their freedom of choice for their children.

Let us be clear about this: it costs the taxpayer less when a child is educated in a non‐government school. I have been advised that the estimate is a saving to state budgets of an average of $1,800 per child.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's because the parents are going to pay.

—You should talk to Jennie George about freedom of choice, because she now seems to understand this, but you did not understanding it in the workplace and you do not understand it in relation to schools.
—Don't go on with that babble.

—So it is just babble, is it? Freedom of choice for parents is babble, is it? That is what you think of freedom of choice for parents. We will remember that, and every member of this House will remember that. You think freedom of choice is babble. All right!

BREAK.PARA: Let me be quite clear on this point: the government has no policy about the appropriate size of the government and non‐government school sectors. I want to remind all members of this House of the government's commitment to quality government school sectors. The distinction between the two sectors is perhaps becoming less important as time goes by, but the relative size of the two sectors is determined by the choices that parents make and the financial incentives that exist for parents to select a government school.

The principle of freedom of choice is increasingly recognised in all sectors as an important accountability principle, and it is being pursued now by a number of state governments within the government school systems. The government's policy will open up desirable, largely low‐fee options for lower income parents. I understand that the Anglican church is keen to move into this area of school provision.
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —This is `elitism', is it, in the western suburbs of Sydney?

—These are low‐income parents who have been largely disadvantaged by the opposition's bureaucratic policy. This government takes its promises seriously. Labor broke promise after promise from Paul Keating's l‐a‐w law tax cuts, right down to Beazley's black hole. In the election campaign we said:

BREAK.PARA: A coalition government will abolish the Labor government's unfair and inequitable new schools policy.
We will keep this promise.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs with responsibility for Customs. In answer to a question yesterday from my colleague the member for Franklin you talked about maintenance of customs inspections on passenger movements. Are you aware that the amount of illegal drugs going through South Australian ports as cargo and postal items is 50 times greater than the amount related to passenger movements? How is your decision to target the cuts in South Australia at non‐passenger cargo, together with the abolition of the inspection unit, going to assist the crackdown on drugs?
—It has happened in the last 2½ months! You are a joke.
—You can yell all you like, but I would like to hear the answer to my question.

—I thank the honourable member for his question. I might add that, if that has been happening, it has been happening for the last 13 years. I mentioned in my previous answer that, in the administration of Customs and the targeting of Customs personnel, this government intends to ensure outcomes are met.
—You are going soft on law and order.

—This Prime Minister is the person who is active in law and order. Have you forgotten about that? In regard to the process of Customs and the importation of illegal substances and narcotics, Customs are always mindful of targeting those areas. With the enormous number of movements—not only barrier but also shipping movements—in remote ports around Australia, Customs must target not only the ships and their destination but also the make‐up of the crew in a risk analysis for those areas. We intend to continue and step up that process. That process will not be compromised by any efficiency dividends gained out of Customs.
—Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Papers are tabled as listed in the schedule circulated to honourable members. Details of the papers will be recorded in the Votes and Proceedings and Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: The schedule read as follows—

Australian Science and Technology Council Act—Australian Science and Technology Council—Report—Developing long‐term strategies for science and technology in Australia—Outcomes of the study: matching science and technology to future needs 2010.

Christmas Island Phosphate Mining Corporation—Report on the audit of the account of receipts and payments and statement of the position in the winding up of the Corporation by Coopers & Lybrand, December 1995.
Employment, Education and Training Act—National Board of Employment, Education and Training—Australian Research Council, including the Board's comments—Reports—
Collaborative activities of the Institute of Advanced Studies, the Australian National University, January 1996.
Reviews of grants outcomes—
No. 19—Experimental physics 1988‐1992.
No. 20—Astronomy and astrophysics 1988‐1992.

Treaties—Texts of—

Treaty with Brazil on Extradition, done at Canberra on 22 August 1994

Exchanges of Notes constituting an Agreement with—

New Zealand, done at Canberra and Wellington on 25 and 29 January 1996, to extend the Agreement concerning Royal New Zealand Air Force Skyhawk Aircraft involvement in Australian Defence Force Air Defence Support Flying of 13 July 1990. The Agreement entered into force on 1 March 1996, the date specified in the Notes.

The Korean Peninsula Energy Development Organization (KEDO) regarding an Australian Financial Contribution to KEDO, done at Canberra and New York on 8 and 19 December 1995. The Agreement entered into force on 19 December 1995, the date of the Note in reply.

The United States of America concerning Certain Mutual Defence Commitments, done at Sydney and Canberra on 1 December 1995. The Agreement entered into force on 1 December 1995, the date of the Note in reply.
