TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, in this new era of independent speakers—I am still working out what that means—
—We both are.

—I would be grateful if you could go back to the question asked of the Minister for Finance about the currency, the budget and its implications. I ask you to look at not only the question and the answer but also your comments about relevance. Could you then explain to us all—or drop me a note—how the answer is in any way related to the question and advise us what your rules are on relevance.

PARA.BREAK: Quite clearly, you said some fine words when you were elected. We took you seriously. I, for one, wish to take you seriously, but that question and answer beggar the imagina tion. I would be grateful for a formal response to what your rules are on relevance.

TALK.START.PARA: —The member for Newcastle has already received some correspondence from me. I will review the nature of your question this afternoon and, if necessary, I will respond to you privately.
—I call the honourable member for Kalgoorlie.
—Thank you, Mr Speaker. I was beginning to feel like the invisible man.
—Do you have a question for me?

—Yes, I have, Mr Speaker. In the name of equity, I feel I am entitled to one question in 55 in this parliament, and I am not getting it. I have constantly jumped up before the Leader of the Opposition. While I realise that it is sometimes hard to see around the Leader of the Opposition, would you acknowledge that he is the leader of that opposition and not the leader of this opposition.

—We addressed the question of fairness and equity yesterday. We have reviewed the correspondence between the Speaker and the Chief Opposition Whip and, at the moment, there are no anomalies that cause any concern whatsoever in the way questions are apportioned in this House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding, Clyde, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I claim to have been misrepresented. In a column written by Mr Gerard Henderson of the Age this week, referring to the Telecom debate, he wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: "ALP backbencher Clyde Holding (falsely) alleged that foreign ownership of the Chilean "telecommunications network" was a "significant factor" in the military overthrow of Salvador Allende's government in 1973."

The fact is that, in making that statement, I was relying upon representations that were made to the US Senate Foreign Relations Committee in respect of ITT, an American national company, in 1967. I also relied on the evidence of President Allende when speaking to the United Nations in 1972. When citing ITT's own document, he accused ITT of `attempting to bring about civil war in my country'.
As one who generally has a high regard for Gerard Henderson's column, I am bound to say that this is one of those occasions when he is wrong and I am clearly and demonstrably correct.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The need for the government to ensure the construction of a second major airport for Sydney.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tanner, Lindsay, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the last election the coalition made a very clear commitment to build the second airport for Sydney. Its airports policy, which was quaintly named `Putting people first', stated, `The coalition will develop Sydney West airport to full international standard as a matter of priority.' In the Senate on 30 November last year Senator Parer, the then shadow minister for aviation, stated, `The development of Badgerys Creek should go ahead.' In the Sydney Morning Herald on 16 February this year, in an article titled `Liberals look at making Badgerys main airport', it was made plain that the Liberal Party was committed not only to building Badgerys but also to making it the No. 1 airport in the Sydney region.

SPEECH.PARA: For a few weeks after the election we had broadly a similar line emerging from the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) and other members of the government. On ABC radio on 13 March the minister stated:
We want to build a second Sydney airport, we want to build one that is capable of handling all international aircraft.
He also stated:

BREAK.PARA: The challenge for us is to minimise the impact of noise and to spread that noise impact more equitably and that's what we're trying to do by the reopening of the East-West runway, the selection of new flight paths, and obviously trying to get Sydney West Airport constructed in Badgerys Creek.

I specifically draw the House's attention to those last words in that quote. Subsequently, in the same interview, the Minister for Transport and Regional Development stated that, with respect to the government's commitment to Badgerys Creek, they were committed to `getting Sydney West airport up and running as quickly as we can'.

So far so good. Up until that stage it appeared that the government was sticking to the commitment to Badgerys Creek that had been established by the previous government and which it had stated numerous times prior to the election that it was going to maintain. Then things started to get a bit murky. Then we had a little speculation floating up about Goulburn—very fast trains that just happened to be in the minister's electorate. It was 200 kilometres from Sydney; nonetheless, it was a serious possibility.

Then there were a few hints about Newcastle and that maybe that would be a good place to have a second airport for Sydney. Then there were one or two rumours about Holsworthy, and the true agenda started to float to the surface. Yesterday on 2UE Alan Jones, in an interview with the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, stated:

So therefore the delay caused by the new environmental impact statement could be a good thing which enables you, particularly, to take a realistic view of all the social costs and perhaps knock the thing on the head?
The `thing' of course was the Sydney West airport at Badgerys Creek. The minister's response was, `That certainly could be the case, Alan.'

So the agenda starts to become clear. What was a clear, strong commitment on the part of the coalition prior to the election, and even for a few weeks after the election, suddenly gets a bit cloudy. Then we hear the litany of excuses gradually flowing from the minister as to why they have changed their position—`The runways are too short. There is not enough capacity for the proposed Badgerys Creek airport. It is not flat.' What a surprise! I think the term was `rugged terrain' or `undulating terrain'. He said that it will require a fair amount of cut and fill works. I would be surprised if there were too many places near Sydney that would not require cut and fill works to construct an airport. Apparently that is a major problem at Badgerys. He also said, `There are access problems. You need road and rail links. They have to be constructed. That is costly. There are other cost issues involved. There are problems with the prospective flight paths.'

It is hardly surprising, in the wake of this litany of problems the minister was putting forward, that Mr Jones concluded at the end of the program that there will be no airport built at Badgerys Creek. Maybe the minister got cut off at that point, but it was noticeable in the transcript that there was no response from the minister to that concluding statement by Mr Jones.

TALK.START.PARA: —He signed off.

—Maybe he signed off at an inopportune moment. Is the minister expecting us to believe that he has become aware of these aspects of the Badgerys Creek development over only the past few weeks? Is he expecting us to believe that he knew about some of the issues that he raised in this interview within only the last few days? Does he expect us to believe that he had not realised Badgerys Creek was going to require substantial investment in road and rail links and that he did not know the Badgerys Creek site was not flat?

BREAK.PARA: Does he expect us to believe that these things have been brought to his attention only in the past few weeks? Does he expect us to believe that he did not know there were some serious issues about flight paths and that some difficult choices would have to be made? Does he expect us to believe that he was completely unaware of these things?

What did he expect us to believe? What does he expect us to think was his development of policy in this area? Maybe he thinks we should believe that he hopped into the Range Rover at some stage, maybe last weekend, whacked on the Akubra and the RM Williams, went down to have a look for himself, got out the binoculars, checked around and said, `Oh, gee; this doesn't look like such a great place for an airport. It's got a lot of rugged terrain.'

We know that the National Party can be a bit amateurish at times. They have been out of government for a fair while and they occasionally have cowboy type people in some important positions. But it defies credibility to suggest that the minister was unaware, until the last few days, of these aspects of the proposed development at Badgerys Creek—that he did not know these sorts of things were problems and that obstacles had to be overcome.

When he gave his interview on ABC radio on 13 March, there was no mention of these sorts of problems. None of these obstacles was dealt with. It was full steam ahead: `Badgerys Creek, we're committed. The former government were wimps. The former government were only half‐hearted about it. They weren't really serious. They wanted only a little one. We want a fully‐fledged second Sydney airport at Badgerys Creek.'

He knew at that stage about the obstacles involved with building Badgerys Creek. He knew about the need for road and rail development. He knew about the cost. He knew that there would be a bit of earthmoving required. So why was he so committed a couple of months ago and why is he now backing away? The story seems to change about every half an hour. He is now using the term `fall back'. He wants Holsworthy as a fall back option. I do not think he used that term in his press conference today. It will be interesting to see whether it is in there.

PARA.BREAK: He wants Holsworthy as a fall back option. This is in spite of the fact that, when the Labor government examined all the options which led to the choice of Badgerys Creek over 10 years ago, Holsworthy finished second last out of 10 options. It did not even make the cut. He wants Holsworthy as a fall back option, in spite of the environmental problems associated there and the fact that the terrain at Holsworthy is even more rugged than the terrain at Badgerys Creek. It is full of ravines and gorges. In spite of the exist ence of numerous unexploded bombs on the site, Holsworthy is going to be the fall back option.

BREAK.PARA: Did the minister or anybody else in the coalition mention prior to the election anything of this to voters in electorates like Hughes? Did any of those voters know that part of the prospect of electing a coalition government might involve this? No, they did not. I can suggest a few serious reasons why this is happening.

The first is money for budget cuts. It was calculated that Badgerys would cost $83 million in 1996-97 and $73 million in 1997-98. So here is a bit of money those opposite can get by not having to spend it on the Badgerys proposal and slowing everything down on every other front. Secondly, it sends the second airport for Sydney off into the never-never. They can still pretend that they are committed to doing it and going ahead with it by saying to the people around KSA, `Don't worry. We're looking after you. We're going to build Sydney's second airport but just not quite yet.' Thirdly, they are letting the real agenda come through, which is basically to expand Kingsford Smith airport, to get rid of the curfew, to get rid of the cap and to have no second airport.

It is very significant that yesterday two people from absolute opposite ends of the spectrum on these issues, Chris Brown from the Tourism Task Force, which does not want Badgerys built, and the New South Wales Minister for Urban Affairs and Planning, Mr Knowles, both agreed that this meant that there would be no second airport for Sydney. Maybe it has something to do with the fact that we are likely to have a Lindsay by-election in the near future or the fact that Badgerys Creek is now surrounded by a number of marginal Liberal electorates and there are more safe Labor electorates around Holsworthy. Perhaps there are a few little political whiffs in there as well.

When we consider what has happened with respect to Kingsford Smith and the fact that Liberal‐National Party policy with respect to Kingsford Smith was essentially based on the need to get aircraft away from Bennelong and to give them some chance of winning Lowe, perhaps we should not be too surprised. Perhaps we should not be too surprised that policy is being developed based on putting the airport where it largely affects only safe Labor seats—maybe Hughes but mostly safe Labor seats—and making sure they hang onto seats like Macarthur, Lindsay and the rest.

The real agenda is to keep putting off the second airport, let pressure from the Olympics gradually build up and put the government in a position where it has no choice but to get rid of the cap and the curfew at Kingsford Smith airport. The political pressure from within the community to make sure that the Olympics are successful and that we do not have transport chaos, including with the airlines, at that time will be considerable. So the minister and the government are setting up a situation where ultimately the people who live near Kingsford Smith airport will suffer substantially as a result of these decisions.

The strategy is pretty straightforward. First, you cast a bit of doubt on Badgerys by saying, `Oh, no. There's all these obstacles. There's all these problems. It's pretty hard and it's very expensive.' Then suddenly the estimates of how much it is going to cost start multiplying. None of this was there before the election, of course. Then you float Goulburn, then you float Newcastle, then you suddenly insert Holsworthy, which did not pass the cut 10 or 12 years ago, and you slow things down a bit more. Maybe they will eventually get to Dubbo. There is still a chance. Dubbo is in there with a show of being the second airport for Sydney.

The consequences of this backflip are, first, that the last hope of having a second airport for the Olympics has gone. The Liberals half killed it by stopping the funding through the Senate when they stopped the sale of airport leases in the Senate which was needed to fund Badgerys. Second, the retention of the cap and the curfew is now under serious threat. The minister has told us he wants to share the pain at Kingsford Smith airport. Now we know why—there is going to be a lot more pain to go around. The potential jobs in western Sydney from a second airport are now under threat. Road developments that link different parts of Sydney will be abandoned. The sale of the lease at Kingsford Smith airport has been thrown into further confusion because that will be put back again.

The minister cannot even seem to get his head around when the decision is going to be. Yesterday he told Alan Jones that he will make a decision in a few weeks time. His representative said in this morning's Australian Financial Review that it would be within 12 months of the Badgerys' EIS. We are told today that there will be a decision after competing EISs and a comparative study. When the minister was asked in question time today whether there would be as a result of his decisions extra delay in the development of the second airport at Sydney west, he did not answer. All he said was, `We're committed to building a second airport as soon as possible.'

We probably had better give the coalition, now in government as well as when they were opposition, some credit for consistency in aviation policy. They are consistently inconsistent, consistently hypocritical and consistently very confused. Labor was committed to building a second airport and had committed money to doing so. It had made that subject to an environmental impact statement in order to ensure that concerns with respect to noise, environmental factors and the like could be properly taken account of. Until the Liberals intervened through the Senate, we were on track to build such an airport in time for the Olympics and in time to make sure that Sydney will be able to cope with the massive influx of tourists that the Olympics will inevitably produce.

Let us look at the Liberals in contrast. We all remember them in the late 1980s. Some of us were not in this place at the time, but in the late 1980s they were gung-ho advocates for the third runway, with John Howard leading the charge. When the government started to do something about it, they then changed their minds, saying, `Oh, no. This is terrible. This is going to produce all sorts of appalling consequences.' They were also gung-ho advocates for privatisation. They thought privatising airports was a great idea— and privatising everything would be a great idea. But when the government started to do it and started to sell leases to the airports what did the Liberals do? They blocked that in the Senate.

Then we had a situation where they supported building a second airport for Sydney at Badgerys Creek to take the pressure off Kingsford Smith airport and to make sure that people in the inner suburbs have a reasonable lifestyle. But, now that they are in government and they have a chance to do something about it, what do they do? They back away, obfuscate, put things off.

The fact is that the government are not committed to building a second airport for Sydney. They do not want to spend the money. They do not care about the residents around Sydney airport. They do not want to confront the practical obstacles that are involved in getting a second airport up and running as quickly as possible. This latest device is a transparent device to ensure that they can let the whole issue just drag on for a few more years and that they will not have to spend much money. They will just chop and change here and there, slide around a little and wriggle out from underneath their commitments to avoid investing in new airport infrastructure for Sydney and get to a point where the impending Olympics will give them the excuse they want to wriggle out of their commitments to look after the people who are living with great difficulties around Kingsford Smith airport.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr SHARP
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it amazing that members of the Labor Party could get up in this place and speak with any credibility on the subject of the handling of Sydney's airport problems, given their complete and utter failure over the last 13 years to deal with the very vexed questions of how to resolve the siting of the second airport and how to handle the management of aircraft noise over the heads of Sydneysiders.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no question in the minds of just about everybody in Sydney today as to who is to blame for the problems the coalition government inherited—the problems of aircraft noise and of the failure to develop a second airport for Sydney. The people in Sydney know that the truth is that the former Labor government—and their members stand in the House today pretending that they have some credibility in this area—is to blame for the problems we inherited on 2 March when we entered government after 13 years of Labor rule.

I think it is extraordinary that the shadow minister for transport, the member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner), stood up here today and expressed concerns about the status of Sydney's second airport and the aircraft noise problems, given the track record of Labor. They had 13 years in government and they failed to deal with this issue adequately.

It is very interesting to note that the subject we are discussing today—that is, the second airport for Sydney—has been the subject of discussion and debate in this House for nearly 30 years. In recent years, it has been the subject of considerably more debate following the 1985 decision by the former Labor government to undertake an environmental impact study of 10 sites in the Sydney region that would be considered for the second airport.

In February 1986 the then government announced, following an EIS, that Badgerys Creek was the preferred site for a second airport for Sydney. It is interesting to note that at that time Badgerys Creek was not situated amongst a residential area, and the possible flight paths for an airport at Badgerys Creek would not have caused the occupants of houses under those paths the inconvenience and the aircraft noise that many of those people who live in the western parts of Sydney now endure.

In February 1986 a judgment from the government of the day said that Badgerys Creek was the best site. The government then proceeded to vacillate, to wax and to wane and to obfuscate when it came to providing reasons for the delay in construction of the airport at Badgerys Creek. In March 1989 they finally announced a staged development of Badgerys Creek and claimed that Badgerys Creek would be developed with a runway in operation by June 1995. So, after selecting the site in 1986 and spending three years delaying any further work on it, they finally announced a staged development of Badgerys Creek that would see the airport in operation by June 1995. Of course, we have gone beyond June 1995 and nothing has happened.

As concerns started to rise about aircraft problems and aircraft noise in Sydney, the then government showed fresh interest in Badgerys Creek. In December 1993, the former minister for transport, Senator Bob Collins, turned the first sod, amongst much media attention, at Badgerys Creek airport. A little while later—only a few days later, in fact—Senator Collins was no longer the minister for transport, and the member for Kingsford-Smith, Mr Brereton, was appointed.

As has been pointed out, it is important for members of the House to understand the history of this. If you understand the history of this, you will realise the hypocrisy shown by the people sitting opposite us today when they talk about possible delays to the development of the second airport in Sydney.

In December 1993 Laurie Brereton was appointed the Minister for Transport. Then, in March 1994, he decided that there would be an initial cutting ceremony for the site at Badgerys Creek and a special commemorative plaque was commissioned. All of that was due to take place on 10 March 1994. But that was cancelled. On 25 March another ceremony was organised for the initial cutting, and the minister dutifully appeared on top of a bulldozer to mark the beginning of the construction of the so‐called Badgerys Creek airport. In May 1994 the government of the day announced through its Working Nation statement that they would build a 2,900‐metre runway.

PARA.BREAK: We have seen the history of it, and the consequence of that history has been that we have seen a great deal of indecision and a great deal of delay. The last announcement made by the Labor Party in May 1994 was an attempt by them to convince the people of Sydney that they were fast-tracking the airport and developing it to accommodate more than just the overflow capacity from Sydney's major airport at Mascot. Of course, that decision in May 1994 delayed the develop ment and completion of that airport until at least 1998-99.

SPEECH.PARA: Late last year the then Minister for Transport, Mr Brereton, announced further delays to the development of Badgerys Creek airport and admitted that the airport would not be completed until some time after the year 2000—15 years after the decision to site the second airport for Sydney at Badgerys Creek and at least five years after the initial completion date was indicated by the former government.

It is interesting to note all of that history because, when you note that history, you realise that the people sitting opposite us in the Labor Party have no credibility when they talk about delays, inconvenience and the possibility of settling this issue of a second airport for Sydney. When we were in opposition we made a clear commitment to the development of a second airport for Sydney.

We said that, as part of that commitment, we would have an environmental impact study and that impact study would take into account the possibility of Badgerys Creek not being an environmentally suitable site. That is the commitment we made in opposition, and it is a commitment we fulfil today. I can assure the House this afternoon that the new government is determined to build a second airport for Sydney as quickly as possible and that attempts by the Labor Party to paint our announcement today as another reason for delay are totally wrong—totally and utterly wrong. We are determined, now more than ever, to build a second airport for Sydney as quickly as possible.

The reason for our decision today in announcing two parallel EISs is to overcome one of the major flaws we inherited from the previous federal government and that is, of course, the flaw that has been identified by many people living in western Sydney. I see the honourable member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) sitting here; she would be very much aware of the problems of Badgerys Creek. I have heard many complaints from elected representatives in the western and south‐western parts of Sydney talking about the problems in western Sydney.

TALK.START.PARA: —John, don't leave me out!

—And, of course, the member for Chifley, as he sits there so cheerfully. We are all aware of those problems, and we need to understand in the House today that the former Labor government put all of their eggs into the one basket called Badgerys Creek. If that environmental impact study that was to be undertaken by the former government and which is to be undertaken now by this government proved that Badgerys Creek was not an acceptable site from an environmental point of view, what would this government have done if they had not considered another site in the process?

SPEECH.PARA: What would the opposition have done if Badgerys Creek had been proven to be environmentally unacceptable? They would have had to go back to square one again. What would that have resulted in? Further delays and further inconvenience for people who suffer aircraft noise as a result of Kingsford Smith airport flight paths. What this government has decided to do is take out some insurance, if you would like to call it that. Our insurance is a position whereby, if an environmental impact study to be undertaken on Badgerys Creek proves that it is environmentally unacceptable to build an airport there, we can move to an alternative site straightaway, without any further delay.

If the Labor government were still in power today, the net consequence of that environmental impact study proving that Badgerys Creek was environmentally unacceptable would have resulted in further delays. As a consequence, we would have seen more inconvenience to people living in Sydney. This government is not causing delays; it is indeed taking out insurance against any delays as a consequence of an environmental impact study for Badgerys Creek. Our first preference, our first priority, our first order, is to develop Badgerys Creek. Within the possibility of Badgerys Creek being proven to be environmentally unacceptable, we will be able to move to an alternative site without further delay. For people to say that this is a delaying tactic is totally and utterly wrong because we are totally and utterly determined to develop an airport—a second airport for Sydney—as quickly as possible.

BREAK.PARA: There has been a matter raised by the honourable member for Melbourne, in his address to the House this afternoon, in relation to the possibility of expanding Sydney airport. Indeed, the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Albanese) also questioned whether we will lift the cap on aircraft movements per hour at Sydney's Mascot airport because of the impending Olympic Games. Can I say to the House today that we are committed to the maintenance of that 80 aircraft movements per hour at Sydney's Kingsford Smith airport. We are as committed today as we were in opposition. We are also committed to the curfews that were initiated as a consequence of John Howard's private member's legislation that was moved last year by him and which instilled that curfew in legislation.

We are also committed to not building another runway at Sydney's Kingsford Smith airport, which is the implication of what the honourable member for Melbourne was saying in his MPI address today. We are committed to one thing, and one thing only, and that is the construction, as quickly as possible, of a second airport for Sydney to alleviate its aircraft noise problems. Our track record in this area is, I believe, first‐class.

When we were elected to office we said, as we had said in opposition, that within 10 working days of being sworn into government we would reopen the east-west runway; we did that as we had promised, and we did it, in fact, within eight days. We also said that we would have a more equitable distribution of the aircraft noise problem over Sydney if we were elected to office. That is precisely what we have done. We said in opposition, as we have done in government, that we would have a review of flight paths for Sydney's Mascot airport. And we have done that. We have initiated that process today. We have initiated that process since we were elected to office. In terms of all of the things that we said we would do—Sydney's Kingsford Smith airport, flight paths, a more equitable distribution of the noise problem over Sydney, and the reopening of the east-west runway—we have fulfilled our commitments and will continue to work towards achieving the fulfilment of our commitments, just as we will continue to work for the development and completion of a second airport for Sydney because Sydneysiders have had a gutful of the delays caused by the former Labor government in developing this very important part of Sydney's infrastructure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McClelland, Robert, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The fundamental mind‐set of the government is still one of opposition. They are knockers, they are not doers. They are now entrusted with the task of getting on with the job.

SPEECH.PARA: The first delay in the construction of Badgerys Creek was the need to upgrade the airport from a regional runway of 1,800 metres to a fully international runway of 2,900 metres. The Labor government saw the need to do that to cope with the obvious demand that will come.

The second delay occurred because the then opposition knocked over the funding base for Badgerys Creek with the rejection of the airport privatisation legislation. Despite that, $150 million was spent by the Labor government in the acquisition of sites and the development of infrastructure. It is false in the extreme to say that the former government dragged the chain on those developments.

The present government's prevarication in building a second Sydney airport at Badgerys Creek is an excuse for doing just what big business want, namely, to expand the Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport. The government is finding every possible reason not to proceed with a second Sydney airport.

The government has interrupted the fast‐tracking of Badgerys Creek, saying a more extensive environmental impact statement is required. The blatant hypocrisy stands out for all to see when the government has put planes over the homes and the schools of my electors in Barton and other electorates under the east‐west flight path without giving them the opportunity to have an input in their own environmental impact statement.

Now the government has the audacity to speak of the sanctity of the environmental impact statement when saying it may interfere with Badgerys Creek. Certainly they can make one interfere with the construction of Badgerys Creek, and that is no doubt their hidden agenda.

The government wants to derail a second Sydney airport by speculating on a second alternative. That is all it is, it is no more than speculation. As I stand here today on 21 May 1996, I state: the government will never go ahead with Badgerys Creek and it will never go ahead with an airport at Holsworthy. They are just false promises. The second site has been examined up hill and down dale and rejected unequivocally. As sure as night follows day, the government's deliberate delaying tactics will blow out the noise curfew and capping on hourly flight movements that exist at Kingsford Smith.

This is more so given the government's arrogant and irrational decision to reopen the east‐west runway at KSA which was referred to by the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) in the concluding parts of his speech. It is irrational because it significantly decreases the capacity of KSA. While the east‐west runway is operational, the north‐south runways are virtually closed. The north‐south parallel runways have a capacity of between 70 and 80 movements an hour. The east‐west runway has a safe capacity of approximately 20 movements an hour.

The figures speak for themselves. The reduction in capacity caused by the operation of the east‐west runway is acknowledged by the fact that the government can only use the east‐west runway during non‐peak periods. That is, it is putting planes over the homes of school children when our kids are trying to learn. And, again, when the kids come home of an evening, when parents are trying to put them to bed, the government has planes flying over our homes.

Unfortunately, the government still has not silenced the complaints coming from the electorate of the member for Bennelong, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). Even while the court case is taking place to challenge the government's decision on opening the east‐west runway, the government has arrogantly increased its hours of use.

Simply to placate the Bennelong voters, the government is pumping planes out from the east‐west runway to prove a point. There is no doubt that many of those planes would otherwise be going out over the fish in Botany Bay rather than our homes and schools.

At the same time, despite a clear and unequivocal election promise, the government has not allocated one cent—not one cent!—to insulating our homes and schools under the east‐west flight path. And the government talks of election promises. They are putting planes over our homes, but where is the money?

Let there be no doubt as to the trauma the government has caused the residents of Barton. I will read from a letter from the President of the Kyeemagh Public School Council. This was a desperate plea to the minister:

The members of the School Council of Kyeemagh Infants School are concerned that with the reopening of the East‐West Runway at Kingsford‐Smith Airport, the noise from planes landing and taking off once again seriously disrupts the teaching/learning activities at Kyeemagh school.

The letter goes on to speak of the stresses, traumas and impediments to learning suffered as a result of the government's arrogant actions in opening the east‐west runway without an environmental impact statement.

The government is not coming clean. All money for noise insulation has been allocated north of the airport and that has been tied up for three years. Unless there is a special allocation in this coming budget there will be no funds to insulate the homes under the east‐west flight path. I am an optimist but, unfortunately, I am not prepared to put a bet on the government honouring its election promises. Yet they stand up here with sanctity and self‐righteousness and say that what they are doing is honouring election commitments.

PARA.BREAK: By the year 2000 there will be 20 million passengers coming into Sydney airport and it simply does not have the capacity to handle it. So the curfew will be broken and there will be an increase in aircraft movements and a return to the simultaneous operation of cross‐runways. The simultaneous operation of cross‐runways has been universally acknowledged as significantly less safe than parallel runways. Between 1991 and 1993 there were five serious incidents involving aircraft at Kings ford Smith airport. In August 1991 there was a near collision involving an Ansett aircraft and a Thai Airways aircraft.

SPEECH.PARA: That event resulted in the Ansett aircraft having to take evasive action, missing the Thai aircraft by metres. The air traffic controllers reported to the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation they were convinced a collision was about to occur. The firefighters had launched the alarm because they were convinced a collision was about to occur. If the government proceeds down this path it will compel all air travellers to face this risk.

The minister has given a direction to Airservices Australia to maximise the use of the east‐west runway. We are starting to move very rapidly into a dangerous situation of cross‐runway operations. We are looking at the risk of a significant disaster—and not for any rational economic benefit. As the minister indicated in his letter of 20 March to the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill), his reasons for opening the east‐west runway were essentially political in character.

So we are not even talking about `affordable safety'—some have been condemned for this—where aircraft safety is being compromised for economic reasons; we are talking about affordable safety for blatantly political purposes. The facts of the matter are that these events are going to continue. The pressures on Kingsford Smith airport are going to increase to an intolerable level, particularly as we are approaching the Olympics.
The minister has not acknowledged the fact that at Holsworthy there is a designated sacred Aboriginal site. Even if he does not acknowledge that fact—

TALK.START.PARA: —Twenty‐three.

—I understand there are 23 designated sites. Even if he wants to ride roughshod over those, he is going to end up in a two‐year High Court case—more delay and no action. That is what this government is about. I stand here and say that the government will do nothing about opening a second airport, an airport that is so desperately required to ease the trauma and suffering of people in my electorate and other electorates around Kingsford Smith airport.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zammit, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is incumbent on all good governments to have long‐term planning—a trait that, sadly, was lacking under the Keating‐Hawke government. The problems at KSA were evident 12 to 15 years ago. What did the Labor Party do about that when they were in government? They ordered an EIS for Badgerys Creek. That is well and good—a first step.

SPEECH.PARA: Was there any intention of proceeding with Badgerys Creek? Let us have a look at the situation. After they ordered the EIS, eight years went by and they thought, `We'd better do something about this.' So if they were fair dinkum about proceeding at Badgerys Creek, why didn't they proceed when the EIS came in? There was no action on Badgerys Creek. What did they do when it became evident that KSA was becoming overcongested? They said, `We'll build a third runway.' Once they built the third runway, they closed the east‐west runway.

Let us see who benefited the most from the closure of the east‐west runway. There were no more flights over the state electorate of Maroubra, no more flights over the state electorate of Heffron and no more flights over the federal electorate of Kingsford‐Smith. That begs the question: was the then Minister for Transport, the member for KingsfordSmith (Mr Brereton), acting impartially in the pursuit of his policy initiatives? Is it by coincidence that the flights were all but removed specifically over those two state and one federal electorates? Is it coincidence only that those electorates that have benefited the most are those of the now Premier of New South Wales, the member for Maroubra; the Labor member for Heffron; and the former minister, the member for Kingsford‐Smith.

Prior to entering the federal parliament, I was a member of the New South Wales state parliament for 12 years. I have never come across an issue that has brought decent, good Australians out into the streets as much as this issue. In the meantime, what is happening at Badgerys Creek? Absolutely nothing. I marched on Kingsford Smith airport during that very first demonstration, when tens of thousands of inner city Australians turned out to protest at what was going on. The people were all highly critical of the then Minister for Transport. Those who were the most critical were his own state Labor colleagues. They were calling out for two things: the re‐opening of the east‐west runway and the building of the second airport. What about the second airport? There has been a lot of talk today about how fair dinkum those opposite were on pushing ahead with the building of the second airport.

On a side track, I must say that I looked up the forward estimates for 1993‐94. If the people opposite were fair dinkum about building the airport then why was there absolutely no money allocated towards the cost of building the second airport? What plans did those on the other side have to encourage Qantas and Ansett to move out to the new airport?

TALK.START.PARA: —Nothing.

—There was absolutely nothing. There was no way in the world that they were going to spend huge sums of money to partly move their operations to Badgerys Creek. What incentives were there? Did you talk about it? How were you going to get them to move? You had no intention of building the second airport.
—We had a good plan.

—Good planning? Is that right? I find this incredible, Mr Acting Speaker. When I saw the notice of the matter of public importance, I saw it as the height of arrogance for you to bring this motion forward today when you had no plans—
—I remind the honourable member for Lowe that I have not brought any motion forward today. Please address your remarks through the chair—and I am Mr Deputy Speaker.

—Yes, Mr Deputy Speaker. Panic was starting to set in, within the ranks. What visionary plan was put in place to solve the problem? What saving grace did those on the other side exhibit in resolving the problem at KSA? Did they place a cap at Sydney airport? People were going off their brains with the noise. No, the then Leader of the Opposition raised the matter in parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: How did they respond to that? They said, `We'll send it off to a committee.' Did they enshrine in legislation mandatory penalties for breaking the curfew? Again, it was the then Leader of the Opposition who came forward in regard to this matter, and they opposed that and again it went off to a committee.

What was happening at Badgerys Creek with all this inaction by those opposite? Absolutely nothing. Where was the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) then? I note he is not even in the chamber. It is his MPI and he has left the chamber. What did he say then about the issue? Did he raise the issue in parliament if he was so concerned about this matter? No, absolutely not.

Where were the other members opposite in regard to the problems at Kingsford Smith? Under the Labor government's proposal, what sort of an airport was being envisaged at KSA? A major international airport? How can you justify that with the short runways you had planned? What about the infrastructure around the proposed new airport—buildings and houses going up? What if you wanted to expand the airport? You could not do it because the properties were being sold and bought.

It is clear that the only airport that was being planned by those opposite was a small‐scale regional airport. Further panic was starting to set in the Labor ranks. Election day was approaching. The former Minister for Transport then decided to act, and act decisively. And what did he do in January this year, after 10 years of inaction? He ordered another EIS. He got caught out. There is no doubt in our minds that he was going to announce the start of work on the new Badgerys Creek airport but he got caught out because his departmental officers told him, `You can't start building an airport with a 10‐year‐old EIS.' So what did he do? He ordered another EIS.

An election commitment was made by the coalition government—sharing the pain by re‐opening the east‐west runway, a cap on flights, a curfew, a full EIS on Badgerys Creek, and that is all occurring. But let us look at the hypocrisy of those opposite. It takes approximately 18 months for a full EIS. Let us assume that the EIS is not satisfactory. In other words, what those opposite were saying was that they would wait 18 months for the result of the EIS and, if the EIS stated that Badgerys Creek was not the place to put it, they would then have to look around for another site and they would have to order another EIS, which would take another year and a half.

TALK.START.PARA: —But Holsworthy is not suitable.

—The honourable member for Prospect is saying that Holsworthy is not suitable. That may well be the case, but in the first instance this government has made a commitment to a full EIS for Badgerys Creek. You have heard the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) state—and he is here, sitting on the front bench—that if the full EIS for Badgerys Creek is satisfactory it will go ahead at Badgerys Creek. But he has also stated, not just in the parliament but outside this parliament, that we have to ensure we are ready, in the event that the EIS for Badgerys Creek is not satisfactory, with another EIS that will look at another site. If the Holsworthy site, after all that occurs, is the site that is chosen eventually by the government, I can assure everyone that the honourable member will ensure, if that occurs—(Time expired)
—Order! The discussion has concluded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl, Garry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Selection Committee relating to the consideration of committee and delegation reports and private members' business on Monday, 27 May 1996. Copies of the report have been circulated to honourable members in the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: Pursuant to sessional order 28D, the Selection Committee has determined the order of precedence and times to be allotted for consideration of committee and delegation reports and private Members' business on Monday, 27 May 1996. The order of precedence and the allotments of time determined by the Committee are shown in the list.
1 MR NUGENT to move:
That this House:

(1) welcomes the initiative of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation to launch a National Reconciliation Week to be held each year from 27 May to 3 June for at least the next five years up to 2001, the centenary of federation;

(2) notes that the inaugural National Reconciliation Week beginning on 27 May 1996 will launch twelve months of community activities and a public awareness campaign leading up to the Australian Reconciliation Convention, which will be held during National Reconciliation Week in 1997;
(3) reaffirms its commitment to a process of reconciliation; and
(4) calls on all Australians to support the National Reconciliation Week and thereby to advance the reconciliation process. (Notice given 20 May 1996. )
The Committee determined that consideration of this matter should continue on a future day.
2 MS WORTH to move:
That the House:
(1) extends its sympathies to the family and friends of all the victims of the Port Arthur massacre;
(2) recognises the outstanding work done by the police and emergency services during the tragedy and the efforts of those associated with the counselling of victims, their families and friends;
(3) congratulates the Prime Minister and the State and Territory governments in making a significant contribution to public safety by moving to ban automatic and semi‐automatic rifles and shotguns;
(4) acknowledges the contribution made by the Leader of the Opposition in securing a bipartisan approach to the issue of gun control; and
(5) acknowledges that many law abiding citizens who own guns may be inconvenienced by the ban on some types of firearms. (Notice given 20 May 1996. )
The Committee determined that consideration of this matter should continue on a future day.
3 MR BRERETON to move:
That the Australian Parliament:
(1) declares its support for world efforts to secure peace in the Middle East through a settlement of the present conflict between the Hezbollah and Israel in Southern Lebanon;
(2) deplores the tragic loss of life and the endangerment of the innocent civilian population as a result of this conflict;
(3) is of the view that a settlement must involve the Governments of Lebanon, Syria and Israel and be based on the following guarantees:

PARA.TAB: (a) the territorial integrity of Lebanon and all countries in the region; and
(b) the absolute right of security for the citizens of Israel; and

SPEECH.PARA: (4) supports the implementation of UN Security Council Resolution 425 as part of the settlement. (Notice given 30 April 1996 .)

TAB.EMPHASIS: Time allotted—any remaining private Members' business time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee determined that consideration of this matter should continue on a future day.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Cadman) agreed to:
That the following bills be referred to the Main Committee for consideration:
Housing Loans Insurance Corporation (Transfer of Assets and Abolition) Bill 1996;
Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment (No. 1) Bill 1996;
Loan Bill 1996;
Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill 1996;
Indigenous Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill 1996.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 May, on motion by Mr Fahey:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb, Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In the short time remaining to me, as my speech was cut short last night when the debate was adjourned, I wish to say something about the matter of the gun laws in this country, which has created a great deal of controversy. Someone remarked to me that, with 800,000 people unemployed and overseas debt running at over $180 billion net, there are more important things to be speaking about. But it has caused a great deal of emotion.

SPEECH.PARA: In saying that, I do not want to diminish the great horror and dismay which we all experienced with regard to the Port Arthur massacre which took place not so long ago. In particular, I wish to commend the response of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), who has shown great leadership on this issue, as have the police ministers from all the states and territories and from all major political parties. They have behaved extremely well and in response to the desires of the Australian people. Most opinion polls show about 90 per cent of people in support and about six to eight per cent opposing what was done, with two to four per cent undecided.

I stress that I support the thrust and substance of what has been proposed, though when it comes down to the detail of what is decided in the legislation that will go before the various state parliaments around this country I hope consideration can be given to a number of matters that I wish to raise now, particularly matters relating to semi‐automatic rifles, semi‐automatic shotguns and pump action shotguns.

I know there is going to be provision for farmers and professional shooters—under certain stringent circumstances—to be able to use these weapons, but I have a particular concern about sporting shooters. I say this very carefully because what I wish to put before the House in no way compromises safety to the Australian public, which of course is behind the thrust of what has been proposed generally.

The sporting shooters—apart from a few rednecks at meetings up in Queensland whom we have seen on our television screens recently—are responsible citizens of the highest order and are very safety conscious indeed; they have always been this way. In fact, a group representing clay target shooters and field and game shooters came to see me the other day, and they described to me various incidents.

Some time ago there was an incident on their range at Dubbo when, after the clay pigeon box was emptied, the wind caught the box and swept it across the range. Someone fired a shot into the box and was immediately ordered off the range. That is how strong a priority they put on safety. No animals or birds can be shot on ranges, and birds get to know this of course and fly around these ranges as they do anywhere else.

These people also instruct children on safety measures. They provide a very valuable community service, I believe, because they get the gung‐ho macho element out of the children by instructing them on how serious it is to use firearms. If there is any money left over from the extension of the Medicare levy—a subject which we will debate in coming weeks—then perhaps some of that money could be used towards increasing firearm safety awareness, particularly for children.

I wish to read from a letter which was composed by the four main firearm dealers in Dubbo, the main city in my area. The letter was written by Peter George of Carrington Firearms, Austin Bourke of Austin Bourke's Bastille Gun Shop, Bob Dowling of Macquarie Arms Co. and Peter Kay, a gunsmith and qualified tradesman. They wrote to me on the proposed new gun laws, and they say:
Dear Sir,
We refer to the meeting between the proprietors of the four firearms shops in Dubbo held in your office on the 17.5.96.

As a result of that meeting we respectfully suggest steps that could be taken to ensure that the Federal Governments objective of uniform Gun Laws, "Making Australia a Safer Place" and removing military style weapons from the general public, can be achieved.

We are also mindful of the monetary cost to the Australian Taxpayer, which if the present suggestions are carried through, and every effected gun owner complied, would run into an excess of Four Billion Dollars.

This is the best estimate that we can make based on our combined 125 years experience in dealing with those involved in Firearms use, as it applies to the various disciplines of the Firearms Sports, Pest Control and collecting etc.
To achieve the Governments objectives outlined above, we believe that the implementation of the Classes 1. and 2. of the N.S.W. Firearms Act (prior to 14.5.96) be applied to Australia Wide.
They go on to describe what class 1 and class 2 shooters' licences and permits over and above those licences mean. The letter continues:
N.S.W. Premier Carr has stated on numerous occasions that "N.S.W. has the toughest workable firearms laws in Australia."
Compensation payable on the proposed legislation would be an unnecessary and enormous burden on the Australian Taxpayer, if the N.S.W. Firearms Laws were adopted Australia Wide.

We take this opportunity to thank you for enabling us to express our views and if we can be of any further assistance please do not hesitate to contact us. Would you also kindly keep us informed of the developments as they occur in this matter.

They are simply proposing that semi‐automatic rifles and, particularly, shotguns be used on the ranges. Even though the magazines of semi‐automatics hold five rounds, you are only allowed to put two cartridges in them. If you put three cartridges in and miss the clay pigeon with the first two shots, you could fire off a third shot, pretend it was your second shot and still have it counted as a score. They are only firing off what can be fired off with a double‐barrelled side by side or under and over firearm anyhow.

The members of the group also said that the self‐loading guns are particularly good for use by women, who are taking up this sport in increasing numbers. They are particularly good, too, for use by over‐70‐year‐old people who find the weight of two barrels a little onerous. Also, because these self‐loading shotguns are gas operated, there is less recoil on the shoulder. For elderly people who have been shooting all their lives, this is a bonus. The members of the group asked me to put these matters before the parliament to see if they could be considered by the police ministers, the Premiers and the Chief Ministers around Australia when the legislation is drawn up.

Duck shooters do not exist any more in New South Wales, since they were banned, but down in Victoria if you have got to break your barrel when you are standing deep in water and cannot use an automatic magazine, then this is also a hindrance. Perhaps we could crimp the magazines of these semi‐automatics to restrict them to two cartridges. It is something that I hope would be considered.

You are allowed to use semi‐automatic pistols on ranges now, so surely it is not inconsistent to be able to use semi‐automatic shotguns—and possibly semi‐automatic rifles—in these particular sports. I commend those thoughts to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio, Janice, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I too rise to speak on Supply Bill (No. 1) 1996‐97, Supply Bill (No. 2) 1996‐97, and the Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1996‐97. I particularly make reference to the allocation that has been made to the Department of Transport and Regional Development as listed in schedule 2 to Supply Bill (No 2).

SPEECH.PARA: The latest statements on Badgerys Creek made by the Minister for Transport and Regional Affairs (Mr Sharp) are a complete surprise. As a resident and member of parliament for that area for many years, it is a very pleasant surprise, but a surprise nevertheless. Who would have thought that we would now see such a change in a man who just two months ago said:
In order to make Sydney West Airport capable of all international flights we have to extend the length of it . . . we've got to obviously re‐design the details of Sydney West Airport.
Or, in another statement he made:
Badgerys Creek is part of the airport solution . . .
Or, in relation to getting it up and running before the Olympics, he said:
Well, we will certainly try it. Laurie Brereton again said you couldn't do it . . . but we're going to give it the best shot we can to get it done in time for the Olympics.
If the minister would like to say that he did not make those comments or remarks, I can assure him that I have the tape as I taped the particular program on 2BL.

Of course, there was no mention then of Holsworthy, or even of `eggs in the baskets', or even about a second EIS; nor was there any mention of this in the coalition's airport policy document, Putting people first. I actually went back and reread it. Now the minister has turned around and announced a new EIS for Holsworthy to be operated in conjunction with the present one being carried out for Badgerys Creek.

I must admit that, when I heard about that yesterday and then again this morning, I wondered whether the member for Hughes (Ms Vale) had been consulted about what a second investigation into a new EIS at Holsworthy would mean to an electorate like hers. She probably only found out today and she probably also found out that the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey) has decided that he is not going to take any more of the type of action that I have had to take year in and year out from the groups that I represent. Those groups probably went bashing down his door and he has decided to pass the buck. He won out, and now the member for Hughes is going to have to suffer for it.

As far as Badgerys Creek is going, I hate to say to the minister but I will say: I told you so. Since Badgerys Creek was first selected as the site for the second Sydney airport, I have viewed its impending development with a very jaundiced eye. Since coming into this House in 1990, I have used my speaking times repeatedly to question the wisdom of our then government in planning an airport at that particular location, and I have repeatedly lobbied my ministers to this effect. I have no problem in admitting that at times I became, not a thorn in the side, but perhaps a stone in the shoe of both the former Minister for Transport and the former minister for the environment. I certainly did chew their respective ears off as to the dangers of Badgerys Creek and why we should look elsewhere for a suitable site for a second airport.

In recent times my fight has been supported by various people within my own community. I am sure this House is aware that the political fights surrounding airports are not usually pretty ones, nor are they clean. I am sure that the member for Grayndler (Mr Albanese), one of my colleagues who is here at the moment, would certainly support me when I say that different people certainly become emotionally involved when we talk about airports, particularly when the aeroplanes are flying over their own homes.

Certainly one of the more vocal groups in my community is the Fairfield Residents Against Airport Noise, or FRAAN, as it is more popularly known. As someone who personally has always been against the proposed airport at Badgerys Creek, I initially viewed FRAAN, upon its inception in July of last year—take note, it formed only last July—as a genuine outpouring of community feeling. I saw it as a group of concerned individuals, independent of political beliefs, asking questions and raising issues about Badgerys Creek for the common good.

This view has certainly changed somewhat over the past 10 months, especially as various leaders in the group have attempted to smear my name by saying that I was always for the airport and that I was actively participating in the supposed deception of the community over the former government's plans for Sydney West airport. However, to this day, I recognise that there are still members of FRAAN who maintain the community-minded intentions with which the group first began. I offer them my continued support and I thank them for the encouragement that they, in turn, have given to me.

BREAK.PARA: Before the election I had the great pleasure of making representations on behalf of a number of people, both within my electorate and outside, who suggested alternative and far superior sites for airport development. The question of Holsworthy was certainly only one of those from one constituent of mine, a Mr Alex Pope, who approached me at the very beginning of this year to make representation to the Environment Protection Agency on his behalf. I suppose he must have been very pleased this morning when he read about how that is now going to be given consideration.

The other site about which I have also written to the respective authorities suggesting further investigation was Goulburn—and the minister well knows this. I had prepared myself for a long struggle ahead with the new government, particularly after the minister's initial statements, which were made once he had assumed the reins in his portfolio. Now I have been delivered this new news like manna from heaven.

`What could have brought about this development?' I stopped to think this morning. I thought, `Is it sheer good sense?' which, I must say, is not entirely out of the question. Or is it perhaps the fact that Badgerys Creek is now circled by a number of new Liberal seats, including, as I stated earlier, the seat of the Minister for Finance? This cannot be discounted either—and, if you are a politician, you do not discount anything. I dare say that the minister has had time to reflect and, in doing so, perhaps even seen the error of his government's plans—not only to build at Badgerys Creek but to expand the airport to reach international size rather than let it remain as an overflow operation, as the previous government always intended.

Rather than continuing these two EISs, I say to the minister that Goulburn certainly seems to be coming more and more the attractive proposition as each day passes, particularly as references to the very fast train project have begun to increase exponentially in recent times. I would suggest to the minister that now is the perfect time for a reappraisal of the merits of locating Sydney's second airport at Goulburn. An airport at Goulburn could only increase the value of a very fast train operation. Conversely, it would only be through a very fast train link that such an airport could be made viable. If my memory serves me correctly—and having read that EIS over and over again I think it does—Goulburn was originally counted out of the airport site selection process in the mid-1980s due to the fact that it would lie approximately 200 kilometres from the city it would primarily serve—that is, Sydney.

Doesn't a very fast train entering into the equation change things? Just as the minister has now told the House that technological advances have rendered the unexploded bombs at Holsworthy not a problem, can't the same be said with regard to the technological advances regarding rail travel? When we look at what speeds these trains can now reach and the short time it would take for them to cover those very long distances, it really does become awe inspiring—I think more than awe inspiring. The transportation possibilities raised by the very fast train actually negate the factors for which Goulburn was rejected as an airport site in the first place. With the very fast train rendering the argument of distance impotent, the positive aspects of Goulburn as the choice for Sydney's second airport site suddenly come into focus.

There is the `people' factor for a start. There are many proponents of Badgerys Creek in Sydney—some of whom are in this parliament—who believe that the airport, once built, would be situated in some sort of isolated and empty country setting. While the rural nature of the site is not questioned, the fact that it is now fringed by some of Sydney's fastest growing housing developments is failing to loom large enough in people's minds.

PARA.BREAK: It is estimated that only 1,500 people would be directly affected by Badgerys Creek. I would personally wager that many thousands more will be affected. The construction of an airport at Goulburn, on the other hand, would affect less than 100 people. It may pose a concern to sheep and cattle! We may have to investigate those concerns. We are not paying close enough attention to the fact that beyond the fringe there are the more heavily populat ed areas of the greater western suburbs of Sydney, which are growing at the moment at an incredibly fast pace. Goulburn has none of these population worries.

BREAK.PARA: To my mind, population worries also count against Holsworthy as a site for the airport. Much has been said in the papers this morning about those vast tracts of national park that surround the proposed Holsworthy airport site. I am sure the members for Cook (Mr Mutch), Hughes and Fowler (Mr Grace)—and I know the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) has expressed his concerns—would certainly have things to say about the effect on the homes and lifestyles of their constituents. I know that, as concerned members of parliament, they would be concerned that the lifestyles of their constituents would be affected by airport noise should Holsworthy ever be built.

We are no longer a small isolated state. No matter where the second airport goes, it must have 24‐hour operation. This is not feasible and not possible at Badgerys Creek. It certainly would not be possible at Holsworthy. I do not believe that we should even contemplate having an airport that operates 24 hours a day anywhere near a large congregation of residents. To build another airport in this state without that capacity is foolish indeed.

Situated as it is, far from even the slightest suggestion of urban sprawl, Goulburn would have the least environmental impact of any of the sites so far considered for the airport. As the airport grew there would be no danger of it encroaching on the lives of thousands upon thousands of people, nor would there be any problems with it operating on a 24‐hour basis.

There are also other less obvious problems associated with Badgerys Creek. For example, there is no evidence of the Goulburn site ever having been used as an ancient Aboriginal settlement. Such evidence has recently been uncovered at Badgerys Creek. The Holsworthy site has been recognised and documented as including 23 Aboriginal archaeological sites.

I think we also have to remember that Holsworthy, like Badgerys Creek, is also situated well within the Sydney basin. The concerns that we have had in south‐western Sydney regarding the smog and air pollution that would be an unavoidable spin-off from Badgerys Creek are still relevant when looking at Holsworthy.

Goulburn has none of these problems. When looked at in conjunction with the very fast train service, these are the positives which I believe we should now be considering. In relation to the very fast train, Australia is at the moment inadvertently well placed to reap the benefits from the amazing advances that have taken place in the area of rail travel.

There are two types of very fast train available to us now. One has been put forward by the company Speedrail, which advocates the use of a train modelled on the French designed TGV. It reaches speeds of up to 300 kilometres an hour. The TGV, believe it or not, is not actually now at the forefront of fast rail technology. That honour goes to a train called Transrapid, otherwise known as Maglev.

The Maglev forgoes the traditional `wheel on steel' approach to rail travel in favour of a carriage which sits above the tracks thanks to magnetic levitation. I know that it sounds like something that H.G. Wells would have come up with some 100 years ago, but a Maglev train will actually go into operation between Berlin and Hamburg in 1998. It will reach speeds of 580 kilometres per hour. Looking at the opportunities a train such as the Maglev carries with it, Australia, having delayed taking up the very fast option until now, has a chance to actually step in at the top end of the queue of rail technology.

If it is estimated that the TGV would take approximately one hour to reach Goulburn on its way to Canberra, then we could expect the Maglev to take a much shorter time than that—in fact, it is estimated that it would take less than 45 minutes with stops. That is less time than it takes to travel by Sydney rail from Central Station to my electorate in Fairfield, which is in the western suburbs, let alone going on another 15 to 30 minutes to Badgerys Creek.

This is how the situation appears to me. I have enough confidence in the case for Goulburn as Sydney's second airport site that I had no hesitation in making representations on this subject to the former minister for the environment, the Executive Director of the EPA and the Secretary to the Department of Transport on behalf of Mr Tony Lamarra, the former mayor of the city of Goulburn, some months ago. I know those people have made countless representations to the present minister for transport.

I do not presume to have enough expertise on this subject that I hold Goulburn up to the House and the minister for transport as some sort of faultless answer to that vexing question of where to place Sydney's second airport. Of course we would encounter problems with the site. There would have to be a great deal of consultation with the people of Goulburn—a point I am sure the minister for transport would strongly agree with, considering the area is included within his own electorate. However, subject to the hurdle of gaining approval for the high‐speed rail link, any problems associated with Goulburn, I am confident, would be far more easily overcome than those linked with Badgerys Creek or Holsworthy. Building an airport at Badgerys Creek may have made sense 10 or 15 years ago. Now it continues to do so less and less as every young family chooses to make south‐western Sydney their home.

The Sydney basin has a finite population capacity and it is clearly approaching its limits for absorbing air and water pollution. In going ahead with Badgerys Creek I fear we are going to be subjecting that growing population of south‐western Sydney to the sorts of social and environmental problems which have developed for the residents of the inner city.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, Ha!

—I feel it is my duty to voice these fears which, for the information of the Chief Government Whip, the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), I have done repeatedly in this House for the last six years. I have continually done that on behalf of my constituents—and, I might say, we have been overwhelmed by his silence on this very subject. I too read Hansard and I will continue to bring up the concerns of my constituents.

BREAK.PARA: I am quite aware that by suggesting Goulburn I am sticking my neck out. I know that to place an airport in Goulburn may not seem to make sense to some. However, I would suggest that it only fails to make sense to those people who persist in viewing the development of airports in the conventional, traditional way that we seem to have become accustomed to. I would have thought that the pain and the suffering surrounding the development of Sydney's third runway and the failure of governments to gain popular approval for Badgerys Creek should have told us that those ways of looking at airport development and operation have passed.

People in Sydney have developed an ingrained cynicism and hostility in regard to the building and the operation of airports—a bitterness that I think will never be overcome and which I am sure will come to the surface again if and when Holsworthy is ever selected. The onus is on the government to think further ahead than just the 2000 Olympics. We have to look 25 or 30 years down the track. By that time we will look back and question our judgment as to why Badgerys Creek was ever considered. I hope we will not have to kick ourselves and ask how we were stupid enough to actually let it be built there.

I believe the minister must weigh up the pros and cons. I think you will see, Mr Deputy Speaker—as would the government if they would take their blinkers off—that Badgerys Creek is not necessarily the answer to the Sydney airport problems. I do not believe Holsworthy is either, for the reasons I have submitted in the very short time that I have had here today—bearing in mind that we only heard something like 18 hours ago about this wonderful gesture on behalf of the minister to run two concurrent EISs, much to the amazement, I am sure, of all the population in that area who are now going to be subjected to that. Certainly, it was never a commitment given by the now government during their campaign.

Goulburn, I believe, is the place for a third EIS. If you wish to have two EISs, have a third. Have one where it is going to be plausible in the future to build an airport for the future, not as a stopgap. I also believe that the government must acknowledge that the current EIS which is being investigated was commenced under the previous government. It was commenced in such a way that we will have ongoing consultation on water and land, and on flight paths. This was a guarantee supplied to us by the then bureaucrats from the EPA and the transport departments at public meetings attended by many people, not just myself.

I believe when they have started to go into that investigation they will find that to have a 24‐hour operating airport in an area like Badgerys Creek in the Sydney basin is going to be a disaster. I believe we can correct those mistakes now. Let's not make them in the first place. If we are now going to contemplate, with the extra expenditure of another EIS, taking into account a site such as Holsworthy, surely to God commonsense can prevail.

I am sure the new member for Hughes will join me and support me so that, on behalf of her constituents as well, we can say to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, `Give consideration to a third EIS. Keep your two, if you want them. One is already started; one you are about to commence. At least have commonsense and take the blinkers off. Look at the feasibilities of where an airport for the future residents of this country should be built and also look at the probabilities of providing a fast rail transport. Get those trucks off the roads. Get immediate transportation from the airport to the very fast trains and let us, for once, see vision when we start thinking about airports for the future.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call the honourable member for Deakin, I remind the House that this is the honourable member's first speech. I ask the House to extend to him the usual courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Barresi, Phil, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker Jenkins. I congratulate you on your elevation to the office you now hold and I ask that you convey my congratulations to the Speaker.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to say at the outset that it is an honour to be elected as a member of the Howard coalition government. In the first few weeks of my parliamentary life I have seen this government bring to an end that fatalistic acceptance of mediocrity that had come to dominate Australian life. For years we have had to cop the rhetoric that told us that high unemployment was inevitable and that the will of the people was to be determined by vocal and divisive interest groups. These weeks have brought to an end such rhetoric and have returned to us a sense of hope. And I want that hope to last.

If representing an electorate in federal parliament were not in itself a great responsibility, I find myself humbled by the memory of the man whose name appears on the window on my electorate office. As we approach the centenary of Federation I cannot help but think of what it must have been like to be there—to be at the birth of a nation. I think of how Alfred Deakin anticipated so many of Federation's potential difficulties, yet continued to fight for a constitution that will bring us together.
In March 1898, in his now famous speech at the Bendigo ANA conference, Deakin said:

A Federal constitution is the last and final product of political intellect and constructed ingenuity; it represents the highest development of the possibilities of self‐government of peoples scattered over a large area. Yet I venture to submit that among all federal constitutions of the world, you will look in vain for one as broad in its popular base, as liberal in its working principles, as generous in its aim, as this measure.
The constitution taught us about Deakin the idealist. But to get all those involved in the debate to accept the constitution taught us about Deakin the politician.

Politics is the pragmatic side of the process—it is the art of perpetual compromise. Yet, as skilful politicians, we can, through compromise, bring about significant change. The idea can withstand the impact of politics; the idealist and the politician can be one and the same. Constitutional reform should be far‐sighted and supported by the Australian people every step of the way.

Five years out from our centenary celebrations, the challenges that confront our government today are just as significant as those faced by our founding fathers.
