We are being asked to examine the role of the monarchy. We are being asked to mould a new state‐Commonwealth relationship, and we are being asked to provide stability, order and prosperity in an ever changing and uncertain global village.

I cannot help but think that, were Alfred Deakin able to stroll down the Maroondah Highway and through the streets of the electorate which today bears his name, he would be quite proud of our nation. However, he would also be aware of a community still in need of political action. He would realise that this is not a postcard federal seat. We have no Blue Mountains, Barrier Reef or Opera House. Our monuments are the 111,000 people who live in Deakin's sprawling suburbs, whose existence is not always glamorous and exciting but is often dignified and meaningful.

Some people in my electorate are descendants of the very first Australians, those who lived here 40,000 years ago. Others are related to those who fought for our nation in more recent times, while others have lived in Deakin for less than a generation. Deakin's population is ageing. Those over 55 years of age now represent over 30 per cent of the population. This reality brings with it new demands on our infrastructure. It means that the demand for government assistance will increase rather than diminish. The chronic shortage of nursing home beds, the plight of our home carers and the continuing need for health services for the aged were some of the issues on which my election campaign was fought. These were the issues highlighted by the Gregory report, yet neglected by Labor.

Families with young children are also making their presence felt in Deakin, particularly in the outer‐east growth areas. These are families at their most vulnerable stage, for whom the health of Australia's economy is not merely a series of statistics but the difference between employment and falling beneath the poverty line. As the coalition's policy for families states, `A loving, supportive and stable family environment is the best and most enduring system of social support.' Therefore, government policy must be directed at strengthening families.

BREAK.PARA: My electorate lies at the heart of the fastest growing suburban region outside Canberra and the Gold Coast. It is becoming the IT and communications hub of Australia. This is placing incredible strain on the region's infrastructure, particularly on our road links with the wharves, airport, and the major interstate highway. Fifty‐eight per cent of all finished goods in the area are moving northward along the Hume Highway. This means, according to some estimates, that average vehicle trip times in eastern Melbourne will increase by one-fifth by the year 2011, placing another unnecessary oncost to those who create the jobs and the wealth for this country.

The proposed Scoresby freeway will provide us with a way of relieving this pressure. It could offer an escape from the deadlock which will be crippling to the economy of the east. I will be encouraging the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) to list the Scoresby transport corridor as a `road of national significance', making the project eligible for private sector funding.

Deakin today is a community which is rich in cultural, ethnic and religious diversity, something which our founding fathers may not have envisaged but which is certainly part of those traditions of social justice and acceptance they wrote into our constitution. Deakin has sizeable Greek, Italian and Chinese communities. Languages other than English are spoken in 16 per cent of homes and this percentage is growing.

On a more spiritual level, my electorate has large and active Christian communities. The suburb of Blackburn is considered Australia's Baptist capital, something of which we are particularly proud—and I know our Treasurer (Mr Costello) is. Deakin is also home to several other large Christian denominations, as well as other religious communities from around the world.

The less savoury aspect of the seat of Deakin is not always immediately apparent. It seems to me that the fight against youth homelessness and unemployment has focused most people's attention on Melbourne's west where the problems are more visible at street level. However, those in Deakin who are familiar with the plight of the homeless, the unemployed and those employed but unable to make ends meet will know that 13 years of Labor have not been kind to our community.

Deakin and the outer‐eastern region is in need of the government's youth homeless pilot project and the regional community employment councils being established with the support of the local councils and the community groups.

It is a blight on our society that there is only one youth refuge in the region—Wesley 121 with eight beds. We need to tackle youth homelessness in the suburbs and at a family level as a way of preventing the exodus into the inner city.

Having worked with the long‐term unemployed under one of the myriad of Labor market programs offered through DEET, I am fully aware of what has and has not been done to help the unemployed find work. I was dismayed to discover that many programs do little more than create a false and cruel expectation in the eyes of recipients that they will find work. On Friday I attended the graduation ceremony of four young people from the local landcare and environment action program. After 26 weeks of hard work, they had acquired skills in environmental management and had made a stand against environmental degradation. But after the ceremony one of the parents took to the stage to urge CES and DEET to offer training with a purpose, to find jobs and to train young Australians to get them. I believe that programs that prepare young people for real jobs need to be encouraged, but these programs are pointless unless jobs are created for people to go to. Despite the rhetoric of Working Nation, the Labor government failed to create real, meaningful, long‐term jobs.

Group training companies in my electorate are delivering successful programs based on industry, company and community needs and not on artificial needs created by bureaucrats. These companies must be encouraged. Industry in my electorate ranges from the small to the medium sized. There are companies which produce chocolate, underwear, tiles, fibres—more or less everything. Yet my involvement with the local chambers of commerce in Ringwood and Blackburn has strengthened my resolve to demand urgent industrial relations reform.

For industry to continue to work for the people of Deakin, it is my belief that the industrial relations package, as announced in the Governor-General's speech, must be passed. I say that not out of blind commitment to political ideology but because I know the world of industrial relations and I understand the risks a society runs when groups set out to protect their own vested interests. I am talking about not only unions but also employer associations, companies and practitioners who have put in place an industrial relations club in this country.

I speak from experience about industrial relations. My professional background is somewhat unusual for a member of parliament. I am a registered psychologist. But, please, before my colleagues start to recline in these comfortable chairs and begin to tell me about their problems, allow me to say that I have spent the past 18 years of my professional life in the organisational‐industrial setting. I have worked in workplace reform, management‐organisational development, productivity improvement, industrial relations and human resources.

I am proud to be able to say that my relationship with blue-collar workers has always been positive, even in the most heavily unionised work environments. I have worked with both unions and individual employees. I have been successful in gaining their trust, despite the widely held perception that Liberals and unionists cannot work together. It goes without saying that industry needs to be backed by government policies which encourage growth and investment. I believe our government policies will provide such incentives.

But in the course of my career I have also come across abysmal management practices, poor leadership, short-sightedness and at times pointless anti-union sentiments. Government policies dealing with small business, vocational training and employment must continue to be looked upon as a guide for many companies, but governments cannot do the work for which the employers are ultimately responsible.

Since its creation in 1937 the electorate of Deakin has seen its boundaries undergo several changes. It has become more urban than semi-rural. I am proud to say that, except for an 18-month `sabbatical' with the Labor Party, Deakin has always been a Liberal conservative seat. In its 58 years of life, the seat has been represented by William Hutchinson, Francis Davis, Alan Jarman, John Saunderson, Julian Beale and Ken Aldred. All of these people have made their contribution to parliament, the electorate and the nation.

Two of these former members deserve a special mention. The first person is the Hon. Julian Beale, who held the seat between 1984 and 1990 and then went on to represent the seat of Bruce between 1990 and 1996. Julian's support throughout the recent election campaign was appreciated, particularly as he had a tough fight of his own. Julian is a reminder that periodically we must contend with forces that are beyond our control: the redrawn electoral boundaries.

The second person I wish to mention is Alan Jarman, who served in this House between 1966 and 1983. Although I never met Mr Jarman, I feel his legacy is part of my political and personal identity, and even today he epitomises the notion of a caring and committed local member. His son, David, is a former vice-president of the Victorian division and has been a personal friend and confidant for many members of the Deakin electorate.

I have heard quite a few of my parliamentary colleagues refer to their family backgrounds. Each has staked their claim that the cultural diversity of the House is beginning to reflect that of the Australian society as a whole. Allow me to add my own background to the list. There have been many Australians of Italian origin in federal parliament, mostly on the Labor side of politics—people with names such as Lazzarini, Luchetti, Klugman and Sciacca. Western Australian Senator John Panizza was the first and—until now—the only Liberal Italian-Australian in federal parliament.

My personal first is that I am the first Italian-born member of parliament for the coalition—a fact which continues to highlight the changing nature of my party. For its own political gains the Labor Party has portrayed the coalition as less accepting of diversity than Labor. With my colleagues, I obviously reject that portrayal.

I was born in a small town on the northern coast of Sicily and I spent four years of my life in a town called Falcone. It is only a few kilometres away from the birthplace of the former member for Bowman. He will be missed by Australia's Italian community, although I am sure not by my worthy colleague who defeated him on 2 March.

It is impossible not to be moved by stories of immigration because nine times out of 10 they are happy stories, variations on the rags‐to‐riches theme. But many Italian-Australians did not make their fortunes in Australia. Many were happy to work in factories, save just enough for a small house in the suburbs and then retire to be with their families in the autumn of their lives. My family story is not much different. My father came from generations of Sicilian immigrants. My grandfather had travelled to Argentina and New York, before returning home. My father arrived in Fremantle in 1959 and I arrived a year later aged four.

Under the economic conditions in Australia in the 1950s and 1960s my parents were able to stake their claim on the typical migrant dream. They worked, they gave their children what they were never able to have and they retired to the suburbs. It was not luck; it was hard work, and my parents owe Australia as much as Australia owes them.

We grew up in an environment which, it was assumed, would spawn nothing but Labor voters. Mum and dad both worked in a Labor-dominated environment. That is why on the day the 38th Parliament was opened I made a point of introducing my family to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the Treasurer—the epitome of the kinds of politicians Labor people told my family not to associate with. Yet these are the leaders whom increasing numbers of average Australians, the battlers, are turning to.

I thank my parents for being here on that day. Their pride demonstrated their acceptance of my chosen political path. They are proud of me; but equally proud, as I am, of my sister, Isabel, and my two brothers, Laurie and Jack. They could not be here today, but I am sure they are listening.

It would be remiss of me not to thank those prominent Italian-Australians who congratulated me after my election. My thanks go to the Italian Ambassador to Australia, Dr Marcello Spatafora, and the mayor and councillors of the town of Falcone in Sicily, who were genuinely moved by the news of the success of one of their town's sons.

Mr Deputy Speaker, winning this seat has been nothing short of a battle for me. My victory is due to the single‐minded focus and hard work of many of my supporters. Please bear with me as I acknowledge some of those who made it all possible. Firstly, I thank my wife, Vivienne, who is in the gallery, who has been a true partner throughout the process and without whose support the transition to my new life would have been impossible. To my two little mates, my children Paul and Carla—the best two kids I could hope for—thanks. To my mother-in-law, Rose, the best baby‐sitter you can get during a federal campaign—thank you.

Thanks go to my branch presidents and the campaign team—people such as Ross McClymont, Charles and Bernice Hogarth, Kaele Way, James Kimpton, Sue Lawrie, Pam Read, Bev Bailey, Andrew Munro, Merle Hare, Sue Ryan, Jan and Peter Tredrea, Charles Czerny, Ronah Dennis, Margaret Lee, Terry Macdonald, Jim Madden, Andrew Rawlings, Jock Hancox, Tony Callander, Margaret Kirby and the other 480 supporters who helped during the campaign.

Thanks also to my local Liberal state members of parliament in Victoria, whose help was invaluable. Thanks also to my close friend the Hon. Shane Stone, Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, who has been a true mentor throughout my political career—from our university days at ANU until today—and who, along with many in this House, is looking for strong federal leadership in issues affecting regional Australia.

Thanks also to Senator Judith Troeth, who gave me the courage many years ago to consider standing for preselection. Thanks to Senator Kay Patterson, a great patron senator, and her staff. Thanks also to the best Liberal Party secretariat in the country—headed by Dr Peter Poggioli and Ted Bailleau. And thanks to my colleagues in the surrounding federal seats of Aston, Menzies, Chisholm, La Trobe and Casey.

A special thanks to ALI, the Association of Liberal Italians, which for the last 20 years has been a strong supporter and communicator of Liberal values in the Italian community. And, finally, thanks to all my friends in Melbourne and Perth.

I have come to parliament, like all new members, to have a say in the future of both Australia and my electorate. But I also want the politician and the idealist to live side by side, to bring about change that means something to us as Australians. I thank the House for the courtesy it has extended to me today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Albanese, Anthony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In the context of considering the supply bills which are before the House today, I wish to raise the government's announcement today that it will walk away from building the second Sydney airport at Badgerys Creek. In my first speech two weeks ago, I spoke about the airport at Sydney and the devastating impact it is having on residents in my electorate. I spoke also about how the federal Labor government had pursued programs to alleviate aircraft noise and the reason why the problems with the airport had developed.

SPEECH.PARA: I suggested two weeks ago that this was an issue which was about economics. It was about a failure of governments to provide appropriate infrastructure—that was what the previous Labor government was setting about rectifying—and not really about aviation. We all understood that it was inevitable that Sydney needed a second airport.

What we saw today in the announcement by the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, the member for Hume (Mr Sharp), is a repeat of history. From 1972 to 1975, a previous Labor government also set about solving Sydney's second airport needs. In 1974 it chose a site at Galston. With the coup which occurred on 11 November 1975, the Fraser government threw that out the window and we saw eight years of prevarication under the conservatives.

During the federal election campaign, my friend Tom Uren wrote to the constituents of Grayndler warning them that, unless the Keating Labor government was returned, Sydney would not see a second airport at Badgerys Creek. Unfortunately, it appears that his prophecy will be proven to be correct. Today we saw the member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) and John Sharp defend the situation whereby they will establish an EIS into the site at Holsworthy concurrently with the EIS into Badgerys Creek—the expanded EIS established under Labor.

It appears that the member for Bennelong and the member for Hume are today's Burke and Wills. They are wandering around New South Wales looking for a second airport site. They are looking for that elusive tree stump with the marking `Dig here for a second Sydney airport site'. If ever they find that stump, the member for Hume will turn to the member for Bennelong and say, `Well, what do you reckon about this for the site?' There is no doubt that the member for Bennelong will say, `Oh, not here. It's a bit close to Hunters Hill.'

This delay shows a contempt for those residents currently living around the Sydney airport. We are seeing that political will, political courage, foresight and vision are needed to solve Sydney's airport problem. The new minister for transport showed today that he has none of that. We need to look at where Sydney West airport is at. This is not a new proposal. The EIS occurred a decade ago. Holsworthy was considered then and ran second last. Badgerys Creek was chosen as the most appropriate site for Sydney's second airport because it was by far and away the best site.

It is not as though nothing has happened since then. Last year's budget allocations of the federal Labor government show that substantial progress has already been made: $306 million has already been allocated for airport development; $152 million has already been spent—not allocated but spent. All the land for Sydney West airport, including the 2,900‐metre runway, has already been acquired. Some 1,770 hectares of freehold land have been compulsory acquired by the federal government in order to provide a solution to this problem.

Already allocated is $21 million for the control tower and firefighting services, $23 million for environmental safeguards, $480 million for roads and $17 million to ensure that the rail corridor is reserved. The Minister for Transport and Regional Development spoke about the cost of this infrastructure, but in terms of its benefits it will not serve just the airport. What Labor had in mind was a visionary approach for a second Sydney airport, one which would not only solve Sydney's airport needs but also provide benefits. Labor intended to provide a ring‐road which would finally connect the south‐west of Sydney to the main western lines and main western freeways. That would have had massive employment benefits for the people of western Sydney.

Labor also wanted to make sure that we were not simply transferring the problem from Sydney airport to Sydney West airport. So we undertook to do a review and an update of the EIS, and that update was due to report. But it was not to be an EIS looking at alternative sites, because that process has already been done. With this decision today the coalition are essentially saying, `We'll turn the clock back 20 years and we'll once again start the whole process.' It is as though no money has been spent, no money has been allocated and no sites have been looked at up to this time.

The Liberals' agenda has been consistent in one thing only—that is, if Labor is for it, they are against it. As the member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) would know, the member for Bennelong and the then New South Wales Premier Nick Greiner were the leading advocates for a third runway at Kingsford Smith airport. As members opposite would also know, prior to the election the then Liberal opposition made a statement that Badgerys Creek would go ahead. In fact, on 16 February this year the headline on page 1 of the Sydney Morning Herald read `Liberals look at making Badgerys main airport'. They have taken a turn, like so many of their broken promises, because it is against the interests of the airline industry and because of their obsession with short-term budgetary considerations. They are just not prepared to put the money that is necessary into public infrastructure.

To find out the Liberals' real agenda, I refer to the comments of Chris Brown, who is on the Tourism Task Force. Yesterday he went on the John Stanley program on Radio 2UE in Sydney. When asked about their agenda, his response was pretty interesting. He said:

There's (1) getting smaller aircraft off the parallel runway, which means maybe—maybe eighty movements of proper planes an hour, you know, might be appropriate—we can possibly still live with that—but when eighty movements an hour include, you know, the old Pitt Street farmer coming in and landing there in time for his lunch appointment in Sydney, denying the tourism industry the export dollars it brings from access to Sydney Airport, then that's the first place to look.

I say to members opposite, and particularly those who represent the National Party and rural areas, that with the expansion of Sydney airport—which is inevitable unless something else is done—rural New South Wales will miss out. They will be forced out because of the need to accommodate the larger jet movements. Chris Brown further said:
There are smarter operational ways of using that airport—
referring to Sydney—
particularly with the north‐west, and in the longer term we're going to have to consider ways to increase the infrastructure at KSA.
There is billions of dollars invested in those terminals, in those runways, and if we can find measures which will increase runway capacity there . . .
I think the tourism industry's agenda is very clear, and what has further been exposed is the attitude of those opposite towards community consultation.

Where has the community consultation been with the electorate of Hughes over the choosing of the Holsworthy site? We saw the abolition of the Sydney Airport Community Consultative Committee, of which I was a member and which was established by the previous government. That committee was working very well. We came up with a 20-point plan which would have resulted in an immediate reduction of aircraft noise of 30 per cent in the areas around Sydney airport. That committee did not operate along party lines; it operated in the interests of residents. There was only one vote in its one year of existence. It came up with a number of programs, such as the expansion of the acquisition zone in Sydenham and the increase in insulation, which were considered positively and agreed to by the federal government.

We hear a lot of rhetoric from the conservatives about how much they care about working people and how much they care about small business. The committee was considering giving support and compensation and had carried a resolution of support and compensation for small business residents in Sydenham. Because of the third runway, small businesses in Sydenham have had their living denied to them. Businesses are closing down, no-one is going into their stores, and there has been no word from this government about whether they will receive compensation. They have been told that they just have to wait.

The government set up a committee to look into the flight paths and to report back by 16 December. Advertisements have been placed in the Sydney Morning Herald and in local papers in my electorate. It is interesting to see who is on that committee. The group receiving the submissions, the Air Traffic Management Task Force, consists of experts on civil and military airspace, flight operations, air safety, environmental issues and communications. There is not a single mention of residents. It is as though people do not matter; the airport is simply there to service industry.

As the member who serves the electorate most affected by aircraft noise, I contacted Airservices Australia and asked for a list of who was on this committee. I was told that it was not available and that an official announcement would be made at a later date. Let me quote from the coalition's airport policy, laughingly called `Putting People First', launched at the last election:
The coalition has activity consulted Sydney residents . . . In government we will continue to listen to your views.

That is another broken promise. Obviously, if you live in Hunters Hill or Lane Cove your views are listened to, but if you live in Marrickville, Sydenham or Rockdale do not bother because this government will ignore you. Added to that are the residents of Hughes. If you live in east Liverpool, Chipping Norton or around Holsworthy, do not bother. I wonder whether this government consulted its marginal member, the honourable member for Hughes (Ms Vale)—destined to be a oncer as a result of today's announcement—about the decision before it was made.

Preferential treatment has been taken a step further. During the election an announcement was made that no planes would go over the electorate of Lowe; the Bermuda Triangle was going to operate. The planes would take off from Kingsford Smith airport. They would hit the Iron Cove Bridge. They would not go right because they would hit the Sydney Harbour Bridge. They would not go straight ahead because we are against the Bennelong funnel and they would not go left because that was over the electorate of Lowe. They would just disappear into thin air. Perhaps the government's commitment to competition policy suggests that they are competing with the new ride at Seaworld in Queensland. That is what would have to happen.

This is pretty interesting because there will be another announcement in the next few days. The government, I am sure, will be setting up some form of farcical community consultation. I would not be at all surprised if the chair of that farce is none other than the member for Lowe (Mr Zammit).

You can have it one of two ways: either Lowe is not affected by aircraft noise—in which case why does the member for Lowe care?—or it is going to be affected by aircraft noise, in which case it is yet another lie. If the member for Lowe agrees to chair that committee, then he stands condemned, as he does by being prepared to participate in today's debate.

As I said in question time, recent figures show that Sydney airport has grown by over 9.6 per cent. We have an absurd situation in Holsworthy. The Minister for Transport and Regional Development, in his statement today, said:
At the time of the 1985 EIS, Holsworthy was not considered suitable because of engineering and unexploded ordnance problems together with the roughness of the terrain and distance from the city.

Maybe he is trying to slip something through. I understand that ordnance problems refers to bombs. When he talks about less aircraft noise around Holsworthy, perhaps he is excluding the noise that will be made from bombs exploding as the planes arrive. `Undulating terrain'—it will be like landing at the top of Kathmandu. As I understand it, there are 60‐metre ravines on this site and the largest number of significant Aboriginal sites—23, in fact. It has all been considered and rejected. What we are really seeing is another part of Costello's con, another part of deferring budget expenditure.

I should not say that the Minister for Transport and Regional Development made the announcement on Alan Jones's program; it was more like Alan Jones made the announcement and had the Minister for Transport and Regional Development along to listen. However, when the announcement was made, selling off the land at Badgerys Creek was left open. The government has already acquired it; it has already spent $152 million. Perhaps there will be an announcement down the track that the government will be selling off that land.

Sydney cannot afford to wait. This is an outrageous breach of faith by the coalition. The former Minister for Transport, the honourable member for Kingsford‐Smith (Mr Brereton), is in the chamber now. To his credit, he had the courage to come out and say that Sydney West airport would be built and he put mechanisms in place to ensure that that would occur.

He was attacked by the coalition. They said, `Oh, we'll do it better.' But we have seen that they will not do it at all. They will not spend the money, the noise will not go away, and there will be an inevitable push to get rid of the curfew and the cap at Sydney airport. We will see both north-south runways running at maximum capacity—approximately 450,000 movements per year and not the 263,000 movements we saw last year.

The government stands condemned. If I were the member for Hughes, I would be pretty nervous. I say to the member for Lowe that a lot of statements have been made. John Howard chose to launch this as his first policy in the electorate of Lowe, and we will be reminding the electorate of the government's broken promises. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —These three bills were introduced on 8 May. Supply Bill (No. 1) authorises the Minister for Finance to issue an additional $14,659 million from the consolidated revenue fund. This measure will provide for sufficient expenditure to maintain government service delivery until the August budget is passed by the parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: The supply bills must be passed by the parliament before 1 July this year to ensure the government has the funds to maintain its program delivery. Amongst other things, Supply Bill (No. 1) foreshadows the introduction of bills to replace the Audit Act 1901. One of these bills will be the Financial Management and Accountability Bill, which is just one of three bills that will totally rewrite the way the federal government's activities are monitored and audited.

The reform Audit Act was a hotly contested issue in the last parliament, members may recall, with the then Labor government being totally irresponsible in refusing to support amendments to increase the independence of the Australian National Audit Office, the ANAO, from the executive. It was also proposed that the parliament would play a more pro‐active role in overseeing the operations of ANAO, predominantly through the establishment of a parliamentary committee.

These recommendations were based on the Joint Committee of Public Accounts report entitled, The Auditor‐General: ally of the people and parliament and a further report from the ANAO entitled Parliament's right to know: legislation to replace the Audit Act 1901. These recommendations should be acted on.

BREAK.PARA: Supply Bill (No. 2) seeks appropriations from the consolidated revenue fund totalling $1,720 million. These funds will be used for a wide range of measures affecting every department except the Department of Industrial Relations. The expenditure items range from the construction of public works and buildings to grants to the states for capital works. Supply Bill (No. 2) also details additional expenditure of $38 million for new government policy initiatives. The third supply bill relates to the parliamentary departments and involves an additional $68 million to keep Parliament House running.

All these bills, like Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No.1) 1996, are useful in gaining an insight before the budget into the policy and fiscal direction of the new government. The big test, however, will of course be the August budget. Can the government bite the bullet and cut expenditure where required and balance this with keeping faith with the Australian people? That judgment will have to be reserved for the time being.

However, we already have some insight into the agenda of the government. It appears that the new government is so far inclining towards window dressing. I refer specifically to the government's proposal to reduce the provisional tax uplift factor from eight per cent to six per cent. Although that undertaking was an election promise, it is tokenism at its very worst. But we will have the chance to debate that when the bill is brought on for discussion in the House.

Between now and the next election there will be two new certainties in Australian life to add to the age‐old chestnuts deaths and taxes. We have all come to accept that deaths and taxes are inevitable and under the previous government the death taxes and tax amendments were equally unavoidable.

To those, over the life of this parliament, we can safely add two new verities. The first is that this government will have broken or will break more election promises than you care to poke a stick at. The second is that the previous Labor regime is to blame because of the parlous state of the Commonwealth government's finances and budgetary condition. The extent to which both claims and counterclaims are true will, hopefully, become apparent within a comparatively few short months.

With a sensible commitment to resist new and eliminate existing duplication of service delivery functions between the federal government on one hand and the state and territory governments on the other, one can be forgiven for thinking that there is the promise of a new spirit of federalism in the air. But that feeling must be tempered by threats along the lines that, if designated federal taxpayers' funds are not used for purposes stipulated by the Commonwealth, it will nevertheless resort to tied grants or some other form of conditional funding.

Let it be abundantly clear: the system of tied grants to states and territories is the biggest single catalyst for duplications of functions between the states and territories on the one hand and the Commonwealth on the other. Tied grants also limit the benefits which will accrue from the states and territories competing to attract investment in industry by restricting the breadth of incentives each government may, at its discretion, want to offer or match.

On the score of Commonwealth funding for the states and territories, the government is justified in expecting the latter to accept a fair share of the pruning to be done to get the national government's budget back into surplus. But Labor has used funding cuts to make bunnies of the states and territories during its terms of office. While Labor's spending grew expeditiously, its states and territory funding was ruthlessly reduced.

It is now past the time for the Commonwealth to bear a greater share of the burden of fiscal responsibility, particularly in light of concerted action by the states to overcome the legacies of previous state governments. Let us hope also that this federal government does not lose sight of substance for shadow in its efforts to reduce its own spending.

Its action in reducing the salaries of so‐called junior ministers by $10,000 a year each is a classic example of penny‐pinching populism at its worst. It relies for its effect on the psyche of a part of the population that believed—and still believe—that all ministers and members are paid much more than they are worth. It shamelessly seeks to pander to blind prejudice. Never mind that salary levels are decided by an independent tribunal, the government as one of its first acts has set a precedent that will cause all members to defend future salary increases rather than getting on with the job they were elected to do. And all for what? It is a saving of $130,000 a year gross or, after tax and superannuation deductions, a net saving per year of $60,000 or thereabouts. The country deserves better than mere populist symbolism from a cabinet which should be devoting all its time and energy to the big picture items of expenditure.

It is to be fervently hoped that in its programs to trim what it regards as fat in the Public Service the government does not in the way just described go chasing every silly little rabbit down every inconsequential burrow. To this day, the lessons of the Fraser government loom large in the recollections of some. Across‐the‐board axing is no substitute for the elimination or refinement of functions.

If functions are not targeted and cuts of two per cent, five per cent or whatever are to be the order of the day, we will end up with more chiefs than indians in the service, as well as laying the foundation for lows to be followed by highs in some areas of essential expenditure.

If history has taught us one thing in this context, it is that, if an across‐the‐board direction to the Public Service to reduce numbers of employees is the order of the day, it is the gardeners, tea ladies, maintenance personnel and the like who will get the chop. Time wasting by those left in more senior jobs will necessarily proliferate and the restoration and maintenance consequently deferred will become a drain on future budgets as costs are multiplied by a factor of who knows what, in the absence of timely and methodical attention to essential tasks.

PARA.BREAK: The government will not be forgiven if it takes the easy way out in this element of its approach to cost cutting. The across‐the‐board cuts to either spending or staffing levels, without eliminating or reforming functions, is the stuff of short‐sighted, inadequate govern ment. It is necessary on one hand to reduce recurrent spending, but on the other hand it is pure folly to eliminate or even reduce necessary day‐to‐day running costs.

BREAK.PARA: Small business figured large in the most recent general election. In Australia today, some would say—and I am inclined to subscribe to this view—that small business is truly at a crossroads. If the business community does not receive the attention it deserves from the Howard government, it will never receive a proper hearing. With so much to offer, the coalition should—and, I hope, will—do everything to improve the business environment so that our economy can grow as quickly and efficiently as possible. Even more importantly, we need growth to achieve more rapid employment creation. This is so important for so many Australians, particularly our young Australians.

In pursuing a policy of freeing up small business, as has been promised by the government, one of the first targets should be serious attention to and reform of the fringe benefits tax. It is complicated and unnecessarily prescriptive. Fringe benefits tax legislation in New Zealand is only one‐sixth the size of Australian legislation, yet on a per capita basis it nets the New Zealand government more revenue. Not only that, the cost of complying with the New Zealand fringe benefits tax is just over two per cent of total fringe benefits tax receipts in that country while in Australia conservative estimates place it at over 12 per cent. So the fringe benefits tax in Australia is an example of unnecessarily complex tax law.

This new government must honour its commitment to simplify that law and all tax law. By simplification I do not mean a carbon copy of Labor's totally discredited tax simplification project. Real tax simplification means not only rewriting the tax laws but also questioning all policy on which those laws are based. Capital gains tax has become a monstrosity that is worse than the FBT. Tax professionals have even greater trouble figuring out the requirements of that legislation.

Australia needs to get the capital gains tax off the backs of all Australians to the maximum possible extent. We should be aiming to phase out capital gains tax over the five years following the purchase of each capital item, by reducing each taxable gain by 20 per cent per year. At the very least, the Howard government needs to honour its promise of providing capital tax rollover relief to small business proprietors who reinvest the proceeds from the sale of a small business into another or into an approved superannuation scheme.

Reform of the industrial relations system is a definite requirement. It is needed to provide small businesses with a labour market system which encourages flexibility and increased productivity. Small businesses want to employ more people in the main, but when the system actively discourages this, such as with the unfair dismissal laws, they naturally avoid employing more staff.

Of course, legislation reforming the industrial relations system should also benefit employees. The benefits of greater productivity and profitability will flow on to workers in the form of higher real wages. This is only fair. In providing small business with a conducive environment in which to operate, it is not enough for government to just provide a better tax system and a more flexible industrial relations system. The government also needs to create a macro‐economic environment which is favourable. To that end, lower interest rates are an important factor. At the same time Australia needs to increase national savings and move to a net government sector surplus if interest rates are to be brought down to sustainably lower levels.

We have heard much about slashing $8 billion from federal government outlays over the next two years. Obviously, this is necessary because of successive Labor governments' profligate fiscal policies, aimed mostly at trying to buy off the electorate. In slashing expenditure, the government must maintain an appropriate balance between economic and social objectives, however.

The government's approach to cutting expenditure must also be strategic in that it must look to the longer term picture. All programs should be judged against the criteria: what is the objective of the program? Is the objective still relevant? Is the program achieving the objective? Are the alternative means of achieving the objective involving less reliance on government support? To the extent that government support is required, can it be delivered in a more efficient manner?

These criteria have been applied to the best practice and workplace bargaining programs within the Department of Industrial Relations, I understand. Both programs, on examination, lacked objectives which met the public interest, and were axed. Both programs were integral components of Labor's strategy of transferring taxpayer funds to the trade union movement. Other government programs across all departments should face similar rigorous scrutiny and, when found wanting, they should get the chop.

The proposals currently being mooted involving the transfer of some responsibilities to the states, especially in the areas of health and education, also offer great potential for eliminating wasteful federal‐state duplication.

It is Australia's low rate of national savings that has been an issue and so much the subject of public discussion over the past few years—and especially so since the FitzGerald report. Australia's household saving rate is projected to account for only 2.8 per cent of disposable household income in 1996. The Netherlands, with 1.3 per cent, is the only OECD nation with a lower household saving rate. In fact, the majority of OECD countries have saving rates of over 10 per cent.

Australia's household saving rate has not always been so low. In 1978 it was 11.2 per cent and it was about 14 per cent in the early 1970s. Although the level of household saving is expected to increase in the coming years because of compulsory superannuation and greater incentives to save, the real villain in Australia's shocking gross national savings record is the federal government's—and, to a lesser degree, the state governments'—poor fiscal policies. This was highlighted when the then Labor federal government in 1988 delivered a budget surplus and overall national savings increased to 22.4 per cent of GDP. In 1993, they slumped to 16.7 per cent.

As well, Australia's performance has been diminished by a poor—abysmal, one might say—balance of payments record. Although the Netherlands consistently has the lowest household saving rate in the OECD, because that country has an ongoing healthy balance of payments surplus it has maintained gross national savings figures which are consistently higher than the OECD average. In 1993, for example, the Netherlands achieved national savings of 23.3 per cent of GDP. If Australia is going to reverse its poor national savings record, it is obvious that the total government sector, both state and federal governments, needs to operate in surplus and households need further encouragement to save.

These bills are interim measures and we are in a holding pattern until the August budget. My misgivings and reservations aside, I wish the government well in the important work it has to do. It can hardly do worse than its predecessor.
Debate (on motion by Mr Bruce Scott) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 1 May, on motion by Mr Sharp:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tanner, Lindsay, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Ships (Capital Grants) Act was passed by the former Labor government in 1987, arising from the maritime reform process which was initiated originally by a former National Party Minister for Transport, Mr Ralph Hunt, and which emerged from the deliberations of the Crawford committee.

SPEECH.PARA: The act provided for the payment of a seven per cent bounty or grant to Australian owners of Australian registered ships that were at least 60 metres long and which had crew limits below 21 and, since 1989, below 18. The ships had to be either new or second‐hand vessels that were under five years old and had previously not been Australian registered ships. There was a five‐year sunset clause on the legislation and it was subsequently renewed by the parliament in 1992. It is again due to expire in 1997 as a result of the same sunset clause.

BREAK.PARA: The Shipping Grants Legislation Bill 1996, put forward to the House by the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp), in effect amends the act by removing the word `1997' and replacing it with `1996' in order to terminate the grant immediately and, obviously, to not roll over the provisions in the legislation as had previously been the case. The former Labor government had announced that it was going to extend the act again for a further five years to ensure that the grant remained available to Australian shipowners, but clearly under the legislation as it is now proposed that grant will disappear.

The legislation which we have before the House this evening also relates to the repeal of the International Shipping (Australian‐Resident Seafarers) Grants Act 1995, which was adopted by the parliament in response to the Ray Taylor report from SIRA, the Shipping Industry Reform Authority, and which also emerged out of discussions between the government, the Maritime Union of Australia and the Australian Shipowners Association in the latter part of 1994 with respect to the prospective sale of ANL.

This piece of legislation provided that PAYE tax for crew members on vessels trading a majority of the time on international routes would be rebated to the owners of those vessels as a means of ensuring that the competitive gap between Australian shipping and foreign shipping, particularly flag of convenience shipping, was effectively reduced and, therefore, that Australian shipping had some basis on which it could compete with international competitors paying little, if any, tax. It is important to remember that this initiative was not the brainchild of the Maritime Union. It was supported by the Maritime Union of Australia, but it was largely the brainchild of the Australian Shipowners Association.

As much as it may be derided by the minister and people on the other side, the initiative to rebate PAYE tax for Australian seafarers serving on vessels trading a majority of the time on international routes was in fact largely pushed by the shipowners, adopted by the government of the day and supported by the Maritime Union. It is also important to remember that the initiative involved the owners of the vessels, not the seafarers, getting the fiscal benefit. The seafarers retained the original take‐home pay, but the tax that would otherwise have been paid to the government was retained by the owners. The bill simply repeals this legislation.

The government has also announced that it is going to: repeal section 57AM of the Income Tax Assessment Act, which provides for an accelerated depreciation regime of 20 per cent per annum for Australian ships; either abolish or alter—depending on when you listen to the minister or when you read the government's policy statements—the provisions for cabotage and introduce a second register, although there is some form of inquiry planned with respect to both of those propositions; and sell ANL to the highest bidder at the earliest opportunity, though the government will await some sort of report, which I understand is due at the end of the month, from the ANL board.

There is also a question mark to complete the picture of the government's assault on the Australian maritime industry. There is a big question mark over $14.5 million of funding which had been budgeted for a world's best practice hydrodynamic testing facility that was planned for the Australian Maritime College at Launceston. The capital grants repeal legislation, supposedly, will save $12 million per annum for the government and the PAYE repeal bill will save $40 million over four years. However, it is important to remember that this is before tax. As both of those benefits were taxable, in the hands of the shipowners the amount that will be saved will be significantly less, particularly when you consider that most of the major shipowners would be paying company tax at a reasonably healthy rate.

PARA.BREAK: The government's intentions are clear. Firstly, a few more million dollars must be found for their Fightback agenda to cut the supposed budget deficit—the budget deficit crisis that they are creating as a guise for introducing a whole range of regressive social cuts. Secondly, there is a blind hatred for the Maritime Union of Australia and the Austral ian shipping industry based on the prejudice that comes from people such as the member for Corangamite who have been the users of these services. It is reflected in the fact that the minister has chosen to appoint Mr Greg Bondar, formerly Executive Director of the Australian Chamber of Shipping, as his maritime adviser. The Australian Chamber of Shipping, in spite of its name, is basically the lobby group for foreign shipping in Australia. It is pretty extraordinary that the minister has chosen to appoint somebody from that background as his adviser, particularly when you consider that it has been stated that Mr Bondar will continue to provide, for some time, assistance and support to the chamber. It is roughly equivalent to the minister for primary industries appointing the European Community's commissioner for agriculture as adviser on primary industry. If it is shipping, nobody seems to care.

BREAK.PARA: Thirdly, with the perverted logic that seems to apply with the coalition, there is an attack on subsidies and regulations that apply to people other than their supporters. If you are a National Party supporter then your subsidies are okay, your rorts are okay. Anybody else who wants some form of assistance will not get it.

The opposition opposes this bill and will vote against it both here and in the Senate. The minister is still acting as if he were in opposition. There is no overall strategy for the Australian shipping industry. Companies and investors have been left in limbo. For example, the recently appointed new Chief Executive Officer of ANL, Roger Perkins, stated in response to this legislation:
It is unfortunate that the government chose to abolish an important tax incentive at a time when other issues within the industry have not yet been resolved.

There has been considerable confusion about vital structures in the industry. On the one hand, the Liberal policy on cabotage was to abolish it and, on the other, the minister has said, no, there will be an inquiry. Then he said that the current single voyage permit arrangements would be extended and that the government would move over to something a bit like the New Zealand model.

With the second register, there was the same sort of response. The minister has announced an inquiry; the government has committed itself to introducing one. As for ANL, there have been all sorts of peculiar speculation about possibly selling it to Coles Myer or other potential buyers—a very strange suggestion.

There has been no examination of the effectiveness of the legislation that we are dealing with today, no attempt to look at the capital grants and the PAYE rebate to see whether they have, in fact, been beneficial to the industry and to the Australian community. There has been no consultation of any substance with affected parties, particularly the Maritime Union, until the last minute when the legislation was being introduced. There were no alternative industry assistance proposals being put forward. There was no real consideration of the merits of these initiatives at all. To the minister, they are just MUA rorts or Australian shippers with snouts in the trough.

We might well ask ourselves: who was it who actually initiated these sorts of assistance mechanisms? Who supported the capital grants legislation in 1987? The coalition. Who pushed the PAYE rebate? The shipowners—people such as BHP, Shell, Mobil, and others. There can be no doubt that this legislation will severely, and probably terminally, damage the Australian shipping industry. The Australian Shipowners Association estimates that it will increase the costs of Australian shipping by about 20 per cent.

International shipping is absolutely riddled with subsidies, tax avoidance and all sorts of arrangements designed to assist shipping industries of the particular countries. Twelve OECD countries have similar arrangements to our PAYE rebate. A number of OECD countries have accelerated depreciation allowances such as the one the minister proposes to abolish.

These things have been acknowledged recently in a speech by Mr Bob Hutchinson, who is the chair of the National Bulk Commodities Group and, therefore, obviously no great strong supporter of the Australian shipping industry—in fact, somebody who would be likely to be critical of it. Mr Hutchinson has acknowledged the importance of these fiscal assistance measures because our competitors right throughout the world have the same sorts of things.

Apelbaum Consulting figures that were provided to the Australian Shipowners Association comparing the cost structures of Australian shipping with other OECD countries and with the FOC countries indicate that, with these assistance mechanisms which are similar to the mechanisms that apply for other OECD countries, we are pretty competitive with other OECD nations. Also, we are only one or two million dollars per annum per vessel higher in average costs than flag of convenience vessels—and there are some other offsetting factors which tend to reduce that cost gap, like higher insurance costs for FOC vessels.

What will happen if these mechanisms of assistance are removed and nothing is put in their place? Rather than being relatively competitive, particularly with OECD countries, we will be put in an almost totally uncompetitive position. BHP Transport, in the latest edition of its magazine Ironships, states:

. . . removing the capital grants and the PAYE grants would have a dramatic effect on the ability of the Australian flagged fleet to compete internationally. The inclusion of fiscal measures such as these in the Australian flag are important in ensuring Australian vessels share a competitive base similar to those of international vessels against which they compete.

That is not the Maritime Union of Australia speaking; it is BHP, one of the major Australian shippers that operates both on coastal runs and internationally. It is very clear that, without this assistance, the Australian shipping industry will suffer enormously and the pressure to shift business offshore to flag of convenience vessels and operators will be enormous. The Australian Shipowners Association has stated:
. . . with such large increases in costs persisting, there is little future for Australian flagged and crewed ships.

End result: what is left of the Australian industry will be pretty slight indeed. In the time that is left to me, there are a number of detailed issues with the legislation that I might advert to. Australia currently has approximately 13 ships engaged in international trade and about 17 which trade both internationally and on coastal routes.

One of the significant things about the PAYE rebate, which is only just starting to evolve—because it is only a relatively recent initiative—is that it has created an incentive for companies with vessels that previously have plied only domestic routes to, in effect, double and split them up and use them half of the time on international routes. So there is already at least one example of a company buying another vessel and, rather than simply using one vessel on one domestic route, using each of two vessels for half of the year on the domestic routes and for the other half of the year exporting, in effect, shipping services by plying international routes into the South Pacific. That is only just starting with the PAYE tax rebate. It is an example of the things that will flow from this assistance structure if it is given time to operate.

We have a huge shipping deficit in our current account, and that is something which will be substantially exacerbated by these measures. A substantial proportion, if not virtually all, of the shipping that is currently done by Australians will shift offshore. About 15 per cent of our invisible imports, which historically have been the major problem in Australia's current account deficit, are accounted for by shipping.

In the debate about woodchipping which occurred about 18 months ago, I recall—as I am sure honourable members present this evening will recall—that one of the big issues constantly being pushed by many people was, `We've got a big deficit in timber and paper products in this country, why do we import so much?' If it is good enough to have that logic for timber, paper products and woodchipping, why don't we apply it to shipping?

We have an enormous current account deficit with shipping services. The government's initiatives this evening are destined to blow that out even further. The decimation of the Australian fleet will have a serious adverse defence impact. There are numerous vessels, some 40 or so, where the owners have memoranda of understanding with the navy which relate to how these vessels could be used in Australia's national interest in times of emergency or war. Some of them even have on‐board equipment which has been paid for by the owners for use in those circumstances. It will enable the ships to be used to assist the navy and military forces in times of emergency or war.

We all remember well—and I am sure the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott), who is at the table, will recall well—the important contribution made by merchant seamen in Australia's war effort in the Second World War which has only recently been recognised properly. I think it is worth asking ourselves the question: if such circumstances occur again, can we expect the same sort of contribution from vessels crewed by foreigners flagged in Liberia, Panama and the like? I think not.

The proposals will mean that we have fewer trained seafarers. That obviously has implications for our defence preparedness, for our ability to administer safety and environmental maritime regulations. It means that our overall maritime skill pool, from which emerge numbers of people specialised in skilled occupations—such as harbour masters, investigative and safety personnel for organisations such as AMSA, the Australian Maritime Safety Authority, and various other state agencies—will be reduced. There will be less demand for certain types of specialised services which will exacerbate that problem.

There will be adverse environmental consequences. One of the things that is probably not widely understood in the community is that bulk shipping is pretty much the most environmentally friendly form of transport. The cost base of shipping will shift upwards in Australia. That will mean that a substantial proportion, if not the overwhelming proportion, of cargo currently being carried on Australian ships will shift either to other modes of transport or to flag of convenience vessels.

We only need to look at a couple of figures on energy consumption to illustrate this point. Bulk shipping uses 0.2 megajoules of energy per tonne per kilometre compared with 0.4 for rail and 1.4 for trucks. In terms of greenhouse emissions, bulk shipping generates 13 grams of carbon dioxide per tonne per kilometre compared with 29 grams for rail. The figure for motor vehicles is much higher again.

With this legislation we will also see fewer replacements of older, less fuel efficient ships. The vessels that are carrying Australian cargoes will tend to be less fuel efficient, more energy consuming, more dangerous and more likely to be engaged in things like oil spills and maritime accidents, which are serious problems for our fragile coastline.

There will be less industry development. There are important spin‐offs that emerge from the maritime industry in Australia—insurance, provedoring and supply of high‐tech equipment. We do not build many large vessels in Australia anymore, but we do construct things like high‐tech guidance systems and various other components that go into the vessels that are constructed. Obviously, if the demand for those vessels is shifted offshore then the potential for Australian companies, particularly in regional Australia, to develop economically is going to diminish significantly.

It is instructive to look at Norway by comparison. Norway has less than one per cent of world trade—that is less than Australia. It has about 4½ million people, about 10 per cent of the world fleet and about 60,000 to 70,000 people employed in related industries such as ship broking, equipment, insurance, manufacturing and design. This is a classic example of clustering and economic development based on specialisation in certain industries.

It is unlikely that Australia is ever going to get to Norway's level in the maritime industry. That illustrates how we are going in the reverse direction and how we are losing all the potential that is starting to unfold for related high‐tech, high skill industries that are dependent upon having a substantial Australian maritime industry.

It is also important to recognise, and it needs to be emphasised, that Australian shipping has reformed substantially in the past decade. This is something that those on the other side routinely deny. We have seen average crew sizes shift from 31 to 18. The world average is 24 and the OECD average is 22. Australian shippers have invested $2 billion in the industry since 1989. These are the people that the Minister for Transport and Regional Development says have their snouts in the trough. There have been a thousand voluntary retirements and 1,500 seafarers retrained over the past 10 years. Since 1988, there have been 36 new or replacement vessels commissioned and the average age of vessels in the Australian fleet has gone down to 9.6 years which compares with the world average of 16.6 years.

We on this side of the House concede that more reform is needed, but it is churlish to deny that major reform and major improvement have not occurred in Australia's maritime industry. The enterprise bargaining process is just starting to unfold with BHP, ANL and the other major companies. That process should be given the opportunity to work. There are issues still to be pursued, particularly with respect to matters such as maintenance at sea and a variety of other things. I have every confidence, provided the industry is allowed to operate and provided its existing support mechanisms are not taken away as this legislation proposes, that further major steps will be taken cooperatively between the Maritime Union of Australia and the major shipowners to improve further the productivity of our maritime fleet.

It is interesting to see—and I will be interested to hear the view of the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) on this—that the shipping grant that is being removed by this legislation is being removed retrospectively. Shell is currently having a tanker constructed in Poland at the cost of approximately $53 million. The rebate was figured into the bottom line for that project—it was obviously worth several million dollars. The end result is that that has been taken away. BHP and Mackay Refined Sugars are in the same position. These three companies have made decisions based on this grant being in place for the forthcoming financial year. That is being removed retrospectively. Those on the other side of the House tend to get very hot under the collar about retrospectivity. Maybe it is a little bit selective.

Australian shipowners are angered by the government's accusation that they have their snouts in the trough. There was reference to this in the Daily Commercial News. The minister referred to the `windfall gain to existing operators' that the PAYE rebate legislation provided. As the example I cited before of a company moving to export shipping services as a result of the PAYE initiatives indicates, the suggestion that it is simply a windfall gain clearly has no basis in fact. I would like to quote a few statements that have been made recently by leading Australian shipping companies. These comments have been made in response to the minister's legislation. Shell Australia's marine manager, Mike Hines, stated:
The company was upset by the decision to withdraw capital grants for shipping on the basis that it has committed funds to a new vessel which is due to be delivered in March or April next year.

We view this as a grossly unfair and feel the government should have introduced a transitional provision to accommodate people like ourselves who have contracted a ship and based the economics of the vessel on certain criteria.
Australian Tankships shipping manager, Paul Bendy, stated:

It is disappointing to see all the efforts that had gone on within the industry and the last government to resolve the problem end this way. It puts the Australian industry in a more difficult position and we have somehow got to work around it.
Mobil's marine manager, Andrew Brooking, stated that the company:
. . . is disappointed with the removal of the incentives with nothing put in its place to compensate.
Robert Hartley, the manager of the Australian Shipowners Association, stated:
In the current hiatus, new investment in Australian tonnage is already being put on the hold.
Without these measures the Australian flag will decline and there would be little point to an Australian second register . . .

ANL has three trades where the immediate effect of the removal of the PAYE rebate will be $600,000 per vessel. Immediately the viability of each of those trades is seriously threatened—they are fairly marginal at the moment. BHP is concerned that this initiative will add significantly to the price of export steel which is the last thing that Australia needs, given the related shipping costs.

The ironic thing about all this is that to a substantial degree we are talking about phantom savings here. Not only are we talking about grants that are taxable in the hands of the recipient; we are talking about a situation where the removal of those grants is going to largely destroy the income‐earning base that produced the tax in the first place. What is going to happen with the PAYE rebate? Are we still going to have a lot of Australian seafarers earning income from Australian shipowners and then paying the tax, so that the government actually gains that $12 million a year? Of course not. It is going to go to foreign crews working on foreign flag vessels, who will not pay any tax, not in Australia or anywhere else. End result: no gain; a phantom gain.

Exactly the same type of thing is going to happen with the grant. The economic activity that is associated with operating the vessels that are constructed for Australian owners, with the help of the grant, will disappear. The end result is that income that otherwise would have been earned by Australian owners on which they would have paid tax to the government will be earned by foreigners. End result: zero sum game again.

It is also worth while noting that the proposal to abolish the accelerated depreciation provisions is in effect a very clear breach of the government's commitment not to increase any taxes or to create any new taxes. It is very clear that what this will do is increase the tax being paid by Australian companies engaged in owning and operating ships. It is interesting to compare the accelerated depreciation provision with some of the things that apply in sectors that are the natural constituency—so‐claimed—of the government: agricultural implements, 17 per cent; bulldozers, 20 per cent; harvesters, 20 per cent; general aircraft, 20 per cent; tractors and trucks, 20 per cent; and crop‐dusting aircraft, 40 per cent. They all get accelerated depreciation. There are no question marks about any of that. That is not a problem. But, when it comes to Australian ships not run by constituents of the National Party, they cannot have 20 per cent accelerated depreciation. It is okay for their mates, it is okay for their constituencies, but not for people that they do not like.

This shows the real agenda. The National Party and the government do not mind subsidies, they do not mind rorts, they do not mind snouts in the trough—provided it is their subsidies, their rorts, their snouts in the trough. It is reminiscent of Bernard Woolley in Yes, Minister with the irregular verb. It goes something like this: I subsidise; you pork‐barrel; he or she rorts. That is basically the National Party approach to these things.

Australia as a society has been constructed on a vast network of cross‐subsidies with people, industries and groups helping each other. You do not need to look much further than the natural constituency of the National Party to see where this has happened—with diesel fuel rebates, monopoly marketing schemes for various agricultural products, public sector research and development through the CSIRO and departments of agriculture, community service obligations—

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Telstra.

—In things like Telstra. A classic example from the former Minister for Communications and the Arts, the member for Dobell. Then there are gas and electricity, preferential tax treatment, and so it goes on. I do not oppose these things. I do not oppose these things because this whole country has been developed with these sorts of structures as a base, with everybody helping each other and people cross‐subsidising each other. As an urban dweller, the costs I pay on things like gas and electricity assist people in rural areas but, equally, what they earn in export income assists me.

BREAK.PARA: What the National Party is doing and what the government is doing is tackling the subsidies they do not like; tackling things that they see as rorts for people that they do not see as part of their constituency. They are quite happy to leave in place the 40 per cent accelerated depreciation provisions for the crop‐dusters and for all those things for their own constituency, for their own mates. It is doubly absurd because all of the competitors that Australian shippers face internationally have exactly the same sorts of provisions. Not only is the government removing things from the Australian shipping industry; it is not proposing to remove the equivalents from other industries and other sectors that it regards as its own base. We are removing the shipping subsidies in a way which is going to leave the local industry exposed to unfair competition from people who benefit from exactly the same sorts of subsidies and assistance from their own governments.

The opposition strenuously opposes this bill. It is driven by blind ideology and by hatred of the Maritime Union of Australia. It comes from a government which has so far shown itself to be completely devoid of any strategy at all for Australian shipping and for the maritime industry. Even the employers are saying that. The bill has minimal fiscal benefits for the budget because, when the grant goes, when the PAYE rebate goes, so does the tax revenue earned by the seafarers and so does the tax revenue that comes from the shipping companies to the government. The end result is a zero sum game. These measures are based on a perverted view that somehow certain sections of the Australian economy, certain parts of Australian society and of the community are entitled to be subsidised by other parts, are entitled to be assisted or entitled to be protected, but only if they support the National Party and the Liberal Party—only if they are their mates.

For everybody else, particularly for those involved in some sort of cost input to the economic activity that is associated with people like the member for Corangamite, there are to be no subsidies. The government is saying, `We do not care if we have got foreigners plying Australian routes, we do not care if Australian seafarers are put out of jobs, we do not mind if the Australian shipping industry goes under, because you do not support the National Party and the Liberal Party. All we are interested in is the costs that apply to our mates. They can keep their subsidies, they can keep their assistance, but we are happy to deregulate everybody else.' The opposition is strongly opposed to this bill and will be voting against it both in the House and in the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur, Stewart, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I acknowledge the presence in the House of the member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) and I would like him to stay for just a couple of moments.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Bruce Scott interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I find that remark offensive and I demand that it be withdrawn.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J. A. Crosio)

TALKER.NAME: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J. A. Crosio)

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister would be aware of what he said. I must admit I was listening to the debate.
—I want it withdrawn, please, Minister. There were no grounds for that statement. I came into the House to speak.
—I will withdraw if it upsets the honourable member. I said that I just hope the member opposite has the decency to stay and listen to the debate.
—I spend far more time in this chamber, Minister, than you do.
—Order! The member for Shortland asked for a withdrawal; it has been done. The member for Corangamite has the call.

—Thank you, Madam Deputy Speaker. Could I address my remarks to some of the comments the shadow minister, the member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner), made on the bill before the House, the Shipping Grants Legislation Bill 1996. I appreciate some of the more sensible comments on the relative costings of sea, rail and road. I understand that and accept those to be the true relativities, and I accept the importance of cheap sea transport. I note also his comment that the average age of Australian shipping is 9.6 years compared with the world average of 17 years. However, on most of his other propositions he shows a considerable lack of knowledge of the issues before the House.

SPEECH.PARA: I would be interested to hear what the member for Shortland has to say about this bill, because he has a great understanding of the issues. Whilst I might disagree with him on some matters, the member for Shortland has had long experience in the industry. The same applies to the member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), and I also look forward to hearing his remarks on this important bill before the House.

The member for Melbourne, the shadow minister, who is at the table, talks about exports. Unfortunately, the shadow minister will not allow woodchips to be developed as an export industry. He should go back to his coffee shops in Melbourne and develop some of those arguments with his greenie mates, because he will not allow the woodchip industry to be developed so that it can become an exporter and can utilise the shipping that he is talking about.

Let us look at the big issues that we are addressing here in the parliament. Should the taxpayers be funding handouts to particular industries? This industry is a case in point. Do we say that special grants would aid competitiveness? The shipping industry is a classic case where grants continue to be given to the shipping industry and the waterside workers, yet competitiveness has steadily declined. Taking the position of the US wheat industry, have handouts and subsidies improved the competitiveness of that industry? Likewise, in European agriculture, have the handouts by the taxpayers—some $US50 to $US60 billion—improved the competitiveness of those industries?

Given that four per cent of our international trade is conducted in Australian flag ships, the arguments of the shadow minister at the table are somewhat lacking. Australian ships carry very little of Australia's export and import goods, so this whole argument that we need to support the Australian shipping industry is not paramount to the way our exports and imports are carried across the sea by foreign owned vessels.

As most of us would know, most Australian shipowners are vertically integrated industrial companies, such as BHP, Shell and Caltex. The Shipping Grants Legislation Bill 1996 undoes the grants implemented last year to Australian shipowners engaged in international trade. Members of this House would well recall the arguments when these grants were paid as part of a peace deal brokered to end the Maritime Union strike in 1994 over the sale of ANL.

There was a lot of debate throughout the nation, and the strong and leveraged position of the Maritime Union was used on that occasion. The strike resulted in an estimated 200 ships being stuck in Australian ports for five days just over this comparatively minor matter. According to the Australian Chamber of Shipping, the cost of that strike to the shipping industry was approximately $55 million.
