The peace deal initially involved a PAYE tax exemption for seafarers, but Treasury had second thoughts and convinced the government to actually pay the grants to the shipowners, for simplicity and transparency. Again, the shadow minister at the table would well recall those arguments when the former Minister for Transport got up day after day in this parliament and expounded the virtues of this deal. Of course, in the final analysis the Treasury would not come clean on it and there was another backdoor way of implementing it.

These grants were the equivalent of nominal income tax payable on the earnings of seafarers serving on the ship. Another part of the deal was to strive for further efficiencies in international shipping. Again, they were pies in the skies, given the circumstances. Another element was the peace accord to minimise industrial disputation. Just after we had had a major strike on the waterfront, there is this deal between the former minister, Laurie Brereton, and the MUA and the other maritime unions.

However, the MUA took the action of a national strike to support 75 striking workers at CRA. That was their next move—so much so that they brought the nation to a standstill because of the activities at Weipa. The shadow minister should be well acquainted with the fact that, during the recent federal election, voters at Weipa voted very strongly to support the coalition. What a remarkable turn of events. Having held the nation to ransom, they in fact voted for this side of the parliament and not the other side.

The budgetary cost of these grants is estimated at $52 million. This was the sort of deal that the former minister was prepared to do to get out of a bit of a hole. The grants cost about $90 million last year, and this amount basically went to the shipowners. In order to be eligible for the grant, the ship must spend the majority of its time in international trade.

There are 21 shipowners and 78 Australian owned and registered ships. That is a comparatively small number in view of the amount of international trade that Australia conducts. Of these ships, 31 are sufficiently involved in international shipping to receive the payment. I would be interested to know how they make the judgment: how do you define those ships that are in international waters and those that travel on domestic routes?

BHP is the largest shipowner in Australia, and others are oil companies such as Mobil, Shell, BP and Caltex, and ANL as well. There are two important things to remember: first, only four per cent of international trade goes into and out of Australia on Australian ships; and, secondly, most Australian shipping companies are vertically integrated industrial companies: BHP, Shell—one ship based at Geelong—BP and Caltex, and CSR in the sugar industry.

The grants were paid to the shipowners in respect of between 1,000 to 1,200 Australian seafarers. There are not really many personnel involved, but there is a lot of money involved. The money does not flow to the seafarers themselves, but they benefit from the grants because it makes them easy to employ. On the one hand, you have a bribe to get the people back to work and, on the other hand, you give the money to shipowners. That is a strange way to do business, and I would be interested to know how the shadow minister at the table can defend that position.

Effectively, their employment is subsidised by about $20,000 per year. The base salary of an Australian crew member is around $40,000. They work eight hours a day plus overtime. They work six months on and six months off. Members of the House ought to be aware of that. I recognise the member for Throsby. I am delighted to see him in the chamber. They work six months on and six months off. All members of the Australian work force ought to be aware of this. Those terms and conditions are quite good because, in the six months off, crew members, wherever they might be, can find another job. They are often employed under the pooled labour system where they are allocated to ships as required. They do not develop loyalty to a particular company.

I looked at some of the details of these pooling labour systems, as they have worked on the waterfront, in the shipping industry. The situation seems to be that the deck officers and engineers are employees of shipping companies. That is fair enough. They have a loyalty to the shipping company.

The ratings—crew members—are part of the industry pool, which we have been trying to get away from. Even the member for Shortland would appreciate that. These ratings are called marine cooks, marine stewards—a seaman's engagement type system. It is written in the award that they have these pooling type systems. The shipping companies are responsible for paying the ratings while they are on the ship and while they are on leave, which they take after their six months. The ratings, after their period of leave, go back into the industry pool for relocation.

I thought all of us on both sides of the House were looking to change that pooling arrangement, because we know the devastating effect it has on the waterfront. We have this situation where the pooling system does nothing for the waterfront, it does nothing for the shipping companies and in general it does nothing to enhance efficiency or loyalty to any particular employer.

I concede the point that crew numbers on Australian ships have come down from 30 per vessel to an average of 18 per vessel. I have had a number of discussions with Bill Bolitho about this matter and I concede that on some of the ANL ships these ratios are encouraging and are reaching world‐class standard.

However, the crewing factor stands at 2.13 compared with an international benchmark of 1.7. These crewing measures are the number of crew required to fill one berth. That is an interesting comparison. If you look at the berthing required over a 12-month period, you find that a high proportion of these crew members are on generous leave provisions. They are either on sick leave, long service leave, training or holidays, which is part of the award.

If you look at the strike arrangements on the waterfront and the shipping industry now under the MUA, you see that there is a very strong connection between those groups. If one group is not getting its way, it encourages the other group to support it. Over the last three or four years we have seen the activities of the MUA on the waterfront and nationally.

In a recent edition of Workforce, an industrial relations newsletter, a remarkable situation is claimed. A survey of international shippers found that Australia was the second worst country in the world for strikes affecting shipping and that 23 per cent of the strikes which affected international shipping originated in Australia. That is the figure as reported by this international newsletter; a figure which most people in Australia would come to understand as being true and correct. The recent activities of the MUA really indicate their muscle. Comments last week to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) indicate that they are prepared to use their particular type of industrial muscle to achieve any outcome they think is to their benefit.

Let me draw to the attention of the House the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority program, where $450 million was paid out to 4,000 retiring wharfies. What other industry pays out this amount of money to ensure the retirement of this number of people?

TALK.START.PARA: —Subsidies to farmers.

—I am just giving you the facts. The member for Throsby would understand this. Certainly a lot of money has been paid just to achieve a more efficient end. Another $17 million was spent on redundancies in the shipping industry under the Shipping Industry Reform Authority. So the taxpayer has consistently paid for the waterfront and shipping industry to lift its competitiveness. And what real competitiveness have we achieved?

SPEECH.PARA: I want to talk about the second register and note some of the associated arguments. I know honourable members opposite have pretty strong views about foreign crews and the removal of cabotage, and I guess that is an argument for another day. I also want to talk about the Maritime Union of Australia and a list of some `outrageous proposals' in their publication of January-February 1996.

They are saying that John Howard's government is proposing a list of outrageous coalition proposals. These include a second Australian register and non-union labour on the wharves—how outrageous! Also included is port privatisation, an end to cabotage, an end to the trans-Tasman accord and an immediate sale of ANL—how terrible that is! It is losing great amounts of money and should have been sold two or three years ago. Also mentioned is a watered‐down unfair dismissal law—what a terrible thing to be suggesting, that we change the unfair dismissal law! Another proposal is a deregulated labour market.
Further on in this document, Mr Terry Shaw tells his members why they should vote for the ALP. He says:

John Howard says he wants to bring non-union labour onto the waterfront. And he would open the Australian coastline to foreign ships . . . He would also look at setting up a second register or flagging out Australian vessels and he would privatise our ports. A Howard Government would reintroduce the secondary boycott legislation to make it easier for employers to sue the union.

We all know the arguments about the secondary boycott legislation, and I am delighted to support John Howard on that particular approach. I also want to talk about the shipbuilding industry and the subsidies that might be applied. I also want to refer to the report The Shipbuilding Industry: In the Wake of the Bounty . I note that the shadow minister for health, the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee), is at the table. I compliment him on that very good committee, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology, and this very good report.

I draw the attention of the House to some of the recommendations which I think stand up to debate on both sides of the House. The shipbuilding industry in Australia, as we observed it, had some problems, but it was certainly not the taxpayers' dollars that would make it more efficient or world competitive. As the honourable member at the table would recall, we looked at the aluminium construction in Devonport, we looked at the Anzac frigate ship construction by Amecon at Williamstown and we noted that the 1988 Industries Assistance Commission concluded that the bounty enabled industry to enter export markets but did not encourage a viable, efficient industry. They are very telling words.

Another comment was that the provision of capital to the shipping industry was a problem. As the shadow minister at the table would well recall, we had a number of discussions with shipbuilding industry leaders about the problem of obtaining capital for shipbuilding on a world basis. Other nations around the world were getting subsidies from governments and cheap loans at low interest rates. That was a major impediment to the Australian shipping industry—especially at that time, when interest rates were in the range of 23 per cent. They pointed out to us that that was a very great difficulty.

In terms of training, this committee thought naval architecture was something that needed to be improved. We were impressed with the state-of-the-art training of naval architects here in Australia, in both the smaller and the larger shipping industries. The level of skills and understanding that was displayed there was very encouraging for the development of the industry.

Another factor in the whole argument was the encouragement coming from the Department of Defence towards the Australian shipbuilding industry. The key element here was whether Defence would place orders and help develop an efficient Australian shipbuilding industry, as they did with the Anzac frigate project in joint venture with New Zealand. That starting point from Defence, with the setting up of the contract for the six frigates, meant that systems were developed, capital was invested in that Williamstown dockyard and ships of world quality were produced and will continue to be produced.

PARA.BREAK: The committee members were particularly impressed with the change in the new modu lar construction. All of us well recall our visit to the Williamstown dockyards and the changes that were taking place in computer aided design. What was more important was the contribution by Dr John White, the then manager of those dockyards, and the remarkable change in the industrial relations climate. That change was brought about by the good management of Amecon and the workers' dramatic change in attitude towards their relationship with management. I wish to put on the record my pleasure in and keenness for those changes that took place. They turned around what was formerly a hopeless situation.

SPEECH.PARA: The committee produced a number of arguments about the position of the shipbuilding industry in Australia. The position of the industry depended very much on a change in industrial relations, and that change was clearly demonstrated in the Amecon shipyard. It depended on innovative technology—such as the technology that was introduced in the aluminium shipbuilding industry both in Tasmania and in Cairns—and it depended upon new and innovative designs. The catamarans that were produced in Tasmania have now found a niche market internationally and, whilst there have been some teething problems with one or two of them, they are now selling in Europe and in North America. That is a great feather in the cap of the shipbuilding industry in Australia and is something that all Australians and all members of this House should be proud of.

The thrust of what I am saying is that it will not be taxpayers' dollars that will make the shipbuilding industry efficient—there will be relatively benign taxation regimes. The availability of finance, the entrepreneurship of shipbuilders and the dramatic change in industrial relations which the Howard government will produce will put the Australian shipbuilding industry on its feet. The efficiency in this industry will not come from the subsidies that this bill is proposing, including the subsidisation of ANL. (Time expired)
Debate (on motion by Mr Peter Morris) adjourned.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 6.25 p.m. to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That a Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters be appointed to inquire into and report on such matters relating to electoral laws and practices and their administration as may be referred to it by either House of the Parliament or a Minister.

(2) That the committee consist of 10 members, 3 Members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by the Government Whip or Whips, 2 Members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by the Opposition Whip or Whips or by any independent Member, 2 Senators to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, 1 Senator to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and 2 Senators to be nominated by any minority group or groups or independent Senator or independent Senators.
(3) That every nomination of a member of the committee be forthwith notified in writing to the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives.
(4) That the members of the committee hold office as a joint standing committee until the House of Representatives is dissolved or expires by effluxion of time.
(5) That the committee elect a Government member as its chair.

(6) That the committee elect a deputy chair who shall act as chair of the committee at any time when the chair is not present at a meeting of the committee and at any time when the chair and deputy chair are not present at a meeting of the committee the members present shall elect another member to act as chair at that meeting.
(7) That, in the event of an equality of voting, the chair, or the deputy chair when acting as chair, shall have a casting vote.
(8) That 3 members of the committee constitute a quorum of the committee.
(9) That the committee have power to appoint subcommittees consisting of 3 or more of its members and to refer to any subcommittee any matter which the committee is empowered to examine.

(10) That the committee appoint the chair of each subcommittee who shall have a casting vote only and at any time when the chair of a subcommittee is not present at a meeting of the subcommittee the members of the subcommittee present shall elect another member of that subcommittee to act as chair at that meeting.
(11) That the quorum of a subcommittee be 2 members of that subcommittee.

(12) That members of the committee who are not members of a subcommittee may participate in the proceedings of that subcommittee but shall not vote, move any motion or be counted for the purpose of a quorum.
(13) That the committee or any subcommittee have power to send for persons, papers and records.
(14) That the committee or any subcommittee have power to move from place to place.
(15) That a subcommittee have power to adjourn from time to time and to sit during any adjournment of the Senate and the House of Representatives.
(16) That the committee have leave to report from time to time.
(17) That the committee or any subcommittee have power to consider and make use of:

TAB.TAB: (a) submissions lodged with the Clerk of the Senate in response to public advertisements placed in accordance with the resolution of the Senate of 26 November 1981 relating to a proposed Joint Select Committee on the Electoral System, and
(b) the evidence and records of the Joint Committees on Electoral Reform and Electoral Matters appointed during previous Parliaments.

SPEECH.PARA: (18) That the foregoing provisions of this resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the standing orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the standing orders.
(19) That a message be sent to the Senate acquainting it of this resolution and requesting that it concur and take action accordingly.

We had a protracted debate about these matters when the parliament last sat, and I essentially covered these issues at that time. Although it was not a cognate debate, by indulgence I was given the opportunity to make some general remarks. Those remarks obviously canvassed the importance of committees as the government sees them. We are keen to see the committees established. There has been substantial debate about representation on the committees. For the information of the House, I advise that the committee structure generally has followed the conventions of this House, so representation is on the basis of the numbers in the House—in other words, effectively reflecting the election result.

By indulgence, I wish to comment on one related matter. There has been some debate as to whether or not members of the opposition should be included as a requirement in any quorum. If I can refer to this issue now, I will then not need to refer to it upon the moving of the amendments. There is no precedent for that. That has never been the situation in the House. Obviously, where a notice of a meeting is given, that notice is given to all members of the committee and they have every right to be there in attendance. On that basis, obviously we will not be accepting that unprecedented proposal. The committee structure works quite well.

I also think that generally committees have not operated on such a party political basis. They have attempted to draw on the merits of the issues rather than draw on party political views. For that reason, we will not be accepting such a proposal. I otherwise commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean, Simon, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of matters before us tonight. With indulgence, as the Leader of the House (Mr Reith) has had to make some general comments, I too wish to make some general comments as they apply to a number of the motions that are before us tonight. The basis of our objection has a common thread. At the appropriate time I will be seeking leave to move a series of amendments but, under each of the motions, to in effect group the amendments for the purposes of the consideration of the House. I understand there is agreement to that process.

SPEECH.PARA: We have heard the Leader of the House argue that there has been ample opportunity for debate in relation to this committee structure. There has not. I make the point at the outset that on the opening day of this parliament the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) said, after having congratulated the new Speaker, that the importance of reasserting the supremacy of the parliament over the executive was going to be a hallmark of what they are on about, and he also said, `I say that very deliberately.'

BREAK.PARA: The Prime Minister is very keen to remind us about how certain and deliberate he is about all of these commitments, but he was making very much a pitch for the supremacy of the parliament over the executive. He said:

It is part of our system of government that the executive is controlled by parliament and parliament controlled by the laws and the customs and conventions of our society. I think it is important that steps are made on both sides of the parliament to reassert and re-establish a degree of respect and regard for the institution.

That is what he said on the opening day of parliament. What has been the circumstance in the first sitting fortnight of the parliament? We find a situation in respect of the most significant piece of legislation that this government campaigned on during the last election—the sale of Telstra—where they would not let the opposition move amendments when we got to the detail stage of debate. The second reading debate was run out when it came—

TALK.START.PARA: —Everybody got a chance to speak.

—I said that. I am not taking issue with you about that. What I am taking issue about is that you would not allow the opposition to move amendments. If the parliament is to be supreme, why is it that parliament is being denied the opportunity to deal with the detailed amendments that go to the core of our concern, yet that was the first thing that the government ruled us out on? The second thing I might add is the convention—which I think is longstanding in this place—whereby matters of public importance belong to the opposition of the day, not to the non‐government parties. Yet we had a Deputy Speaker calling an Independent member to second an MPI that we had proposed on gun laws.

BREAK.PARA: The third area is that the Leader of the House has made great play of the extra number of questions that have been taken by the government in the course of question time. He boasted proudly of the fact that in the last sitting fortnight they had had 24 questions in each session. Questions they may have been; answers we did not get. In all circumstances, we are still waiting for the answers. If we are going to lift the status of the parliament, I would have thought it incumbent upon those who assert that this is what they are on about to have the decency to come into this House and give us some answers. I might say that the average of 24 has dropped pretty significantly this week under the difficulty that the government has been having with some of its ministers.

Today we were cut short, at 20 questions, because the minister who is sitting at the table with you, the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Prosser), was floundering around trying to justify the way in which his departmental advice demonstrated the complete opposite to what he was telling the parliament. So much for non‐answers; we are actually getting wrong information from ministers in the House.

If that wasn't enough, in the first fortnight the debate on these committees was reintroduced, after the Leader of the House had introduced it just before question time on Thursday, at 5 o'clock on Thursday afternoon when the House was set to adjourn at 5.30. He then proceeded to gag the debate on the committees. What was gagged through were the committees that had been set up for the House of Representatives. We only dealt with one of the joint committees, that is, committees that are comprised of membership of both this House and the Senate, but we had the gagging of our attempt to move amendments in relation to the joint committees. That is why we are taking time tonight to—

TALK.START.PARA: —Another filibuster.
—It is not a filibuster at all. The reality is, if you are going to deny us the opportunity to debate, we will use all the forms of the parliament to ensure that we get our fair say.
—A pathetic tactic.

—A pathetic tactic—I see! So it is fair for you to gag debate; it is unfair for us to try to use every avenue to get that debate. What arrant nonsense! And you sit over there and try to pretend, as the person who is marshalling the Prime Minister's commitment to lift the supremacy of the parliament, but you will not allow the opposition to participate and move its amendments. Not only did you gag debate on the committees, which is the reason we are here tonight, but you also had the audacity, in the first sitting fortnight, to gag an adjournment. I ask you!

BREAK.PARA: In the space of the first sitting fortnight of this government being in power for the first time in 13 years, they come in here and moralise to the world at large about the supremacy of parliament and lifting the standards, they gag our amendments, they gag the amendments in relation to committees, they gag the adjournment, they do not answer questions, and they try to pretend that what they are doing is lifting the standards of parliament. And that was only in the first fortnight. Let's wait and see what happens over the coming weeks.

Today we actually saw the Prime Minister threaten the Senate. He said, `What audacity of the Senate to move matters into a committee stage,' when the very process by which they are moving into committee stage is the process that you put in place when you were in opposition. What hypocrisy! What cant! Yet you say you want to lift the standards of this place.

In the last sitting fortnight we were forced to divide on all of these issues. If the Leader of the House tries to gag our opportunity on these issues tonight, we will resort to the same approach. If they want cooperation they have to extend it. We will not put up with a position in which they assert they will give us a fair go and yet whenever an opportunity arises to cut us down they do so.

We could not move the amendments on the last occasion. We had to move amendments for two reasons: firstly, they did not consult us about the composition of these committees which they have changed; and, secondly, they did not consult the Senate. So they are not only not consulting this side of the House; they are not consulting the other house on joint committees.

What sort of process is it where you say that you are setting up joint committees, you need cooperation from the other house and this side of the House and yet you do not consult them about it? That is what we are annoyed about and it is the reason why we are taking issue with it tonight.

We have a number of amendments that we wish to move, the thrust of which, in essence, is to challenge the quorum requirements under the new committees. As the committees stand, with a joint committee you can have a quorum of three. But, better than that, you can set up a subcommittee, the quorum of which can be two. Any of those three or two, depending on whether they are constituted as a committee or subcommittee, can make decisions for the committee.

They can have their choice—they can decide to meet in a telephone box if it is the three‐person committee, or they can meet walking down the corridor if it is a two‐person subcommittee. It would be a little cosy meeting of their colleagues. It would not be so cosy in terms of the party room debate that they have been going through over the last 24 hours or so. But the reality is that under the quorum procedures there is no requirement for a non‐government member, an opposition member, to be present. Yet the Senate standing orders requires such a provision.

TALK.START.PARA: —What precedent is there in the House?
—Here we go! Do you ignore the Senate on joint committees? Is that your approach? Is it your approach to talk about joint committees but ignore what the other side wants? Absolute rubbish!

BREAK.PARA: You moralise to us about your great consultations with your IR bill. If they are anything like the consultations you have gone on with on the procedures of this House, they are non‐existent—and that is a fact.

The reality is that, whatever happens to these amendments tonight, they will be amended in the same form in the Senate when these committees get there. Then you will have a stand‐off in which the Senate says that the quorum requires an opposition member to be present, as it should. Yet this arrogant, non‐consultative Leader of the House says, `There is no such requirement.'

Mr Deputy Speaker, you know how the committee system works because you have served on the committees. I have not served on the committees but I will do so in the rest of this session. The fact of the matter is that many of my colleagues have, and the whole approach of the committees is to try to get consensus, to get some sort of understanding to find common ground.

These motions will drive wedges and force a position in which you are not required to consult. You will end up ramming through—not by weight of numbers, which you clearly have—some shonky device that says, `Let's refer it to a subcommittee and let me and Snowy walking down the corridor to dinner decide what we will put up to that subcommittee.' It will make a mockery and a nonsense of the committee process.

If you in the government are serious about arguing that the standards, the form, the role and the responsibility of the House are to be lifted, how can you do it by debasing the very role of the committee structure? Yet that is what these amendments do. We will be moving a series of amendments that give effect to the requirement that the quorum rules insist on at least one opposition member being present when a quorum is held. We believe that this will lend itself to better cooperation on committees, better input, greater preparedness to face up to the issues and will have a better chance of getting consensus. But you seek to exclude that.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can turn up, you know, although I suppose that is asking a bit much.

—That is not right, because you could decide to call a secret meeting, wander down the corridor and make a decision and say, `Well, this is all in form.' Or you could decide to call it in circumstances in which you know we are away doing all sorts of things. You could get up to any trick in the book.
—Like at a faction meeting.

—You talk about faction meetings in the Labor Party; you are the past master at organising those sorts of secret, crooked deals. How many people were involved in the decision that got you the penthouse, Pete? Tell me about the penthouse; tell me how many subcommittees were there. Tell me the quorum that you needed to get the favourable deal on the penthouse. I can see that it has worked in your favour. You think it can work in your private life and you want to introduce it in public life. We are going to try to stop that. If we cannot succeed here in this chamber, it will happen in the other chamber. We will continue to pursue this issue as much as we can.

BREAK.PARA: I make the point that we are committed to playing a constructive role, but we cannot exercise that constructive role if the opportunity to participate is not afforded us, if the opportunity is simply thrown at us and it is said, `You cop that, we are not going to consult you. This is what we have decided as a government—take it or leave it.' We acknowledge the weight of numbers you have on that side of the House. Where there happens to be a majority in the numbers, you can do what you like in those circumstances, but it is not consistent with the proper forms of the House. Accordingly, I seek leave to move a motion in relation to this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —In a spirit of constructive—
—You are learning.

—It is a lesson for you. We are happy to give leave because we would like a sensible debate and we do not want the time taken up by unnecessary divisions, as happened last time at the behest of the opposition.
—I move:

BREAK.PARA: (1) That the following words be added to paragraph (8): ", one of whom shall be an opposition member".
(2) That the following words be added to paragraph (11): ", one of whom shall be an opposition member".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay, Leo, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendments. I think the important thing for the House to consider tonight is that what we in the opposition are saying is that all we want is a fair go. We hear from the government a lot of pious propositions, but what the opposition are saying is that we want a reasonable position from which we would be able to contribute to the work of the House. My colleague the member for Cunningham (Mr Martin), who will follow me in the debate and who, like me, is a former Speaker of the House, knows about the good work that the committees of this House have done over the years and, one would hope, will do in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem we have had with the government over the last few weeks is that it just wants to tear up most of the previous agreements. The committee system of this House, since it was reformed some years ago, has come down with some very good reports that ministers and the opposition have supported. The committee system has worked as a jewel for this parliament.

For a long while people considered that the Murphy changes to the Senate system had made the Senate committee system something for the rest of the world to look at. What we tried to do a few years ago was have the House of Representatives committees be as good as, if not better than, that. We set up an integrated system of committees that shadowed what were in those days the larger portfolio groupings.

Members on both sides took the view that this was a way they could contribute, very properly, to the life of the parliament and the life of the nation. Members on both sides went to the committee system, put aside the animosities that you get in this chamber and said, `What we need to do is to come up with some solutions to issues which both the government and the opposition can agree to.' Ministers in the past have used the parliamentary committee system to address issues that may have been too difficult for the executive government to deal with and too expensive for a commission of inquiry or something like that to deal with. My colleague the member for Cunningham will no doubt expand on that.

I have some recollections of being the chairman of what was the first economic committee of this House which was set up by the Fraser government—the old Committee on Expenditure. It was used by a number of ministers in the Labor government to bring down reports which both sides could agree on and which the government could pick up so that they could get some sensible changes to legislation and to government positions, because the committee went out and talked to a whole range of people and solved some of those problems that ministers had found a bit difficult to deal with in the past.

I think that was one of the best things which the committee system of this House did—it adopted a bipartisan approach. It said, `Let's try to get on with doing the best for the parliament and the best for Australia.' When we were in government we thought a good way to do that was to involve the opposition in it. We expanded the size of some committees from time to time—the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade comes to mind. At the time we expanded it we increased the government membership and the opposition membership.

TALK.START.PARA: —A proper proportion.

—The Leader of the House says it is about proportion. We argued with you a week ago that we think proportion is a reasonable position. It is about the proportion of people who are eligible to be members of committees. Unfortunately, the Leader of the House and his colleagues are not. If committees are going to work, it must be that the backbenchers come together, put aside the arguments we have and see whether we can do a good job for Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: If we come in here and say, `There's going to be a bit more room for government members and a bit less room for opposition members,' that is not the best way to get this system to work. What we said to you last Thursday afternoon, which gave you all the angst, was—

TALK.START.PARA: —It didn't give me angst.
—It gave a lot of your colleagues angst. It gave the Chief Government Whip, the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), angst. Bronwyn wasn't really happy about being kept here.
—Order! The honourable member should speak to the amendments.
—She took her medals and left.
—That is right. As the Manager of Opposition Business says, the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel (Mrs Bishop) took the medals and went. What we said to you last week—
—It was 6.15, too.

—You don't mind being here until 11 o'clock at night on Mondays and Tuesdays, but it was terrible that you had to be here at 6.15 on Thursday, wasn't it? What we said to you last Thursday was that we do not mind the government increasing the size of the committees of the House of Representatives by two members—that is fine—but let us have a bit of fairness in this. Let us increase the opposition's size by one—you have two and we have one. In that way, the Independents here can be accommodated, the opposition members can be accommodated and the government members can be accommodated. But the trouble is you are just damn greedy.
—Order!
—I shouldn't call him greedy?
—Prefaced by the other word.
—I can think of other things to say but I won't. He is just super avaricious—damn super avaricious, probably.
—He's certainly avaricious.

—As the Manager of Opposition Business said, he is certainly avaricious; there is no doubt about that. The point is that, if we had had an agreement last week whereby there was one extra opposition member and two extra government members, we would not have had this problem. What we are saying is that we just want a bit of fairness.

SPEECH.PARA: What we are seeing here tonight with the first of these amendments is the reduction of the membership of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, the reduction of the opposition's representation on the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade and the reduction in the size of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration. There are a number of members on both sides who want to serve on these committees.

TALK.START.PARA: —We're not actually changing the numbers on these committees.
—Actually, you are. The trouble is you do not know what is in your notice of motion.
—Only the treaties one, actually. You're talking about quorums.

—The point is that on the electoral matters committee there used to be 12 members and now there are 10 members. On the foreign affairs committee, the government has aggregated to itself an extra member from the House of Representatives and reduced the membership of the opposition. If you want to increase your numbers, we are happy with that, but let's do it proportionately with the opposition. The Leader of the House has said tonight, `Well, we won the election so we can do what we like.' In a sense you can do that, but you have to be fair. We have had the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) in the last few days stand up here and say, `Well, isn't it wonderful. We've had 20 questions today.' We have had 20 questions without answers, and if the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey) cannot stand up here without his book and read the answer he is in real trouble. Three times we stopped him from reading the answer out of his book, and he just stands up—
—Order! The honourable member should speak to the amendments.
—He is filibustering, Mr Deputy Speaker.

—This is exactly what the amendments are about because the amendments are about accountability. The government says that accountability is 20 questions without answers. What accountability in this place is really about is having the committee system look at what governments do and having the committee system being able to be resourced at a level that the committees can actually look at what the government is doing. What we know is that the government is doing its best to pressurise the Speaker to reduce the staffing for the parliamentary committee system—
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order.
—You are going to deny this now, are you?

—I hesitate to interrupt the honourable member, but obviously claims of pressure on the Speaker are both untrue and probably unparliamentary as a reflection on the Speaker. My second point of order is that obviously that matter is well outside the matters immediately before the chair at the moment. Not only are they irrelevant, but they substantiate the obvious fact—that the opposition, as they did last time, clearly want to filibuster on this debate. They should be required at least to be sort of generally relevant.
—I take the point of order from the minister. The honourable member should not reflect on the chair and should speak to the amendments.

—I am not reflecting on the chair; I am talking about the administrative arrangement whereby the government has required the Speaker of this House—the ministerial head of the Department of the House of Representatives—to reduce the amount of money that the department has to spend. The government is going to do that by reducing the resources available to the parliamentary committees, because it knows that that is the way government can be held accountable. To say that resources for the committees are not related to the committee system is just nonsense. That is one of the most stupid things I have heard the Leader of the House say so far.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: the matter before the chair actually is an amendment about the nature of the quorum. The committee structure is, obviously, generally in debate, but none of these motions in any way undermines the committee structure. It is a rather long bow. Again, it is part of the honourable member's filibustering tactic, but he should be required to stick to the matter before the chair.
—I call the honourable member for Watson, on the amendments.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, we are dealing with the government's motion and the amendment. The government's motion is to establish some committees. We think the way you are going to establish these committees is to gut them of staff. That is what they are going to do—they are going to do away with the staff. Obviously, the Leader of the House has just let the cat out of the bag. He knows that is precisely what they are going to do, and that is the reason he does not want that discussed here tonight.

BREAK.PARA: The reality is that the government will gut the committee system; it will reduce the opposition's representation on the committee system. The government wants to get away from accountability. We have all this pious discussion about how it is accountable, how it is this and how it is that. We have 20 questions without answers, unless the Minister for Finance can read the answers out of his speech notes. What we have is the real system that will look at what the government does. The real accountability system is that we will have fewer opposition members on committees.

If the Leader of the House thinks there is no problem with the opposition being involved in the system, I do not know why he does not say, `Well, you can have another member on committees' or `We can allow the quorum system to include a member of the opposition.' Obviously if there were no problem with this, he could accept the amendments of the member for Hotham. But the reality is that this is one of the greatest ramps that has been run through this place. What we will have is a mechanism that destroys the committee system. Up until now, we have had a committee system—

TALK.START.PARA: —Your smile gives you away.
—Are you going to bring him to order, or is he going to yabber on all night?
— Order! The honourable member for Watson should continue with his remarks.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, we listened to him in almost silence. All he has done is sit here and yap, yap, yap all night.
—The honourable member for Watson shall direct his remarks through the chair.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, maybe you would protect me from this thug over here.
— Order! The honourable member for Watson shall withdraw.
—He doesn't even think that is a reflection on him. He would revel in it. He thinks that is a mark of honour.
— Order! The honourable member will withdraw.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I will withdraw because it is a terrible defamation of thugs, I've got to tell you. What we have here is the government not willing to let the opposition participate in the system, and the government really sowing the seeds for the destruction of the committee system. What you will find with these people is that they will get out there with a quorum of three and they will come down with little reports of their own, and then we will have a series of minority reports.

BREAK.PARA: The one good thing about the system in this parliament was that there were very few minority reports from the committees of the House of Representatives. Both sides worked together; there were very few. If the government will allow a quorum system where a report can come down with three government members meeting in the Chief Government Whip's office, it will destroy the system. You ought to think seriously about it. All we are asking for is a fair go, a bit of justice and a bit of equity.
Let us make the system work properly. I think the amendments of the member for Hotham will go to helping the system operate properly, and I would ask the House to support them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to rise briefly to speak on this because I would be interested in some of the—
—Is this a personal explanation on minority reports?

—No. I had the pleasure of serving with the honourable member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay) on the Procedure Committee, so I know exactly how fair he can be. I was very grateful to him for describing how fair and equitable the previous system was. Certainly, in the case of the Procedure Committee it was very robust, and at times, of course, we had our differences which led to minority reports.

BREAK.PARA: As somebody who has an interest as a member in committee work, I must say that the amendments proposed by the Manager of Opposition Business, the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Crean), in my view, would detract from the work of the committee. In fact, if you think about it carefully, the requirement to have an opposition member in the subcommittee or as a part of the quorum of a subcommittee could well sabotage the work of a committee.

You could make sure that a subcommittee never effectively gets a quorum, particularly if it is looking at something that perhaps the opposition party may not have an interest in looking at very closely or, for instance, does not suit their particular political objectives. It may well be looking at some legislation, for instance. There may be times when legislation is referred to a committee for the—

TALK.START.PARA: —What has the opposition got?
—Well, if you recollect during the last parliament, a number of—
—Order! The honourable member for Moore shall direct his remarks through the chair.

—I apologise for that, Mr Deputy Speaker. In the last parliament, a number of bills were referred for consideration to committees of the House. If you wanted to delay the passage of bills you could organise for subcommittees to be formed with a requirement in the standing orders for one person on those committees to be an opposition member and thereby prevent the subcommittees from ever meeting and deliberating on the particular matters that they had been asked to consider.

BREAK.PARA: Unfortunately, I missed the opening remarks of the member for Hotham. I will deal with the position of the Independents, which is that we still have not resolved, as far as we are concerned, a satisfactory method of arriving at agreements in relation to our arrangements. We are obliged, as has been pointed out to us, to operate through the honourable member for Watson, the Chief Opposition Whip. I am not making a reflection on the honourable member.

Quite clearly the individual political interests of the Independent members are quite different from those of the opposition party, the Labor Party, and it is not suitable to have our matters or our business dealt with or arranged by the Chief Opposition Whip. Therefore, in responding somewhat to the comments made by the honourable member for Hotham in moving his amendments, I would like to point out that as yet we still have an unsatisfactory situation as far as we are concerned.

We are still considered, for all intents and purposes, as some sort of appendage to the Labor Party, which is quite clearly wrong. In actual fact we have substantial interests of our own which we want to see represented, and represented in a way that is recognised by the House. Thus far that has not taken place. The Leader of the House (Mr Reith) ought not to take any comfort from that either because thus far he has not done anything about it either. This is a totally unsatisfactory state of affairs.

In relation to the amendments moved by the Manager of Opposition Business, I would like to say for my part that, as far as the effective workings of committees are concerned, I think it would be detrimental to have a requirement that one of a subcommittee's quorum be an opposition member. Anybody with a modicum of commonsense would realise that that would be a very effective mechanism for stopping the committee system working if that suited the opposition at any particular time.

I note with interest that the member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith) and the member for Fremantle (Dr Lawrence) are sitting on the front bench. I want to make an observation about the difficulties often experienced by members from Western Australia in relation to committee work. The member for Fremantle came straight into parliament on the frontbench and she probably has not had any experience with the workings of committees in this parliament.

Most often meetings of committees are organised in the interests of members from the eastern states. Very rarely are the interests of members from Western Australia taken much into consideration. The point I am trying to make is that I can well see the situation where a member flies all the way from Western Australia to a committee meeting in Sydney or Melbourne, which is where they are usually held if they are outside of Canberra, spends half a day travelling, stays overnight, rocks up to the committee meeting in the morning and finds out that, because an opposition member is not there, the subcommittee will not go ahead.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, rubbish!

—The member of Chifley makes the observation that that is rubbish. I can tell you that I travelled to Sydney for a meeting of the Procedure Committee—it was organised in Sydney for the benefit of Sydney members—and when I arrived the Sydney members had not even turned up. It was a bit of luck that we managed to scrape together a quorum so that the business of the committee could go ahead. I had travelled all the way from Western Australia overnight, travelled back and arrived at midnight all for about a three‐hour meeting.

BREAK.PARA: In all of the debate over the business of committees, I point out that very rarely are the interests of the outlying state members taken much into consideration. I am sure that the member for Perth, as a member from Western Australia and one who has had a long interest in trying to ameliorate the problems encountered by members from Western Australia, would support my view that, if you had a mechanism built into the standing orders that would sabotage the effective running of subcommittees of committees, that would not be in the interests of members coming from the outlying states because they could well have the experience, as I almost did, of turning up for a three‐hour meeting, having travelled virtually all day and staying overnight, which is not going to go ahead because it lacks a quorum.

In speaking against these particular amendments I would like to point out that there is more to this matter than the somewhat superficial view put forward by the member for Watson that somehow this is unfair. Fairness comes through effective, cooperative workings in committees, it comes through all members having the opportunity to express their views—

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't you want a go? We are trying to give you a go.

—I cannot see anything in here where you are giving me a go. I cannot see anything in these amendments where, as the Chief Opposition Whip alleges, there is a better go for the Independent members. The workings of the committees are much better when they are allowed to be effective and able to continue without some sort of artificial impediment as has been proposed by the member for Hotham.

BREAK.PARA: Motion (by Mr Reith) put:
That the question be now put.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendments (Mr Crean's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

PARA.TAB: Original question put:
That the motion (Mr Reith's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SSO.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent notices Nos 3 to 8, government business, being called on together forthwith and one motion being moved that the motions be agreed to.
I have moved that motion because it is quite clear that the opposition's intention is to require a division on each and every matter so as to prevent—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. It is with great reluctance and some hesitation that I take this point of order, because I felt that when the Leader of the House first rose to move that the question be put you actually had seen me stand before him but gave him the call. I regret that this is now the second time that you have appeared to see me standing but have chosen to give the call to the Leader of the House. My point of order is that you should have given me the call, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—Mr Deputy Speaker—
—Order! I am responding to the member for Chifley.
—On the point of order—
— Order! I am responding to the member for Chifley. I recognised the Leader of the House. I did not see the member for Chifley. I call the Leader of the House.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, can I move that the honourable member for Chifley be now heard?
—No. I call the Leader of the House.

—The opposition has a clear tactic. We could have had the opportunity tonight for opposition members to speak to these motions and we were quite happy to do so. I noticed that one of the speakers during the earlier debate said that we had rammed these matters through. The truth is that we put time aside when parliament sat 10 days ago. The opposition set out to spend the whole time in divisions to prevent their own people speaking to the motions so that they could then stand up and say we were undermining our own pledge in respect of parliamentary standards. It is absolutely incredible.

SPEECH.PARA: So determined are they to make this ridiculous claim that, having said how important the committee structure is, they have just voted against the establishment of a parliamentary committee. The whole basis of their claim is that they do not like the proportions of members on the committees. The fact is that the proportions on the committees are a direct reflection of the numbers in the House—which are, of course, a direct reflection of the way in which the people voted in the 2 March election. So what they don't like is the election result. They think this is a good basis on which to run a series of divisions. It is absolutely laughable, Madam Deputy Speaker, and as you are such an impartial chairman I have no doubt you will nod knowingly in regard to what I am saying.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought you might try me.

—It is not for me to want to try you, Madam Deputy Speaker. I will continue to address all my remarks through the chair. So their first argument is they do not like the election result and they want a change which has never been undertaken in the House. We are just following the precedent. We are doing what every government has done, what every parliament has done, in every election since 1901.

SPEECH.PARA: The second proposition is they say that when you have a quorum an opposition member must be a member of the quorum. No‐one has ever proposed that before. They have fabricated this idea and then they come in here and feign concern about parliamentary standards. It is absolutely laughable.

I am glad I was sitting down when I heard the honourable member complain about question time. Today we had 20 questions. I have been in and out of the parliament and then I was back in again. Since I was sworn in in February 1985, I can never remember one question time when we had 20 questions given and answered. And they are complaining about question time! The piece de resistance from the opposition was when they said we had threatened the Senate. Yet, for years and years, we have listened to your side call the Senate absolutely everything under the sun, including an unrepresentative swill.

You keep talking about parliamentary standards. In fact, your behaviour now is just a carryover of your poor standards in the whole time that you were in government. When you look at this debate, you see that in 1987 the parliament established the committee structure as it now is. That structure had bipartisan support and the motions that have been before the chair are a continuation of that practice and convention in respect of the committees. I have read the debate from back in 1987 when we established the committees. We had 39½ minutes of constructive discussion about the establishment of the committees and that was, as I say, a turning point with a new committee structure.

So far on this debate, when we sat about 10 days ago we had 1½ hours set aside, most of which was spent in having divisions. Then tonight we had put aside 1½ hours or two hours, whatever it was, so that everybody could have their say. I said to the Manager of Opposition Business (Mr Crean), `Everybody can have their say, or you can spend the whole night having gags and divisions. Which one is it going to be?' And what do we have? We have gags and divisions. It is absolutely pathetic.

The reason you are doing this is so that you can go up into the gallery and say that the government is not maintaining parliamentary standards. Over the years I have seen juvenile behaviour. Your problem is that you have a whip whose whole record in government was to abuse the processes, the forms and the conventions of the House.

I have now moved this motion so that we can at least make some genuine effort to provide people with an opportunity to speak to this particular set of motions. We are not proceeding with the committee of which the member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) has been chairman. He is entitled to have his say. But for the moving of this procedural motion, quite frankly, he would not have had that opportunity. By moving this particular procedural motion, at least the House can have half an hour or thereabouts discussing these issues and the member for Cunningham (Mr Martin), who also wants to speak, can have his say. Your childish pranks at running a filibuster come to naught. I therefore commend this procedural motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean, Simon, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —We oppose the suspension of the standing orders. The reasons advanced by the Leader of the House (Mr Reith) are completely fatuous. To argue that this House has had the opportunity to debate these issues on the establishment of committees is nonsense. These motions were first introduced into this House at 5 o'clock on the last sitting Thursday. The gag was moved before 5.30—half an hour of debate to establish eight House of Representatives standing committees. Is that a proper course of action? Does that demonstrate a commitment to the supremacy of the parliament over his executive decision as to what the constitution will be? He tries to come into this place and say there should be ample time for debate, but only 40 minutes was allowed tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: So, in total, in establishing all of these committees we have had a little over an hour of debate. Do you know how long it has taken to actually get the first one carried by voting procedures? More time than enabled us to have a debate. More time was spent on procedures because of your arrogance, because of your ignoring the form of the House and because of your trying to deny the opposition the opportunity to move amendments, and this is what you have got. The fact of the matter is that it is not correct to say that the opposition has voted the committees down. What we have voted down is your ability to conduct secret meetings under the guise of parliamentary committees.

You have introduced procedures into this House whereby a committee can comprise three people or two people. You can have your secret meetings in a telephone box or in the corridor. There is no requirement for anyone in the opposition parties or on the opposition side to comprise that quorum. Yet when we talk about the joint committees where there is a requirement not just to take account of our position on this side of the House, the opposition in the House, what about the Senate? Don't you consider it part of the joint process? Yet it has standing orders—standing orders that require an opposition member to comprise the quorum.

BREAK.PARA: What we have is a procedure—and I think the backbench ought to understand this of the government side—that asserts that it is establishing committee processes here, joint committee processes, which will be voted down in the Senate. If you think that is smart, do it. If you do not think that is wasting time, then you are not understanding the procedures. We will be back here in this chamber—forget about how long these divisions might take—debating what the Senate sends back to us.

I think it is absolute nonsense to assert the supremacy of the House, to say that the executive is really leaving these decisions to the House when, in actual fact, the government is ramming these procedures through and not allowing debate. We on our side have always said that the importance of these committees is paramount. We have said that we want to participate constructively in them. We have said that we want to be available and not squeezed out by secret cabals organising their shoddy little meetings.

We have heard the member for Moore (Mr Filing) talk about how difficult it is for people to get across from Perth. Well, I tell you, brother, you will get not a look in; you will not even be able to book the air ticket by the time they have conducted their meeting down the corridor. They will have convened the thing, closed the shop—and you still will be at the booking agency trying to get on the plane. That is what they are talking about.

This is a government that is besotted with the circumstances of its election victory. We recognise that you won the election. We may not like it; that is true in terms of what the Leader of the House says. But the fact is that we recognise it. We have never argued that you should not have majorities on these committees—never argued that at all. What we have argued though is, if you are going to increase the size of them, why not increase the size to accommodate opposition members as well, not just government members.

This cannot be a winner‐take‐all situation. This has to be a recognition that there are two sides to this House—and some argue three. But for the purposes of this debate there are two sides. If you expect cooperation, if you expect a lifting of the standards of this place, there has to be dialogue entered into with us.

The Leader of the House talks about the approach that we are taking here. We do not take this deliberately. We take it in a reactive way, in a way that leaves us no choice because of the stupidity with which you have chosen to bring this forward. These committee issues have been on the Notice Paper for some time. But when were they introduced into the House? The Leader of the House introduced them just before question time on Tuesday. He filibustered up until question time was convened so that we could not get our say in before question time.

The Leader of the House then came over to me and said, `We need some of the inaugural speeches, the first speeches up; can we get a few with the Address‐in‐Reply?' I said, `Sure, we'll cooperate with that.' And we did. We said, `We'll cut a deal on the basis that you give us an extra position, one extra position, to accommodate all non-government members.' We put that proposition in terms of the House of Representatives. But he would not deal. Then he has the gall to say that we are not compromising, that we are not prepared to recognise their mandate.

The fact of the matter is: your view is `take it or leave it'. Your approach with this—the same as it is with the industrial relations bill—is to pretend consultation, to list all the times you have had discussions with people and to argue that that demonstrates a preparedness to involve, to consult. But you do not mean it. You are going through a sham. You have one view in life, your view, and you are prepared to ram it through at any cost.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just like the penthouse contract, it's a sham.

—That showed a bit more skill—the penthouse contract—because at least he was prepared to start with the high position and move down. He was prepared to compromise in the case of the penthouse and to considerable advantage to himself. The reality is that it is not as though he is incapable of compromising—
—It's only when there's a quid in it!

—He will do it only when there is a quid in it and when there is self‐interest involved. When it comes to actually giving effect to the pious words that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) came into this place with—that is, that parliament is supreme and the parliament will stand over the executive of this place; we want parliament not to be dictated to by the executive—we know he does not mean it. He has got instructions no doubt to force through the issues regardless of the merits of the debate. We reject that.

BREAK.PARA: This is the reason why we are attempting to get some commonsense into this debate. We are trying, by moving these amendments, to recognise that if the committee structure is to work it has to comprise quora who recognise the views of the other side of the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Quora?

—Don't you understand the plural of quorum? He is moving a cognate motion. I can understand that your teller cannot count and cannot read the pieces of paper, but I did not know that you were that bad in understanding the procedures.

BREAK.PARA: The fact of the matter is that we are insisting that the committee structure of this place function properly. That cannot occur unless the opportunity is properly afforded the opposition to participate in it. You are excluding us from the committee processes. By setting the process up by which you can have subcommittees comprising two people, you will have two people making these decisions.

Let us take the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, which we have just decided on. Do you not think that that represents all members of the House? Do you not think we have all got a view about what the electoral committee should be deciding? You are saying that you can make those decisions unilaterally. You tell us that in the IR debate things cannot be taken away from people unilaterally. You have unilaterally taken away our opportunity to participate effectively in the committee process. That is precisely what you will do in the IR debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —You're imagining it.

—I am not imagining it. It is your form; it is your style. You are totally consistent except when self‐interest is involved. We will vote down this suspension of standing orders. We want the opportunity to move all of the opposition amendments.
—Order! I call the honourable member for Curtin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the Leader of the House, the member for Flinders (Mr Reith)—

—Madam Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The standing orders of this place require that you treat the Independents in this place as part of the opposition. It is clearly the government's call. I think if you consult the clerk he would confirm that.

—Order! Both members will resume their seats. The honourable member for Curtin indicated that he wished to have the call. I gave the call to him. I will call the honourable member for O'Connor next. I gave the call to the honourable member for Curtin because he indicated his desire to speak previously.

—I want to congratulate the Leader of the House. He is the first franchisee of the Paul Keating system of arrogance towards this parliament. I hope the fee was not too great, but I do understand. I say to the member for Hotham (Mr Crean), `Welcome to the club. I am glad you have found some parliamentary purity at last. We did not hear much of that in the last parliament.'

SPEECH.PARA: I say to the honourable member for Flinders when he says that this is what has happened since 1901, `How ignorant are you?' He is arrogant as well. The honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) would have told you, if you had deigned to ask in your oratory ecstasy, when you were laughing your way through the processes of this parliament, that the parliamentary committee system in the House of Representatives commenced in 1972. For you to be pontificating as an authority does you and your party no credit.

You are the man who, as Manager of Government Business, has not had the decency, except on a couple of occasions last night after you heard the warning, to be in here to listen to the maiden speeches of a very talented backbench. You defied tradition. You are prepared to sacrifice tradition in this place. You are prepared to sit at that table and giggle and think it all a great big joke. You are a big kid who has been here since 1985 but has not had the experience of power. It has gone to your bald head, my friend, and I do sympathise with you—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I can assure the honourable member for Curtin that I do not have a bald head. Direct your remarks through the chair, please.
—I was talking to him, I can assure you.
—Yes, but you will address your remarks through the chair.
—I will from now on, Madam Deputy Speaker, but I was speaking to him then.
—I know, but you will still address him through the chair.

—Madam Deputy Speaker, any pretence by this government that they are paying homage to the parliament has been shot to pieces in their first two and a bit sitting weeks. The changes to parliamentary committees which they rammed through this place—to the advantage of the government without even a pretence of consultation with the opposition—is just one case in point.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, it is not only the opposition; the other non-government members have been ignored entirely. By default or compliance, the opposition have been a party to that. Perhaps they might consider their position on that some time when they are all getting overawed with democracy. You could be forgiven for thinking that the government's professed commitment to reinvigorating parliamentary practices was merely a euphemism for revenge—revenge on the parliamentary Labor Party which, I must say, was equally ruthless in using its numbers in government.

But I will say this for the now opposition: I do not recall their having to resort to the gag on one occasion over the last 12 to 18 months. Having reorganised the way this parliament approaches its business, they did not, to the best of my recollection, resort to the gag. The very first piece of legislation this government has put through the House of Representatives had a gag on it. That is an indication of things to come. It is an indictment of the government, but the chap at the table who giggles and squiggles his way through this debate deserves the greatest condemnation. (Extension of time granted)

I do not wish to take up time, but I might with a little bit of encouragement from those opposite. It would be indicative of the sense of decency towards the parliamentary processes, which is what the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) promised in the most unequivocal terms on more than one occasion in the lead‐up to the last election.

It is perhaps an indication of what is to come that they will allow me to speak for an extra moment or two in this debate. I am speaking in the knowledge that it is going to be cranked off when I sit down, and perhaps one member or other members will have an opportunity to discuss or to contest the gag that is now before the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Keep going.
—What would you like me to say?
—Anything.
—Do you want me to talk about your electorate, my friend?
—You will address it through the chair. You have about three seconds to go.
—Oh, I am sorry, I succumbed.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! The time allowed for the motion for the suspension of standing orders has now expired.

INTERJECT.PARA: That the motion (Mr Reith's ) be agreed to.

BREAK.PARA: (Madam Deputy Speaker—Hon. J.A. Crosio)

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade CommitteeNative Title and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund CommitteeNational Crime Authority CommitteeNational Capital and External Territories CommitteeMigration CommitteeTreaties Committee

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Reith) proposed:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Proposed Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade.

PROCTEXT.PARA: (1) That a Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade be appointed to consider and report on such matters relating to foreign affairs, defence and trade as may be referred to it by:

(2) That the committee consist of 32 members, 13 Members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by the Government Whip or Whips, 7 Members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by the Opposition Whip or Whips or by any independent Member, 5 Senators to be nomi nated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, 4 Senators to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and 3 Senators to be nominated by any minority group or groups or independent Senator or independent Senators.
(3) That every nomination of a member of the committee be forthwith notified in writing to the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives.
(4) That the members of the committee hold office as a joint committee until the House of Representatives is dissolved or expires by effluxion of time.
(5) That the committee elect a Government member as its chair.

(6) That the committee elect a deputy chair who shall act as chair of the committee at any time when the chair is not present at a meeting of the committee and at any time when the chair and deputy chair are not present at a meeting of the committee the members present shall elect another member to act as chair at that meeting.
(7) That in the event of an equality of voting, the chair, or the deputy chair when acting as chair, shall have a casting vote.
(8) That 6 members of the committee constitute a quorum of the committee.
(9) That the committee have power to appoint subcommittees consisting of 3 or more of its members and to refer to any subcommittee any matter which the committee is empowered to examine.
(10) That, in addition to the members appointed pursuant to paragraph (9), the chair and deputy chair of the committee be ex officio members of each subcommittee appointed.

(11) That the committee appoint the chair of each subcommittee who shall have a casting vote only, and at any time when the chair of a subcommittee is not present at a meeting of the subcommittee the members of the subcommittee present shall elect another member of that subcommittee to act as chair at that meeting.
